questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect in describing the location of the triangle of safety in chest tube insertion?

choices.text: Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle
Above the level of the nipple

questions.solution:
'Posterior to the mid-axillary line' is incorrect in the description of the triangle of safety in chest tube insertion.

Chest tube insertion is carried out in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line in the triangle of safety (image below). It lies-

  • anterior to the midaxillary line [yellow line]
  • above the level of the nipple [blue line]
  • below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle (lateral to the lateral border of the pectoralis major) [red line]

Chest tube insertion/ thoracostomy is indicated in pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, etc. Contraindications include pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.

The possible complications of this procedure are:

  • clogging of the tube (most common)
  • incorrect placement
  • intercostal nerve/vessel injury
  • subcutaneous hematoma/emphysema
  • pain

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient came with a complaint of blood in urine. Urine examination showed red cell casts and proteins. Immunofluorescence shows granular deposits of C3. Electron microscopy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis of the above electron microscopy showing ribbon-like dense homogenous deposits along the basement membrane is Dense deposit disease, formerly called Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) Type II.

Dense deposit disease has abnormalities resulting in excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway. These patients have consistently decreased serum levels of C3 but normal C1 and C4. Patients with this have a circulating autoantibody termed C3 nephritic factor (C3NeF).

MPGN is an immune-mediated injury that often presents with a combined nephritic-nephrotic picture. Since, the proliferation predominantly occurs in the mesangium and the capillary loops, mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis is a frequently used synonym.

MPGN Type I is characterised by the deposition of immune complexes with mesangiocapillary proliferation.

MPGN Type II is now called dense-deposit disease that belongs to a group of disorders called C3 glomerulopathies as a result of the excess activation of alternate complement pathways.

Causes of MPGN:

  1. Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
  2. Secondary MPGN
      - System lupus erythematosus (SLE)
      - Infections: Hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoatrial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses
      - α1-Antitrypsin deficiency
      - Malignant diseases, particularly chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL)
  MPGN Type I MPGN Type II

Option B: Membranous Nephropathy: This condition involves subepithelial immune complex deposits and is typically characterised by proteinuria (often a nephrotic range), but it does not typically show granular C3 deposits or dense deposits in electron microscopy.

Option C: RPGN is a clinical syndrome that presents with acute kidney failure and glomerular crescents on light microscopy. It may be caused by several types of glomerulonephritis, but the immunofluorescence and electron microscopy findings described in the question are not characteristic of RPGN.

questions.text: Viable but non-culturable (VBNC) cells are seen in which phase of the bacterial growth curve?
questions.solution:
The viable but non-culturable (VBNC) cells are seen in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve.

The following image shows a graph plotting the log of the number of bacteria against time in a population of cells termed batch culture denoting the bacterial growth curve.

Phases of bacterial growth curve:

Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation of the cells to the new environment during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence, by the end of the lag phase, maximum cell size is obtained.

Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time. One of two things limits this exponential growth:

  • Exhaustion of nutrients in the medium required for growth
  • Accumulation of toxic metabolites that inhibits growth

Stationary phase: When exponential growth of cells is limited, the cells enter a stationary phase where cell growth ceases completely. Cell turnover is seen where the rate at which cells die is equally balanced with the rate of formation of new cells through growth and division. In this phase, a bacterial culture phenomenon is noted where bacterial cells become viable but non culturable (VBNC). This is thought to be triggered by starvation where the bacterial cells enter into a dormant state resulting in no morphological changes. When appropriate conditions are met, VNBC microbes resume growth.

Phase of decline: Cell viability begins to decrease at a defined rate and as a result cell population decreases in this phase due to cell death. The death rate increases until it reaches a steady level.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl was kidnapped and sexually assaulted by her neighbor in an abandoned parking lot, resulting in her death. According to the latest Supreme Court guidelines, what is the BNS section and the minimum punishment applicable for the accused?
questions.solution:
According to the latest Supreme Court guidelines, the minimum punishment applicable as per Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) section 66 for the accused is 20 years imprisonment.

Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita 2023 defines the punishment for causing death or resulting in a persistent vegetative state of a rape victim under Section 66. The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person’s natural life, or with death.

Other Options:

Option B- Section 67 deals with the punishment for sexual intercourse by a husband during separation from his wife, without her consent. The punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than two years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to a fine.

Option C- Section 65 (2), 20 years imprisonment- Section 65 (2) defines the punishment for rape of a girl less than 12 years. The punishment includes rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person’s natural life, and with fine or with death.

Option D- Section 68- Sexual intercourse by a person in authority (police officer, public servant, member of armed forces, management or staff of a jail, remand home or other places of custody and management or staff of a hospital) who induces or seduces any female inmate of such jail, remand home, place, or institution to have sexual intercourse, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offense of rape. The punishment includes rigorous imprisonment for not less than 5 years but which may extend to 10 years and with a fine.

questions.text: An 18-year-old unmarried female patient presents with an abdominal mass, menstrual irregularities, abdominal pain, and fever. On palpation of the abdomen, it has a doughy feel. What could be the most likely causative agent in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of genital tuberculosis and the most likely causative agent, in this case, is Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Genital tuberculosis occurs secondary to primary foci. It initially affects the fallopian tubes bilaterally following which it spreads to other genital organs. The presenting features include a mass abdomen and associated menstrual irregularities. On palpation, the abdomen has a doughy feeling. Other features include dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and pelvic inflammatory disease (fever, nausea and vomiting, menstrual irregularities, vaginal discharge, cervical motion tenderness, adnexal tenderness, etc)

Hysterosalpingography reveals features suggestive of genital tuberculosis such as

  • Lead pipe appearance of the tubes
  • Beading and variation in the filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx

The pelvic inflammatory mass in an unmarried woman is mostly tubercular in origin. A pelvic inflammatory disease that doesn't respond to treatment and recurs is likely to be due to tuberculosis.

Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhea, and Mycoplasma hominis are sexually transmitted and can cause pelvic inflammatory disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures, severe abdominal pain, and dark-colored urine. She has a previous history of repeated hospital admission for similar complaints. A diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria was made after a detailed workup. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The administration of barbiturates is contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.

Acute intermittent porphyria is a disorder of heme synthesis, characterized by a deficiency of hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS).

Barbiturates are enzyme inducers and they result in the increased synthesis of porphyrins and subsequent precipitation of acute intermittent porphyria. The biochemical basis for the worsening of porphyria by barbiturates is the de-repression/induction of ALA synthase.

Barbiturates are metabolized by microsomal CYP450, a heme-protein oxidase system found in the liver. In patients with porphyria, barbiturates precipitate an attack of porphyria by the following mechanism:

 Barbiturates increase the synthesis of CYP450
 ↓
Enhanced consumption of heme
↓
A decrease in heme concentration in the liver 
↓
De-repression/induction of ALAS-1
↓
Increased synthesis of heme precursors
↓
Precipitation of porphyria


Other options:

Theophylline, chlorpromazine, and benzodiazepine are not contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with sudden onset breathing difficulty. There is no history of any prior respiratory diseases. The chest radiograph of the patient shows pneumothorax. Which of the following types of emphysema is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A young adult with spontaneous pneumothorax is most likely to have paraseptal (distal acinar) emphysema. 

The distal part of the acinus is involved in the paraseptal type of emphysema. It is the most prominent just adjacent to the pleura and the margins of the pulmonary lobules. It occurs more frequently in the upper parts of the lungs and accompanies areas of fibrosis or atelectasis. Enlarged airspaces, sometimes forming cyst-like structures, are the characteristic finding. Rupture of the apical cystic spaces that lie within or immediately under the viscera pleura causes pneumothorax. The initial recommended treatment in primary spontaneous pneumothorax is simple aspiration of the air. In recurrent cases, thoracoscopy with stapling of blebs and pleural abrasion is indicated.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, the patient sustained an injury to the right half of the spinal cord. Which of the following features is not likely to be seen in this patient at the level of the lesion?

choices.text: Upper motor neuron type of right sided weakness
Lower motor neuron type of right sided weakness
Loss of discriminative touch of right side
Loss of vibration and proprioception of right side

questions.solution:
The features not likely to be seen in this patient are Upper motor neuron type of right-sided weakness. 

At the level of the lesion, only LMN signs (flaccid paralysis, muscle atrophy) are seen, whereas UMN signs (spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia) occur below the level of the lesion.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways and ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) which is called the Brown- Séquard syndrome. The features likely to be seen here are:

  • Ipsilateral muscle weakness (UMN type) below the level of the lesion as a result of damage to the corticospinal tract.
  • Ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion. It occurs due to damage to the fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus(Dorsal column).
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion due to damage to the spinothalamic tract.

At the level of lesion, the following features are seen:

  • Ipsilateral muscle weakness (LMN type): Flaccid paralysis occurs due to damage to the anterior horn (lower motor neuron damage) at the level of the lesion.
  • Ipsilateral sensory loss: loss of all ipsilateral sensory sensations. In this case, the right side is affected and due to damage to the dorsal root or the posterior column, there will be a loss of discriminative touch, vibration and proprioception on the right side 
  • Pain and temperature sensation loss in the dermatomal distribution due to disruption of spinothalamic tracts at that level.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A young patient who is a chronic smoker and lives in a slum area with poor ventilation is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. Which of the following is NOT the contributing cause for his condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis is not the contributing cause. It is a necessary cause because, without the pathogen, TB cannot develop.

This is Rothman’s model of disease causation, which is a sufficient component cause model. It consists of multiple pie charts, which represent a sufficient cause. A disease can have multiple sufficient causes.

Each sufficient cause consists of component causes. One component cause can be a part of more than one sufficient cause. A component cause is considered a necessary cause if it is present in all the sufficient causes.

Option A, C, D: Chronic smoking, overcrowding, and malnutrition are contributing causes that increase susceptibility but are not necessary for TB development.

In the given model, each pie chart represents a sufficient cause for TB infection. Since Mycobacterium Tuberculosis infection is present in all the charts, it can be considered a necessary cause. All the others are contributing causes.

questions.text: A 3-day old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. There is no history of fever. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed. A barium enema is performed and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a male newborn presenting with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, forceful expulsion of stools on rectal examination, and barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid descending colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschprung's disease is a rectal biopsy.

In Hirschprung's disease, the rectal biopsy shows absent ganglia, hypertrophied nerve trunks, and positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase.

Hirschprung's disease is caused by malformation of the pelvic parasympathetic system that results in the absence of ganglion cells in the Auerbach and Meissner plexus. This causes muscular spasms of the distal colon and internal anal sphincter resulting in their functional obstruction. 

They are predominantly seen in boys and are often associated with Down syndrome. Most cases present during the neonatal period as abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium. Beyond this period, they mainly present with poor feeding, abdominal distension, and severe constipation. Forceful expulsion of stools is observed on rectal examination as the stools were accumulated in the distal colon.

A barium enema is obtained on all suspected cases of Hirschprung's disease. This demonstrates the location of the transition zone between the dilated ganglionic colon and the distal aganglionic rectal segment. 

In older children, anorectal manometry shows a high internal sphincter pressure when the lumen of the rectum is distended with a balloon. This is due to the absence of normal inhibitory reflex in Hirschsprung's disease. But due to relative inaccuracy of findings, this test is not commonly done. 

Ultrasound findings may also suggest the diagnosis but it is not sensitive enough to exclude Hirschsprung's disease.

The three definitive surgical procedures are the Swenson procedure, Duhamel procedure, and Soave's procedure.

The most common cause of death in uncorrected Hirschprung's disease is enterocolitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about the myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow (RBF) and glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?

choices.text: Increased movement of calcium into cells
Increases RBF when arterial pressure rises
Prevents excessive stretch of renal vessels

questions.solution:
The myogenic mechanism of autoregulation helps to prevent excessive rises in renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate when the arterial pres­sure increases.

The stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions into the cells from the extracellular fluid. This causes vessel wall contraction preventing excessive stretch of the vessel and raising vascular resistance. This prevents increases in renal blood flow and GFR when the arterial pres­sure increases.

This mechanism is important in protect­ing the kidney from hypertension­-induced injuries. When there is a sudden increase in blood pressure, the myo­genic constrictor response in the afferent arterioles occurs within seconds, reducing the transmission of excessively high arterial pressure to the glomerular capillaries.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with an absent right testis in the scrotum since birth. On examination, the left testis is normal, but the right testis is palpable in the superficial inguinal pouch. The testis cannot be repositioned back into the scrotal pouch. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 3-year-old boy with absent testis in the right scrotum with right testis palpable in the superficial inguinal pouch is suggestive of ectopic testis, and the most appropriate management of ectopic testis is Orchidopexy.

Testes develop from the genital ridge in the retroperitoneum at 3 months of intrauterine life. They descend into the scrotum by 9 months of age due to differential abdominal growth, the pull of the gubernaculum, and the effect of testosterone. 

Cryptorchidism refers to the absence of one or both testes in the scrotal sac. The descent of the testis can be arrested in its usual path of descent (true undescended testis) or can migrate from the usual path of descent (ectopic testis). The most common site of ectopic testes is the superficial inguinal pouch.

The image below shows the possible sites of the testes in cryptorchidism:

Other options:

Option A: Orchidectomy (removal of the testis) is not appropriate in this scenario because the testis is viable and should be preserved if possible, as the child is young and the testis is palpable in a location where it can be surgically repositioned.

Option C: Surgical exploration is only required when:

  • The testis is non-palpable, raising concerns about an intra-abdominal position, agenesis, or atrophy.
  • There is suspicion of malrotation or torsion associated with cryptorchidism.

Option D: Observation: A retractile testis can also lie in the inguinal canal and needs to be differentiated from ectopic testes. It is present in the scrotum and occasionally moves into the inguinal canal. An ectopic testis is treated with orchidopexy, while a retractile testis requires no intervention as it resolves spontaneously.

questions.text:
Leukoreduction prevents the transmission of which of the following diseases?
  1. Hepatitis B
  2. HTLV - 1
  3. CMV
  4. HIV 1
  5. Hepatitis D
questions.solution:
Leukoreduction before blood transfusion prevents the transmission of the CMV virus and the HTLV-1 virus.

Leukoreduction refers to the removal of leukocytes from the blood or blood components before blood transfusion.

It prevents the occurrence of certain transfusion reactions such as:

  • Febrile non-hemolytic Transfusion Reactions
  • HLA alloimmunization and platelet refractoriness
  • Prevention of leukocyte-transmitted diseases such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV)-I, and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

CMV Virus and the HTLV-1 virus are transmitted by the infected passenger leukocytes found in transfused PRBCs or platelet components. Hence, Leukoreduction helps prevent them.

Leukoreduction does not prevent other infections, such as HIV-1 and the Hepatitis group of viruses.

questions.text: A young person is brought to the hospital following a snake bite. The attendants have also brought the snake with them for identification. The image of the snake is given below. The poison of the snake is mainly:
questions.solution:
The image shows a banded krait. The poison of this snake is mainly neurotoxic.

The banded krait can be identified by the alternating black and yellow cross-bands along its back and the presence of hexagonal scales. Its tail has a blunt ending with a swelling at the tip. In addition, a black mark can be found on its neck that extends to the eyes.

The initial presentation includes vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, blurred vision, perioral paresthesia, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and piloerection ('gooseflesh').

Ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia is the first sign of paralysis to set in followed by involvement of the face, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles of deglutition. 

Ultimately, respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

The neurotoxic symptoms of the banded krait bite are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs. In some cases the symptoms may even subside spontaneously after a week.

questions.text: Nayi Pahel kits are distributed to newlywed couples under the family planning program. Which of the following items is not present in the kit?
questions.solution:
Nayi Pahel kits are distributed to newlywed couples for a subsidized fee of Rs 220 under the family planning program Mission Parivar Vikas. The government launched Chhaya (Oral contraceptive—Centchroman) and Antara (Intramuscular injectable contraceptive- DMPA) under Mission Parivar Vikas but does not include them in the Nayi Pahel kits.

Nayi Pahel is a family planning kit consisting of:

  • Jute bag with the family planning program logo
  • Marriage registration form
  • A pamphlet containing information on contraception, family planning, how to use UPT kits, and ASHA schemes
  • Pack of 3 male condoms (Nirodh) x 2 units
  • Mala N oral contraceptive pills x 2 packs
  • 3 emergency contraceptive pills called E pills
  • 2 pregnancy testing kits
  • A grooming or hygiene kit consisting mirror, lipstick, bindi, etc
  • An information card with details on respective ASHAs and nearest ANMs

The ASHA is incentivized with Rs 100/kit distributed to newly wedded couples.

questions.text: What type of study is shown below?
questions.solution:
The study shown is a prospective cohort study. 

A cohort study is a type of analytical study, which progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not disease. It is also known as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study. It can be divided into:

  • Prospective cohort studies: Outcome has not occurred at the time of the beginning of the investigation 
  • Retrospective cohort studies: Outcome has occurred before the beginning of the investigation 
  • Combination cohort studies: Both retrospective and prospective elements are combined

A cohort is a group of individuals who share a common experience or characteristic within a defined time period. The cohort groups are selected before the appearance of the disease under investigation. They are divided into study and control cohorts. The study cohorts are exposed to a particular factor thought to be related to the disease occurrence whereas the control cohorts are not exposed to this particular factor.  

Studying the effects of exposure to uranium in causing lung cancer is an example of a cohort study. Uranium miners are taken as the study cohort and other individuals who are not exposed to uranium mining are taken as the control cohort. 

Note: In a nested case-control study, cases of disease that have occurred in a defined cohort are identified. A specified number of matched controls who have not developed the disease are then selected from the cohort. 

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat Yellow phosphorous poisoning?
questions.solution:
Prussian blue is not used to treat Yellow phosphorous poisoning. Prussian blue is an antidote for thallium poisoning.

Yellow phosphorous poisoning in children occurs in the circumstance of fireworks/ ratkiller paste ingestion. Fulminant poisoning occurs at a dose above 1 g and patients die within 12 hours as it causes cardiovascular collapse by direct action on the heart and vessels.

  • In acute poisoning - Burning throat pain and severe abdominal pain occur with intense thirst, nausea, vomiting, garlic odor of breath,  luminescent vomiting, and feces are diagnostic. 
  • Second stage- Symptom-free
  • Third stage - Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, hematemesis, liver failure, oliguria, acute kidney injury, hematuria, convulsions, and coma can occur.

Potassium permanganate (KMnO4 ) gastric lavage, activated charcoal, and Copper sulfate stomach wash are used for treatment along with Vitamin K for hypoprothrombinemia and coagulopathy.

Gastric lavage using a 1:5000 solution of potassium permanganate oxidizes phosphorus into phosphoric acid and phosphates, which are harmless. Activated charcoal adsorbs the poison. The stomach can be washed with 0.2% CuSO4 or 0.2 g of CuSO4 may be given until vomiting occurs. It coats the particles of phosphorus with a film of copper phosphide which is relatively harmless. Vitamin K, 20 mg. i.v. can be given in repeated doses to combat hypoprothrombinaemia and coagulopathy.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient recently diagnosed with renal vein thrombosis is being evaluated. He had past history of weight gain, generalized edema, and hypertension. Urinary examination shows gross proteinuria and the presence of multiple RBCs with normal morphology and no casts. Anti-PLA2R antibodies are present. Which of the following is likely to be seen on renal biopsy in this patient?

GBM - Glomerular basement membrane

choices.text: Diffuse thickening of the GBM with spike and dome pattern

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of nephrotic syndrome. Anti PLA2R antibodies are seen in membranous nephropathy which is seen as diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) on light microscopy examination. On electron microscopy, there are irregular spikes protruding from the GBM.

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by nephrotic syndrome and proteinuria. It occurs due to the accumulation of deposits containing immunoglobulins along the subepithelial portion of the glomerular basement membrane. Most of the cases (75%) are primary and are linked to an autoimmune phenomenon. The remaining are associated with the following: 

  • Drugs - Penicillamine, captopril, gold, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Underlying malignancies like carcinoma of the lung, colon, melanoma
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Infections such as chronic hepatitis B and C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune conditions like thyroiditis

M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) antibodies are seen in the majority of these cases. 

Membranous nephropathy can present with insidious onset of nephrotic syndrome or a hypercoagulable state such as pulmonary embolism, renal vein thrombosis, deep venous thrombosis, and symptoms of heart failure. The hypercoagulable state occurs due to the loss of antithrombin 3 from the urine.

On light microscopy, the glomeruli may be normal or have a uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. Electron microscopy will reveal spike and dome patterns. Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement.

The image below shows the light microscopic findings in membranous nephropathy.

Other options:

Options B and D- Tram-track appearance of the glomerular basement membrane and large and hypercellular glomeruli are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. It presents as nephrotic syndrome and along with features of nephritic component manifested by hematuria or as mild proteinuria.

Option C- Mesangial deposition of IgA is seen in IgA nephropathy (Berger disease).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with continuous fever. On examination, pallor and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. The bone marrow picture is shown in the image given below. Which of the following hepatic cells are mainly targeted in this infection?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing macrophages infected with intracellular amastigotes is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania donovani. It affects the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver. 

This condition causes fever with rigor and chills associated with splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. Though lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, it is rare in India. 

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly, which inoculates the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms:

  • The promastigote, which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote, which multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.

The illustration given below shows the lifecycle of Leishmania:

 

It lowers immunity, causes persistent fever, anemia, and hepatosplenomegaly, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5 mm or more is considered positive; usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis; valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.

questions.text: A patient with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) presents with a sudden increase in the size of lymph nodes. Richter's transformation is suspected. This indicates the transformation of CLL into which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) presenting with a sudden increase in lymph node size raises suspicion for Richter's transformation, indicating transformation to Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL). 

Richter's transformation is the aggressive evolution of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) into a more malignant form of lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). DLBCL typically arises from extranodal mature peripheral B cells. This transformation signifies a worse prognosis due to the aggressive nature of the resulting tumor. It presents with a sudden increase in lymph node size, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, night sweats, weight loss), and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels.

DLBCL can arise from nodal as well as extranodal mature B cells. It is molecularly heterogeneous and can show the given abnormalities:

  • BCL6 (transcription factor) overexpression is most common
  • t(14;18) translocation leading to BCL2 overexpression.
  • MYC translocations (like Burkitt’s lymphoma)
  • Mutations in gene encoding histone acetyltransferases

Diagnosis is confirmed through a lymph node biopsy or affected tissue, immunohistochemistry, and molecular studies. Elevated LDH and systemic symptoms support the diagnosis.

Treatment involves intensive chemotherapy (e.g., R-CHOP), targeted therapies (e.g., venetoclax and ibrutinib), and potentially hematopoietic stem cell transplantation for eligible patients.

questions.text: A patient with multiple sclerosis on treatment with Natalizumab develops Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML). What type of genetic material is found in the virus that is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a patient with multiple sclerosis receiving Natalizumab is at a high risk of reactivating the John Cunningham virus (JC virus), which causes Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML). The JC virus contains circular, double-stranded DNA. 

Natalizumab is an immunomodulatory drug that lowers immunity and predisposes individuals to opportunistic infections, such as PML, caused by the JC virus. The JC virus is a DNA virus belonging to the Polyomaviridae family. It is non-enveloped and has a double-stranded circular DNA genome.

Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy is a fatal subacute progressive demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. The JC virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes. It demyelinates throughout the brain but spares the spinal cord and optic nerves. It is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals (in HIV/AIDS, organ transplantation, hematological malignancies, or use of immunomodulatory drugs such as Natalizumab and Rituximab). 

Patients present with insidious onset and steady progression of symptoms that include:    

  • Focal neurologic deficits (e.g., hemiplegia, aphasia, ataxia)
  • Visual deficits (typically homonymous hemianopia)  
  • Mental impairment (e.g., dementia, confusion, personality change)

The image below shows a brain biopsy of a PML patient. It shows ballooned oligodendrocytes with SV40-positive nuclear inclusion bodies and enlarged astrocytes indicative of JC virus infection. Brain biopsy and histology are the gold-standard tests for PML.

Diagnosis is with the help of MRI-Brain, which shows multifocal, bilateral, asymmetric white matter lesions (hypointense on T1, hyperintense on T2) without mass effect. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of the CSF is highly specific for the detection of the JC virus in patients with PML.

The treatment for Natalizumab-associated PML is supportive. Natalizumab should be immediately discontinued, and plasma exchange should be used. PML typically progresses rapidly and is associated with high mortality.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of chronic cough & difficulty in breathing for the past 6 months. He also gives a history of occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. On examination, he has a saddle nose deformity. The physician orders a haemogram & chest CT, which show the following. What is his likely diagnosis?

CBC: 

  • Hb - 11 g/dL
  • Platelet count- 1.8 lakh cells/mm^3
  • Total count - 13,700 cells/mm^3
  • Differential count: Neutrophils - 70%
  • Lymphocytes - 27%
  • Eosinophils - 2%
questions.solution:
This patient has the involvement of the upper respiratory tract – saddle nose deformity & blood-stained nasal discharge, and lower respiratory tract – chronic cough  & dyspnea with CT chest showing multiple cavitary nodules & pulmonary infiltrates. This, along with the absence of eosinophilia (normal range of eosinophils: 1-4%) and anaemia, points to the most likely diagnosis of granulomatosis with polyangiitis also known as Wegener's Granulomatosis. 

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a granulomatous and necrotizing vasculitis of the small arteries and veins that mainly affects:

  • Upper respiratory tract: chronic sinusitis, serous otitis media due to eustachian tube blockage, nasal septal perforation, and mucosal ulceration of the nasopharynx.
  • Lower respiratory tract: presenting with cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and persistent pneumonitis. Lung involvement typically appears as multiple, bilateral nodular cavitary infiltrates.
  • Kidneys: focal or segmental glomerulonephritis presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. If left untreated it can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.
  • Apart from these organs, it can also affect the eyes and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules.

Lab investigations will show anaemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and high titers of cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) targetted against anti-proteinase-3 (anti-PR-3). The specificity of a positive PR-3 ANCA for Wegener's is very high, especially in the presence of active glomerulonephritis. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy. This finding is commonly seen in the tissues obtained from the lungs, upper airways, skin, and rarely in the kidneys. HPE shows necrotizing vasculitis of small arteries and veins together with either intravascular or extravascular granuloma formation.

Other options :

Option A: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome) involves the skin, cardiac and gastrointestinal tract and peripheral nervous system with associated eosinophilia. Biopsy shows necrotizing vasculitis with eosinophilic infiltrates and eosinophilic granulomas.

Option D: Tuberculosis would be associated with more constitutional symptoms & no nasal deformity & blood-stained nasal discharge.

questions.text: You are a junior researcher studying about the properties of apoproteins.  Which of the following is the basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48?
questions.solution:
The basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48 is RNA editing.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is a result of RNA editing. The ApoB gene is transcribed into an mRNA that leads to the synthesis of 100 kDa protein in the liver, which is called apoB100. In the intestine, the same primary transcript is formed, but a cytidine deaminase converts a CAA codon in the mRNA into a UAA codon; thus codon for glutamine is changed to a termination codon. Thus 48kDa protein has resulted; this is apoB48.

DNA rearrangement, transposition and alternate splicing, do alter gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: A patient presents with dysentery, and stool microscopy shows the presence of ciliate protozoan trophozoites. What is the main reservoir of this infection?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a patient with dysentery and stool microscopy showing the presence of ciliate protozoan trophozoites is suggestive of Balantidium coli infection. Pigs are the main reservoir of this infection.

Balantidium coli exists in two forms:

  • Trophozoites: Active, motile stage found in diarrheic feces.
  • Cysts: Infective stage found in contaminated food and water.

The image below shows the life cycle of Balantidium coli :

Pigs are the definitive and primary reservoir of Balantidium coli. Humans are intermediate hosts, often ingesting cysts from contaminated food or water. The cysts mature in the small intestine. Trophozoites colonize the large intestine, where they can invade the mucosa, causing ulcers and symptoms like diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and occasionally frank dysentery. Balantidium coli is the only ciliated pathogenic protozoa that infects humans. 

The below image shows the image of Balantidium Coli in wet mount:

Diagnosis is by stool examination, which shows the presence of trophozoites in diarrheic feces and cysts in stools. Trophozoites are large with macronucleus and have rapid-revolving motility, while cysts are round with macronucleus.

Treatment involves Tetracycline as first-line therapy. Alternative treatments include Metronidazole or Iodoquinol. Preventive measures include proper sanitation and avoiding consumption of contaminated food or water.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of fatigue and weakness. Peripheral smear reveals Echinocytes. On further work up, she’s found to have hemolytic anemia secondary to a deficiency of an enzyme in the glycolysis pathway. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a female with hemolytic anaemia and possible glycolytic enzyme deficiency suggests pyruvate kinase deficiency.

Pyruvate kinase deficiency, autosomal recessive by inheritance, is the second most common cause of enzyme deficiency-related anaemia (Most common: G6PD deficiency). Mature RBCs lack mitochondria and are dependent on Glycolysis for ATP production. The deficiency of glycolytic enzymes results in reduced production of ATPs and thus causes cell membrane alterations and phagocytosis in reticuloendothelial cells.  

This is seen on peripheral smears as echinocytes or Burr cells which indicate cell membrane alternations. They are red cells with short, evenly spaced spicules formed due to altered cell membrane lipids. They can also be seen in uremia, bleeding ulcers, and gastric carcinoma. Heterozygous individuals are often resistant to the most severe forms of malaria.

The liver pyruvate kinase (PK) is encoded by the same gene as the red blood cell isozyme. However, liver cells are unaffected because they can produce additional PK and generate ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.

It can be present in neonates, children, and adults. Since the enzyme defect occurs at the last step of the pathway, 2,3 BPG production significantly increases, promoting oxygen delivery and thus masking the direct anaemia-related symptoms. This often leads to a late diagnosis in those with Pyruvate kinase deficiency. Severe forms of the disease may mandate iron chelation, blood transfusions, and folate supplementation. Splenectomy and cholecystectomy may also be required.

Mitapivat is a recently approved oral pyruvate kinase activator. It allosterically binds to the pyruvate kinase tetramer and increases pyruvate kinase (PK) activity. The most common adverse reactions are back pain, arthralgia, decreased estrone and estradiol (in males), and increased urate levels.

Other options:

Pyruvate dehydrogenase (option A) complex links glycolysis to the TCA cycle (in mitochondria), It is not an RBC glycolytic enzyme.

G6PD (option B) is not an enzyme in the glycolysis pathway but a part of the HMP-shunt pathway. Deficiency of the other two enzymes in the options does not present as hemolytic anaemias.

questions.text: Which among the following is not an indication for the use of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)?
questions.solution:
Indications of ECT:

Diagnostic indications - 

  • Major depression (Bipolar and unipolar)
  • Psychotic depression (Option A)
  • Mania
  • Acute exacerbation of schizophrenia
  • Catatonic schizophrenia
  • Schizoaffective disorder (Option D)
  • Parkinson's disease (Option C)
  • Neuroleptic malignant disorder

Panic disorder is not an indication of the use of electroconvulsive therapy. 

Clinical indications - 

  • Primary - 
    • When rapid response is required
    • When the risk of other treatment modalities outweighs the benefits
    • Poor response to previous antipsychotic therapy
    • Good response to previous ECT therapy
    • Preference of patient
  • Secondary - 
    • Poor response or failure to respond to pharmacotherapy in the current episode
    • Rapid definitive response necessitated by the deterioration of the patient's condition

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is not effective in somatization disorder (unless accompanied by depression), personality disorders, and anxiety disorders such as panic disorder.

questions.text: Which procedure is combined with meatoplasty to look for middle ear pathologies?
questions.solution:
The procedure combined with meatoplasty to look for middle ear pathologies is the canal wall-down procedure 

Meatoplasty is a surgical procedure that removes a crescent-shaped portion of conchal cartilage to widen the external auditory meatus. It is performed in combination with all canal wall-down procedures, like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, to allow easy access to the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.

It is also an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricles. A sagging auricle obstructs the meatus, leading to wax retention and difficulty in hearing.

Other options

Option A and C: Canal wall-up procedures involve removing diseased tissue through a combined approach via the meatus and mastoid while retaining the posterior bony wall of the ear canal. This approach avoids creating an open mastoid cavity, helps maintain the ear's natural anatomy, promotes a dry ear environment, and facilitates easier reconstruction of the hearing mechanism. Simple mastoidectomy is also a canal wall-up procedure. 

Option D: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only.

questions.text: The difference in the size of the image formed by the two eyes in the visual cortex is known as?
questions.solution:
The difference in images formed by the two eyes is called Aniseikonia.

Aniseikonia is a condition in which the size of the image formed by the two eyes differs and can lead to disturbances in stereopsis. Treatment includes contact lenses in patients with phakia and intraocular lens implantation in patients with aphakia.

The tolerable limit of aniseikonia is 5–8%. It is reduced with contact lenses (8%) compared to glasses (25–30%) in aphakia.

Other Options

Option A: Anisometropia is the difference in refractive power of two eyes.

Option C: Ametropia refers to the different conditions of refractive error.

Option D: Astigmatism is a different refractive power in various meridians.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with seizure disorder comes to the ophthalmologist with complaints of sudden onset redness, pain & blurring of vision in her left eye. Her intra-ocular pressure reading is 30mmHg. She gives the history of the recent addition of a new antiepileptic drug. Which of the following drugs is responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of sudden onset redness & painful eye with blurring of vision with high Intra-ocular pressure points to a diagnosis of Acute Angle-closure glaucoma. In a patient with a seizure disorder, Topiramate is a drug that can precipitate Angle-closure glaucoma. It is known to increase choroidal effusions. Lamotrigine, Sodium valproate, and Levetiracetam don't cause Angle-closure glaucoma.

Topiramate is a newer anti epileptic, that acts by blocking voltage-sensitive sodium channels, potentiating GABA inhibitory action, blocking voltage-sensitive calcium channels, inhibiting subtypes of glutamate receptors (non-MDA receptors), and a weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

It is FDA-approved for generalized tonic-clonic seizures, Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, and migraine prevention and is used off-label as an adjunct therapy for chronic weight management. As a side effect, topiramate can cause significant weight loss, enhance sleep quality, and lessen neuropathic pain which may be advantageous for certain patient groups with chronic pain conditions.

Other options:

Option A: Lamotrigine acts by blocking both sodium and calcium channels. It is effective in treating trigeminal neuralgia, HIV neuropathy-related pain, and neuralgia following nerve section. Side effects mainly include mild dizziness, somnolence, nausea, and constipation.

Option B: Sodium valproate is an antiseizure drug that acts by prolonging the recovery of inactivated Na+ channels and decreasing T-type Ca2+ channel currents. It is used in the treatment of focal, tonic-clonic, absence, and myoclonic seizures. It is also used as a prophylaxis in migraine headaches.

Option D: Levetiracetam acts by binding to SV2A synaptic vesicular protein.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with acidity and abdominal pain for the past few months, not relieved by taking antacids. Endoscopy revealed prominent gastric folds and ulcers on the second part of the duodenum. Investigations revealed elevated serum gastrin levels and increased basal acid secretion. Which of the following is the next best investigation?

choices.text: Endoscopic ultrasound guided deep gastric biopsy
Blood gastrin levels following secretin administration
Monoclonal antibody-based H. pylori stool antigen test
Double contrast barium study of proximal  GI tract

questions.solution:
The presence of peptic ulcers and poor response to antacids, together with elevated serum gastrin levels and increased basal acid secretion are suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The next best investigation to confirm the diagnosis is to perform a secretin stimulation test.

In normal individuals, the administration of secretin causes no change or a slight decrease in blood gastrin levels. However, in patients with ZE syndrome, the circulating gastrin levels paradoxically increase following secretin administration.

Other investigations include:

  • Tumor localization and staging using a combination of CT and endoscopic ultrasound
  • Radio-labeled somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • 68gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Other options:

Option A: Endoscopic ultrasound-guided deep gastric biopsy is usually done to diagnose infiltrating gastric tumours such as linitis plastica (GLP) and gastric lymphoma.

Options C and D: Monoclonal antibody-based H pylori stool antigen test and double-contrast barium study of proximal GI tract are the tests indicated for the diagnostic evaluation of H. pylori peptic ulcer disease.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: A teenage boy presents with the teeth given in the image below. Many of his family members have the same complaint. The junior resident on the team suspects a mineral excess as the cause and asks you to study about Nalgonda technique. Which of the following is the first step involved in the Nalgonda technique?
questions.solution:
Fluoride excess is responsible for dental fluorosis, which presents as the mottling of teeth as shown in the image. The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water, which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

Add lime + alum ➡️ Flocculation ➡️ Sedimentation ➡️ Filtration

The image given below depicts the Nalgonda technique:

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic to certain parts of India like Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana (Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu.  Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake.

  • Dental fluorosis (1.5mg/L): Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It causes mottling of dental enamel. The appearance of chalky-white, and dull patches on the teeth in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and then brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance in severe cases. Mottling is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects permanent teeth during its period of formation.
  • Skeletal fluorosis (3-6mg/L): Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, and fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone. These are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis (>10mg/L): Can lead to permanent disability.

The given image shows skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification): 

Interventions for Fluorosis:

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur, developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique.
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age.

questions.text: The baby in the image below was born at 37 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 4.9 kg to a mother diagnosed with gestational diabetes. Which of the following complications is likely to be seen in this neonate?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the baby born to a mother with gestational diabetes has macrosomia i.e. the baby is large for gestational age. The neonate is likely to develop polycythemia as a complication.

Polycy­themia occurs as a fetal response to relative hypoxia. Fetal hypoxia is due to a hyperglycemia-mediated increase in maternal affinity for oxy­gen and fetal oxygen consumption. Along with insulin-like growth factors, this hypoxia leads to increased fetal erythropoi­etin levels and red cell production.

Other neonatal complications of gestational diabetes include:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome 
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Cardiac malformations - ventricular or atrial septal defect, transposition of the great vessels, truncus arteriosus, double-outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, coarctation of the aorta
  • Neural tube defects, sacral agenesis, caudal regression syndrome, microcephaly, anencephaly
  • Renal agenesis, duodenal atresia, single umbilical artery

Later complications include childhood obesity, diabetes and neuropsychological effects.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. The image is given below. Which of the following is recommended for the treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
Trichloroacetic acid is recommended for the treatment of genital warts in pregnancy. 

Genital warts frequently grow in number and size with pregnancy. They commonly undergo apoptosis and resolution postpartum and hence necessitate intervention only if symptomatic. Therapy aims to debulk the symptomatic warts while minimizing the risk to both the mother and fetus. 

Trichloroacetic or bichloroacetic acid in an 80-90% solution applied topically weekly is an effective regimen for external warts. Some prefer cryotherapy, laser ablation, or surgical excision. Agents such as podophyllin resin, podofilox solution/gel, imiquimod cream, and sinecatechins have a limited safety profile. So, they are not recommended in pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 1,2,3,4
  • Common warts (verruca vulgaris, plantar wart)
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   

 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text: An infant presents with tachypnea and feeding problems. The urine has a peculiar tomcat urine odor. This condition is caused by defective utilization of____.
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine odor is seen in multiple carboxylase deficiencies. Multiple carboxylase deficiencies occur due to defects in the utilization of biotin.

In the neonatal form of the disease, clinically, the affected infants seem normal at birth, but develop breathing difficulties shortly after birth, with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. If untreated, generalized erythematous rash, exfoliation, alopecia, failure to thrive, seizures, and even coma may occur. 

This problem may be an autosomal recessive form due to holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency or may be acquired due to dietary biotin deficiency because of short bowel syndrome, chronic diarrhea, or use of anticonvulsant drugs like phenytoin and carbamazepine. Raw egg ingestion may also lead to this because of avidin in the egg white binding to biotin and decreasing its absorption.

Affected infants should be treated with biotin.
