questions.text: Supplementary nutrition provided under the PM POSHAN programme should satisfy

choices.text: 1/3 of the total protein requirement + 1/2 of the total energy requirement
2/3 of the total protein requirement + 1/2 of the total energy requirement
1/2 of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of the total energy requirement
1/2 of the total protein requirement + 2/3 of the total energy requirement

questions.solution:
Under the PM POSHAN scheme, supplementary nutrition provided must cover at least 1/2 of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of the total daily energy requirement of children in schools.

Minimum number of feeding days is 250.

The PM POSHAN scheme is also called the School Lunch Programme and has been operational since 1961 in India. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the Minimum Needs Programme.

Some other principles of the PM POSHAN scheme are:

  • The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets.
  • The cost of meals should be reasonably low.
  • The meals should be easy to cook in schools.
  • Locally available foods must be used, for as long as possible.
  • The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.
    Note: In September 2021, the Mid-Day Meal Scheme was renamed PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the hospital after accidentally finding a painless lump in her right breast. The lump is solitary and is located below the areola. She also recalls a blood-stained discharge from her nipple a few days back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a solitary intraductal papilloma.  

Intraductal papilloma is a benign, proliferative breast disorder without atypia. It can be solitary or multiple (papillomatosis). Most commonly seen in premenopausal women. It is associated with blood-stained discharge and cystic swelling beneath the areola.

It is important to rule out the possibility of carcinoma with blood tests and cytology. If atypia is present, excision is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

Option A: Duct ectasia is the dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts and is associated with periductal mastitis. The dilated ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-coloured secretions and get discharged from the nipple. Later, it can form an indurated mass that resembles a carcinoma and should be carefully ruled out. Fibrosis causes a slit-like retraction of the nipple. The definitive treatment is Hadfield's operation which involves the excision of all major ducts. Duct ectasia is mainly seen in perimenopausal women (45-55 years of age).

Option B: Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumour that is usually firm, rubbery, and mobile. They occur in women in their 20s and 30s, and they are frequently multiple and bilateral. It has no increased risk of developing into malignancy. 

Option D: Paget’s disease is the skin manifestation of underlying breast carcinoma. It is characterised by nipple erythema and irritation. It is associated with pruritus and may progress to crusting and ulceration. The discharge is from the surface of the skin and not from the nipple. It can be differentiated from eczema by biopsy. Features that indicate eczema include bilateral nipple involvement, younger females, and signs of eczema in other parts.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

From the surface:

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

From a single duct:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Intraductal papilloma (M/C cause)
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour):
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

From multiple ducts:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Carcinoma (M/C cause)
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green:
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent:
    • Infection
  • Serous:
    • Fibrocystic disease (M/C cause)
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

questions.text: A child with pancytopenia and hypercellular bone marrow was diagnosed with Myelodysplastic syndrome. What does the following smear show in correlation with the above?
questions.solution:
The smear shows Pseudo Pelger-Huet cells, commonly seen in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS).

Bone Marrow Findings in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS):

  • Hypercellular Bone Marrow: increased hematopoietic activity due to ineffective hematopoiesis.
  • Pseudo Pelger-Huet Cells: Hyposegmented neutrophils with bilobed nuclei
  • Pawn Ball Megakaryocytes: Megakaryocytes with fragmented or separated, rounded nuclei.
  • Döhle Bodies: Inclusions in neutrophils caused by retained ribosomal RNA.

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) is a group of clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorders characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis, which leads to cytopenia. Despite a hypercellular bone marrow, MDS presents with pancytopenia in the peripheral blood. It is associated with dysplasia in one or more myeloid cell lines and carries a risk of progression to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Common cytogenetic abnormalities include 5q deletion (adults) and monosomy 7 (children).

The images given below show the histopathological findings seen in MDS.

Other options:

Option A: Dutcher bodies are pale staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells seen in multiple myeloma.

Option B: Howel-Jolley bodies are nuclear remnants present in RBCs. Usually seen in patients lacking normal spleen function (asplenia)

Option D: Mott cells are plasma cells with globular cytoplasmic inclusions, which represent immunoglobulin accumulation. They are seen in plasma cell disorders, such as multiple myeloma or Waldenström macroglobulinemia.

Related Pearl: Bone Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series:

  • Megaloblastoid maturation - Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities - Nucleus with abnormal shape
  • Ring sideroblasts - Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm 

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series:

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes:

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: Which of the following tools is most commonly used for root cause analysis in identifying factors that contribute to poor healthcare outcomes?
questions.solution:
Ishikawa diagram is most commonly used for root cause analysis in identifying factors contributing to poor healthcare outcomes.

Ishikawa diagram (also known as the fishbone diagram) helps sketch out problems that affect healthcare in a community and thus use those as pointers to better address them in the community. It is employed by teams aiming to comprehend the numerous potential factors that contribute to a quality of care issue and enables teams to concentrate their development endeavors on these identified causes.

The utilization of this tool is applicable across several phases of the quality improvement framework, with its primary application commonly observed within the context of root cause analysis. The fishbone graphic bears a resemblance to the skeletal structure of a fish. To depict the diagram about a quality of care issue, the problem (effect) is encapsulated within a box positioned on the extreme right of the diagram.

A vertical line, referred to as the center line or spine, is then positioned to the left of the box where the problem is documented. Subsequently, diagonal lines resembling fish bones are sketched emanating from the central line, also known as the spine. The diagonal lines depicted in the diagram signify distinct categorizations of the underlying factors contributing to the issue. Supplementary branches may also be delineated from the primary skeletal structure to symbolize underlying factors leading to the causes.

The groupings are typically structured into categories, commonly known as the five Ps (patients/clients, providers, policies, processes and procedures, and place/equipment), the six Ms (machine, method, materials, measurement, man, and Mother Nature), and the four Ss (surroundings, suppliers, systems, and skills). Nevertheless, the groupings need to be tailored to the organization and problem being investigated.

The responsibility for ensuring this specificity lies with the quality improvement team. Once the categories have been delineated, the quality improvement team proceeds to partake in a brainstorming session to identify causes that are specific to each respective grouping. The aforementioned procedure persists until the team reaches a point where they are unable to ascertain any further underlying factors.

Other Options:

Option A: Control charts are used to monitor processes over time and detect variations but are not designed for root cause analysis.

Option C: Kaplan-Meier survival curves are used to evaluate survival probabilities over time and are unrelated to root cause analysis.

Option D: Funnel plots are used in meta-analyses to assess publication bias or variability in outcomes across studies, not for root cause analysis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus is brought with complaints of cognitive decline. His family gives a history suggestive of stepwise deterioration in his condition. On examination, the Babinski sign is found to be positive. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given patient, who is a known case of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, now presenting with stepwise deteriorating cognitive function and Babinski sign positive (suggestive of a UMN lesion, like stroke), the most likely diagnosis is vascular dementia.

Vascular dementia is the second most prevalent form of dementia, after Alzheimer disease. It includes any dementia which is primarily caused by a cerebrovascular disease or impaired cerebral blood flow. Any cause of ischemic stroke (like atheroembolism), intracerebral hemorrhage, or subarachnoid hemorrhage can cause vascular dementia if the underlying injury to the brain is severe enough. Aside from a clinical stroke, cerebral small vessel diseases such as arteriosclerosis and cerebral amyloid angiopathy can also lead to vascular dementia.

The patient will likely have a vascular risk factor (hypertension, diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, tobacco use or atrial fibrillation), a history of prior stroke, or transient ischemic attack. There will usually be a stepwise decline in the mental state of the patient due to a series of unrecognized strokes. Executive functions (such as planning and organization) are likely to be affected more and early in the disease course.

Diagnosis is usually clinical based on the history but lesions in the brain can be visualised by an MRI. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at preventing further strokes via pharmacotherapy and supportive therapy.

This condition is in contrast to Alzheimer's disease (option B), where there's a slow progression and recent episodic memory is affected first.

Frontotemporal dementia (option A) presents with apathy, loss of social inhibition, and impulsivity. Memory is relatively preserved. It is associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Dementia with Lewy bodies (option C) presents with prominent psychiatric dysfunction in the form of visual hallucinations, delusions (Capgras syndrome), and delirium. This is accompanied by Parkinsonian motor features.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

Related Pearl: Synucleinopathies and tauopathies

Synucleinopathies:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
  • REM behavioral disorder
  • Pure autonomic failure 
Tauopathies:
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Down syndrome
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Corticobasal degeneration
  • Pick’s disease/frontotemporal dementia
  • Chronic traumatic encephalopathy/punch drunk syndrome/dementia pugilistica
  • Postencephalitic parkinsonism
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated degeneration
  • Niemann Pick disease type C
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

questions.text: A 28-year-old man has had recurrent episodes of hematuria after a throat infection 2 days back. His urine protein/creatinine ratio is 2mg/mg. He undergoes a renal biopsy that shows the following. Which of the following is the newly approved drug that delays the progression of this renal disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an adult with an upper respiratory tract infection followed by episodes of recurrent hematuria & proteinuria, with immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits, suggests IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease). Sparsentan is the newly FDA-approved drug to reduce proteinuria in adults with primary Ig A nephropathy at risk of rapid disease progression.

It is a dual endothelin and angiotensin II receptor antagonist, indicated for use in patients with urine protein-to-creatinine ratio (UPCR) ≥1.5 g/g. It retards disease progression by reducing the proteinuria & simultaneously treating hypertension. 

Other drugs used commonly in the management include ACE inhibitors and ARBs to control high blood pressure and proteinuria. If ineffective, corticosteroids and immunosuppressants may be added.

In IgA nephropathy, the duration between a throat infection and haematuria is about 1-3 days, while in Post Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis the duration is about 1- 3 weeks

Other options:

Option A: Lorundrostat is a new drug for the treatment of resistant hypertension. It inhibits aldosterone synthase.

Option C: Finerenone is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist for the management of hypertension and has a positive effect on cardiovascular mortality.

Option D: Belimumab is an inhibitor of the B cell activating factor ( BAFF) that is used in the management of SLE.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a lump in her left breast. The lump has been present for the past 1 month. Examination shows a 2 X 2 cm firm lump that moves easily under the finger.  Which of the following is the best initial investigation for the assessment of her breast lump?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of mobile breast lump points to a diagnosis of fibroadenoma. Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in a woman with features of fibroadenoma. 

Fibroadenomas are benign solid tumors composed of stromal and epithelial elements seen commonly in women below 30 years. They present as a firm mass which is mobile and may increase in size over several months and wax and wane with the menstrual cycle.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 35 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes. 

Other Options:

Option A: Mammography is the first-line imaging for women over 40 who present with a new breast mass. It is of little help in discriminating between cysts and fibroadenomas. 

Option B: MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in cases where metastasis or spread to other breasts is suspected.

Option D: Carcinoembryonic antigen is used to evaluate the prognosis of breast cancer.

Related Pearl: Breast Lump Evaluation

questions.text: A child was referred to dermatology  OPD  with the complaints of rashes on the body. There was no history suggestive of itching or discomfort from the lesions. On examination, pale, firm papules measuring about 1–3 mm were noted and a provisional diagnosis of Miliaria profunda was made. What is the level of blockade of eccrine glands in this condition?
questions.solution:
In miliaria profunda, the rupture of the eccrine sweat duct occurs at the level of dermal-epidermal junction or even below.

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat glands.

The level of blockade in miliaria is:

Miliaria crystallina Stratum corneum
Miliaria rubra Malphigian layer
Miliaria profunda Dermoepidermal junction

 

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman was shifted to the observation room after a surgery in which a certain topical anesthetic was used. An hour later, the patient was found to be cyanotic and diaphoretic, with a room air oxygen saturation of 89%. Despite the use of a non-rebreathing face mask, the patient remained hypoxic, with oxygen saturation of around 86%. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be the cause of the patient's condition?

ABG shows:

pH- 7.35

pCO2- 37 mm Hg

HCO3- 24 mEq/L

pO2- 33.6 mm Hg
questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of methemoglobinemia, which is a common side effect of prilocaine.

The possible diagnosis of methemoglobinemia can be made because the patient is cyanosed, the cyanosis is unresponsive to ventilation, there is no prior history of respiratory problems, and the patient is exposed to a topical anesthetic during the procedure that is known to cause methemoglobinemia. The hepatic metabolism of prilocaine generates O-toluidine, which oxidizes hemoglobin to methemoglobin. Methemoglobinemia risk is directly associated with the total dose administered, usually appearing when doses exceed 8 mg/kg.

Pulse oximetry is used as an important assessment of oxygenation. It uses plethysmography and light absorbance measurements at two wavelengths to estimate oxygen saturation. It is inaccurate when more than two types of hemoglobin are present. This is because abnormal hemoglobin (methemoglobin) is not picked up by pulse oximetry. Pulse oximetry data (SpO2) should therefore be used with caution in patients with methemoglobinemia. Pulse oximetry with low levels of methemoglobinemia shows low levels of O2 saturation, and at high levels of methemoglobinemia shows high levels of O2 saturation.

Methemoglobinemia causes cyanosis, which does not respond to oxygen administration. Methemoglobin level assay is the best way to diagnose this condition. Levels >15% cause cerebral ischemia, whilst 60% blood level may cause fatality. Oxygen saturation in pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia plateaus at 85%

Intravenous administration of methylene blue is the treatment for methemoglobinemia.

Benzocaine can also cause methemoglobinemia, similar to prilocaine. The risk of methemoglobinemia due to Procaine, Bupivacaine, and Ropivacaine is significantly lower as compared to Prilocaine and Benzocaine.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: A child presents with suspected vitamin E deficiency and greasy, foul-smelling stools. A small intestinal biopsy is done and the image is shown below. Which of the following substances is accumulated in the abnormal cells observed in the image below?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards abetalipoproteinemia, which is further confirmed by the presence of vaccuolated epithelial cells in the intestine due to the accumulation of Triglyceride in them.

Abetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive disease caused by a mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP). MTTP is necessary for transferring lipids to nascent chylomicrons in the small intestine and to Very Low-Density Lipoprotein (VLDL) in the liver. In abetalipoproteinemia, chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL (apoB-containing lipoproteins) [Option A, B, and D] are absent, and plasma cholesterol and triglycerides are deficient. Lipid uptake, Lipolysis, and Micelle formation are all normal in these patients.

The usual presentation is fat malabsorption, diarrhea, and failure to thrive in early childhood. Vitamin E deficiency secondary to abetalipoproteinemia can lead to spinocerebellar degeneration. It manifests as loss of deep tendon reflexes, progressive ataxia, and lower limb spasticity by adulthood. Acanthocytosis and hemolytic anemia are also seen.

Intestinal biopsy shows lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium due to triglyceride accumulation. Accumulated lipids disappear after infants stop taking feed. Early treatment with supplemental vitamins, especially vitamin E, may significantly slow the development of neurological sequelae.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic agents interacts with Digoxin and would warrant dose adjustment if used together?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Verapamil is an antiarrhythmic agent that can interact with Digoxin & requires dosage adjustment.

Digoxin is a drug that is eliminated by the P glycoprotein pump (Pgp). P glycoprotein is an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter that is involved in the transport of several drugs and toxic substances. Verapamil can increase digoxin levels by reducing its renal clearance with interaction with the P glycoprotein pump.

Pgp SUBSTRATE:

  • Dabigatran
  • Digoxin
  • Fexofenadine
  • Loperamide

Pgp INHIBITOR:

  • Amiodarone
  • Carvedilol
  • Clarithromycin
  • Itraconazole
  • Propafenone
  • Quinidine
  • Verapamil

Drugs that block the Pgp transporter lead to increased concentrations of drugs like Digoxin. Amongst the given options Verapamil is an inhibitor of the Pgp transporter, thus resulting in Digoxin Toxicity.

Option A: Esmolol is a beta-blocker and does not significantly affect digoxin levels, though both can slow heart rate. Combined use requires caution for bradycardia but not dose adjustment of digoxin.

Option B: Adenosine is used as an antiarrhythmic agent for supra-ventricular tachycardias.

Option C: Lidocaine is a local anaesthetic and is used in the acute intravenous therapy of ventricular arrhythmias.

Combined use of Esmolol, Adenosine or Lidocaine with Digoxin requires caution for bradycardia but not dose adjustment of digoxin.

questions.text: During an ultrasound scan in a pregnant woman, the obstetrician attains the plane observed in the image below in order to measure a growth parameter. Identify the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The plane attained in the image is useful in measuring the abdominal circumference of the fetus, and the marked arrow represents the portal sinus, as it forms the J-shaped confluence with the umbilical vein. 

The abdominal circumference is measured using a transverse image that shows the stomach and the J-shaped confluence of the umbilical vein with the portal sinus. 

The image should ideally include no more than one rib on either side. The spine should appear in cross-section at the 3 o’clock or 9 o’clock position, and the kidneys should not be visible since they are lower in the abdomen. Abdominal circumference is the biometric parameter most influenced by fetal growth, and a measurement below the 10th percentile may indicate fetal growth restriction.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not commonly associated with gastrointestinal stromal tumors?
questions.solution:
Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are not associated with Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are the most common mesenchymal tumors of the abdomen, the stomach being the most common site. They arise from the Intestinal cells of Cajal, the pacemaker cells of the GIT that initiate the basal electrical rhythm (BER). GIST is associated with:

  • Carney's triad (GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma)
  • Carney–Stratakis syndrome (GIST, Paraganglioma)
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1

Grossly, GIST usually forms a solitary, well-circumscribed, fleshy mass covered by ulcerated or intact mucosa. Microscopically, GIST has elongated spindle cells, plumper epithelioid cells, or a mixed pattern. The image below shows microscopy of GIST composed of bundles of spindle-shaped tumor cells.

CT scan is the investigation of choice for primary GIST. EUS-directed fine-needle aspiration confirms the diagnosis. PET-CT is the investigation of choice for recurrent GIST. It is also used to assess response to therapy.

The management of GIST is as follows:

 Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST):

Treatment of choice:

Low risk of malignancy

Complete surgical resection + Surveillance

Intermediate-high risk of malignancy

Complete surgical resection + adjuvant Imatinib for 3 years

Unresectable

Neoadjuvant Imatinib

Metastatic

Imatinib

Imatinib can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA. However, succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)- deficient GIST is imatinib-resistant, so sunitinib, sorafenib, or regorafenib can be used instead.

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

Related Pearl: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

  • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
  • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
  • Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

  • GIST
  • Paraganglioma

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete injures his leg. He complains of pain in his knees. The following technique has been employed to alleviate his pain. This technique relieves pain using which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief. It is based on the gate control theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury to relieve pain.

Gate control theory is based on the inhibition of pain pathways in the spinal cord. Various sensory inputs from a particular dermatome reach the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. The pain is transmitted via A-delta and C fibers, whereas, A-beta fibers carry tactile sensations (touch, pressure) and A-alpha fibers carry proprioception.

When these large-diameter A-beta/A-alpha fibers are stimulated, they inhibit the pain pathway in the spinal cord. This inhibition is thought to result from the local lateral inhibition of interneurons in the spinal cord.

Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presented with a neck swelling measuring 2 cm. There was a history of previous radiation exposure to the neck. There were no palpable lymph nodes. Based on the workup, she was diagnosed to have a papillary thyroid carcinoma. What is the ideal surgical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In this given scenario, the patient has been diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) following radiation exposure to the neck; total thyroidectomy is the ideal surgical management.

Radiation-induced differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC): This patient's history of radiation exposure increases her risk of multifocal and bilateral disease, as well as recurrent disease. In such cases, total thyroidectomy is the recommended approach, irrespective of tumor size, to ensure complete removal of the thyroid tissue and minimize the risk of recurrence. Differentiated thyroid cancers include papillary thyroid cancer, follicular thyroid cancer, and hurtle cell cancer. 

Total thyroidectomy is performed in the following scenarios:

  • Tumors ≥4 cm
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension
  • Evidence of metastatic disease
  • Radiation-induced DTC
  • Familial nonmedullary thyroid cancer
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC

A central neck dissection is performed when level VI lymph nodes are involved. If both level VI and other lymph nodes are enlarged, the surgical approach includes total thyroidectomy, central neck dissection, and modified radical neck dissection. Prophylactic central neck dissection is advised for tumors exceeding 4 cm (classified as T3 and T4).

The TNM staging for differentiated thyroid carcinoma, according to the 8th edition of the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) (2018), is as follows:

1. Primary Tumor (T):

  • TX: Primary tumor cannot be assessed
  • T0: No evidence of primary tumor
  • T1: Tumor ≤2 cm, limited to the thyroidT1a: Tumor ≤1 cm
  • T1b: Tumor >1 cm but ≤2 cm
  • T2: Tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm, limited to the thyroid
  • T3:
    • T3a: Tumor >4 cm, limited to the thyroid      
    • T3b: Gross extrathyroidal extension invading only strap muscles
  • T4:
    • T4a: Tumor extends beyond the thyroid capsule to invade subcutaneous soft tissues, larynx, trachea, esophagus, or recurrent laryngeal nerve     
    • T4b: Tumor invades prevertebral fascia or encases carotid artery or mediastinal vessels.

2. Regional Lymph Nodes (N):

  • NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
  • N0: No regional lymph node metastasis
  • N1: Regional lymph node metastasis: 
    • N1a: Metastasis to level VI (pretracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal/Delphian lymph nodes)                 
    • N1b: Metastasis to unilateral, bilateral, or contralateral cervical (levels I, II, III, IV, or V) or retropharyngeal or superior mediastinal lymph nodes (level VII)

3. Distant Metastasis (M):

  • M0: No distant metastasis
  • M1: Distant metastasis present

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine-sufficient areas, among children, and among those exposed to ionizing radiation. It is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia, and dyspnea are associated with local invasion. On the scan, papillary carcinoma usually presents as a cold nodule.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis are lung > liver > bone > brain. It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Other options:

Option A: Hemithyroidectomy is typically performed for tumors between 1-4 cm without extrathyroidal extension or metastatic disease. 

Option B and D: Subtotal thyroidectomy and near-total thyroidectomy are not typically preferred because they leave residual thyroid tissue, which can complicate follow-up care and monitoring for recurrence.

Related Pearl: AJCC 8th edition Changes in the TNM staging of Thyroid neoplasms:

Differentiated Thyroid Cancer:

  • The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. 
  • Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.
  • N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If ≥ 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.
  • T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland
  • T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)
  • Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.
  • In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer continues to be classified as IVC disease.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cannot be removed by dialysis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options the drug that cannot be removed by hemodialysis is digoxin. 

Digoxin removal via hemodialysis is limited due to its large distribution volume, as digoxin is extensively distributed in the tissues. The efficiency of hemodialysis in drug overdose or intoxication depends on molecular weight, water solubility, protein binding, endogenous clearance, and distribution of the drug in the body.  A drug can be removed by hemodialysis if it has:

  • low molecular weight
  • low volume of distribution
  • high solubility in water
  • minimal protein binding

Salicylate Diazepam
Valproic acid Verapamil
Phenobarbital Opioids
Lithium Metoprolol

Generally, dialysis is indicated when medical management fails to control:

  • Volume overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Acidosis
  • Toxic ingestions
  • Severe complications of uremia like asterixis, pericardial rub or effusion, encephalopathy, and uremic bleeding.

questions.text: A young patient presented with persistent headache and vomiting. NCCT, CT angiography, and reformatted images are shown below. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
CT revealing blood in the basal cistern points to a diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) and angiography images showing sacular aneurysms are suggestive of berry aneurysms. It is least likely to be associated with cerebral amyloid angiopathy.

Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. The diagnosis is suspected when a hyperattenuating material is seen filling the subarachnoid spaces including interhemispheric fissures, Sylvian fissures and basal cisterns. Most commonly this is apparent around the circle of Willis, on account of the majority of berry aneurysms occurring in this region (65%), or in the Sylvian fissure (30%).

Berry aneurysms are commonly associated with syndromes such as Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) and Multiorgan heritable connective tissue disorders such as Marfan and Ehlers-Danlos II and IV syndromes and other disorders such as fibromuscular dysplasia, Neurofibromatosis Type I and Loeys–Dietz syndrome are associated with increased risk of berry aneurysms.

Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is a condition where amyloid beta-peptide proteins build up in the walls of small to medium-sized blood vessels in the brain and lead to intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH) in older people. They are not associated with subarachnoid haemorrhages.

Hyperdensity in the suprasellar cistern and the interhemispheric fissure gives a characteristic star of death sign. (shown below).

questions.text: The parents of a four-month-old boy came to the pediatrician with concerns about repeated spasms. Lately, his parents noticed that he can no longer hold his head steadily. EEG shows hypsarrhythmia.  What is the earliest skin lesion expected in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario of spasms, developmental regression (inability to hold his head steadily) and the EEG showing hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes) suggest West syndrome, which shows an association with Tuberous sclerosis. The earliest skin lesion expected in tuberous sclerosis is Ash leaf macules.

Infantile spasms (seen in West syndrome) are shown below- 

Tuberous sclerosis is an inherited neurocutaneous disorder. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. The clinical features include:

  • Ash-leaf macules - hypopigmented macules
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Shagreen patches, mainly over the lower back (Shagreen patches are also seen in Tuberous sclerosis but are not the most common or the earliest skin lesions.)
  • Periungual fibromas

Other Options:

Option A: Café au lait macules - hyperpigmented macules seen in patients with Neurofibromatosis Type 1.

Option C: Shagreen Patch - seen over the lower back in patients with tuberous sclerosis. However, it is not the most common skin lesion in tuberous sclerosis.

Option D: Port wine stain - is a type of birthmark. Consists of flat red discoloration of skin. Port wine stain on the face in the Cranial Nerve V1 / V2 distribution is seen in Sturge Weber syndrome. Seizures can also occur in Sturge weber syndrome but they are not associated with infantile spasms.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea, obesity, short stature, and intellectual disability. On examination, she has hypotonia and underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics. Hormonal assays reveal low FSH and LH levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an adolescent girl with primary amenorrhea, obesity, hypotonia, and low FSH and LH levels (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism) is consistent with Prader-Willi syndrome.

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a genetic disorder caused by a defect in the paternal copy of chromosome 15q11-q13, typically due to deletion or maternal uniparental disomy. The patients present with:

  • Primary amenorrhea due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
  • Obesity, often due to hyperphagia and elevated ghrelin levels.
  • Short stature and small hands and feet with hypotonia.
  • Intellectual disability and developmental delays.
  • Behavioral abnormalities, including temper tantrums and obsessive-compulsive tendencies.

The following image shows a child suffering from Prader-Willi syndrome:

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) and Angelman syndrome (AS) are both disorders of genomic imprinting, where the clinical phenotype depends on the parent of origin of the affected chromosome 15q11-q13 region.

  Prader-Willi syndrome Angelman syndrome

Other options:

Option A: Kallmann syndrome presents with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with anosmia.

Option C: Turner syndrome has hyper-gonadotropic hypogonadism with short stature and 45XO karyotype.

Option D: Swyer syndrome has 46XY karyotype with gonadal dysgenesis (streak gonads) presenting with primary amenorrhea.

questions.text: You are an intern assisting in a case of laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the surgeon dissects the Calot's triangle and asks you to name the structure marked as 1 in the image. Your correct response should be ___________
questions.solution:
The marked structure 1 in the image is cystic artery and structure 2 is cystic duct. These are the only two structures to enter the gall badder.

The boundaries of Calot’s triangle are: (Mnemonic: 3C's)

  • Superior boundary: Superior border of the Cystic artery
  • Medial boundary: Common hepatic duct
  • Inferior boundary: Cystic duct

The triangle contains a cystic artery, cystic lymph node, and autonomic fibers reaching the gallbladder. The cystic artery is both a boundary and part of the triangle's contents. Identification of Calot’s triangle is important during laparoscopic cholecystectomy for safe ligation and division of cystic duct and cystic artery. A laparoscopic image with structures marked is shown below:

The boundaries of hepatocystic triangle are: (Mnemonic: LHC)

  • Superior boundary: Inferior surface of Liver
  • Medial boundary: Common Hepatic duct
  • Lateral boundary: Cystic duct

questions.text: A kidney specimen with gross necrosis was sent for histopathological examination which showed increased eosinophilia in the necrotic tissue. What is the reason attributable to the same?
questions.solution:
Increased eosinophilia observed in necrotic tissue during histopathological examination occurs primarily due to the loss of cytoplasmic RNA.

Cytoplasmic RNA normally binds hematoxylin (a basic dye) and gives a basophilic appearance. The absence of RNA reduces basophilia, while denatured proteins bind eosin (an acidic dye) more avidly, resulting in increased eosinophilia. Morphological changes that occur in necrosis are:

  • Increased eosinophilia: Due to the loss of cytoplasmic RNA and accumulation of denatured proteins.
  • Glassy or shiny appearance: Attributable to the loss of glycogen particles. (Option C)
  • Moth-eaten appearance: Due to the digestion of organelles by lysosomal enzymes.

Cellular changes in necrosis: Necrosis disrupts the cell membrane, leading to the leakage of cellular contents, local inflammation, and enzymatic digestion. Cellular swelling (hydropic change or vacuolar degeneration) is the earliest manifestation of all forms of injury to cells. (Option D) Key nuclear changes include:

  • Pyknosis: Nuclear shrinkage with condensation of chromatin.
  • Karyorrhexis: Fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus.
  • Karyolysis: Complete dissolution of the nucleus, leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells.

The various types of necrosis are as follows:

  • Coagulative necrosis: Seen in infarcts of all organs except the brain.
  • Caseous necrosis: Associated with tuberculosis.
  • Liquefactive necrosis: Common in abscesses, brain infarcts, and wet gangrene.
  • Fat necrosis: Observed in acute pancreatitis and breast tissue.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis: Seen in vasculitis, Aschoff bodies, and malignant hypertension.

Other options:

Option B: Fragmentation of cells occurs as a later event in necrosis and is primarily due to the breakdown of the plasma membrane and structural components of the cell. However, fragmentation of cells does not directly explain the increased eosinophilia.

questions.text: Rees and Eckler fluid is used as a diluting fluid in the RBC Pipette for?
questions.solution:
Rees and Ecker fluid is used in the RBC pipette for the platelet count.

Rees and Ecker fluid contains:

  • Sodium citrate to prevent coagulation
  • Formaldehyde to preserve platelet morphology and prevent clumping
  • Brilliant cresyl blue to stain platelets, making them visible under a microscope

This fluid ensures accurate platelet counts by maintaining platelet integrity and enhancing contrast. 

Other options:

Option A: For RBC counts, diluting fluids like Hayem's fluid or Gower's solution are used.

Option B: For WBC counts, Turk's fluid is commonly employed, as it lyses RBCs while staining WBC nuclei.

Option D: For differential leukocyte counts, blood smears are prepared and stained with dyes like Leishman’s stain or Wright’s stain.

questions.text: A preterm baby, born at 31 weeks of gestation requires oxygen therapy for 5 weeks. The baby is assessed for lung diseases at 36 weeks of gestational age. The baby still requires oxygen therapy. Which of the following conditions is the baby at increased risk of?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a preterm baby managed with oxygen therapy for more than 5 weeks and while still requiring oxygen is at an increased risk of Bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a chronic lung disease that primarily affects premature infants who have received prolonged mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy. It is a pathologic process leading to clinical features of chronic lung disease that originates in the neonatal period and is defined by an oxygen requirement for 28 days postnatally. Inflammatory injury to the developing lungs due to barotrauma and oxygen toxicity resulting from prolonged mechanical ventilation is the key factor driving the pathogenesis of BPD. 

The image given below shows the pathogenesis behind BPD.

BPD is further classified at the age of 36 weeks of gestation according to the degree of O2 supplementation. Neonates receiving positive pressure support or ≥30% supplemental O2 at 36 weeks of gestation or at discharge (whichever occurs first) are diagnosed as having severe BPD. Those requiring 22–29% supplemental O2 have moderate BPD and those who previously required O2 supplementation for at least 28 days but are currently breathing room air have mild BPD.

BPD is managed with supportive treatment. It includes appropriate ventilatory support and appropriate nutritional support to promote the growth of the lungs

Other Options:

Option A: Transient tachypnea of newborns is typically self-limiting and is seen in term or late preterm infants. It is caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. This condition resolves within 24 to 72 hours of birth and does not require long-term oxygen therapy.

Option B: Persistent pulmonary hypertension would not explain why the infant requires oxygen at 36 weeks postmenstrual age if they were initially supported with oxygen therapy for 5 weeks.

Option D: Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs when meconium is aspirated into the lungs during or shortly after delivery. This condition is more common in term or post-term infants and is often associated with significant respiratory distress shortly after birth.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with right-sided sensory loss following a stroke. The MRI reveals an infarct involving the territory of the vessel marked as 4. Which of the following best explains the patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Thalamic stroke involving the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus
Lacunar stroke in the internal capsule
Thalamic hemorrhage involving the anterior nucleus

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of right-sided sensory loss following a stroke following an infarct involving the territory of Posterior Cerebral Artery (marked as 4) is suggestive of Thalamic Syndrome (Dejerine-Roussy Syndrome). A thalamic stroke involving the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus best explains the patient’s symptoms.

The thalamic Déjérine-Roussy syndrome consists of contralateral hemisensory loss followed later by an agonising or burning pain in the affected areas. In the given image, since the left posterior cerebral artery is affected, therefore the patient will have right-sided sensory loss.

The ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL) is responsible for relaying somatosensory input (pain, temperature, proprioception, vibration) from the contralateral body via the spinothalamic and dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathways. The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies:

  • Occipital Lobe: Visual cortex and association areas.
  • Temporal Lobe: Inferior temporal gyrus, hippocampus, parahippocampal gyrus.
  • Thalamus: VPL, VPM nuclei (via thalamogeniculate and thalamo-perforating arteries).
  • Midbrain: Tectum (superior/inferior colliculi), red nucleus, substantia nigra.
  • Splenium of Corpus Callosum: Posterior interhemispheric communication.
  • Choroid Plexus: Posterior part of lateral ventricles and third ventricle.

Other Options:

Option B: The internal capsule transmits motor signals via the corticospinal tract, and lesions here cause pure motor hemiparesis without significant sensory deficits or pain.

Option C. Thalamic haemorrhage involving the anterior nucleus is involved in memory and limbic system functions. Damage results in memory loss and behavioural changes, not somatosensory or pain-related symptoms.

Option D. Damage to the subthalamic nucleus causes hemiballismus, a hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by flinging movements of the contralateral limbs, rather than sensory loss or pain.

questions.text: Drug X is a newly approved PIK3CA inhibitor for the treatment of Breast Cancer in patients with Hormone-resistant, ER- positive, (HER2)-negative, locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer in combination with Fulvestrant & Palbociclib. What is Drug X?
questions.solution:
Inavolisib is a newly approved PIK3CA inhibitor for Breast cancer.

It is indicated in combination with Fulvestrant + Palbociclib in hormone-resistant, ER +,  Her2 -, advanced breast cancer. Inavolisib is PIK3CA (phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase) inhibitor and inhibits cell proliferation. The following image shows PI3K/AKT/mTOR Signaling Pathway.

Other options :

Option B: Olaparib is a PARP inhibitor used in Breast Cancer patients with BRCA 1 or 2 mutations.

Option C: Abemaciclib is a CDK 4/6 inhibitor indicated in Her2 -ve, metastatic breast cancer.

Option D: Elacestrant is an oral selective estrogen receptor degrader (SERD) indicated in ER +ve, Her2 -ve breast cancer.

questions.text: A male patient came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of brittle beard hair with the presence of soft, white nodules loosely adherent along the hair shaft. Pruritus is absent. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of brittle beard hair with the presence of soft, white nodules loosely adherent along the hair shaft is suggestive of white piedra and the causative agent is Trichosporon beigelii.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types: white piedra and black piedra. 

White piedra is caused by Trichosporon beigelii. It is characterized by the presence of soft, white, or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic and facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is seen in the culture as nodules in the form of a sheath extending around the hair shaft. Arthroconidia and blastoconidia are seen.

Black piedra is characterized by the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. It is caused by Piedraia hortae (option C). On microscopy, they appear as brown, thick-walled with septate hyphae and chlamydoconidia.

Shaving or cutting off the affected hair is useful in managing both black and white piedra. In black piedra, topical benzoic acid and terbinafine is helpful while topical antifungals, azoles, and allylamines can be useful in white piedra.

Other superficial mycoses and infectious organisms are Hortaea (Exophiala) werneckii (option B) causing tinea nigra. They cause lesions in the palm which appear dark brown to black in color. On Sabouraud agar, they appear as grey or black colonies. Skin scrapings reveal brownish branched septate hyphae and budding cells.

Tinea versicolor (Option D) or Pityriasis versicolor is caused by fungi belonging to the Malassezia species like Malassezia globosa, Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur. The characteristic lesions are macules that are hypo or hyperpigmented on the chest, upper back, arms, or abdomen. Skin scrapings show yeast-like cells and short branching filaments.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrician with progressive jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine. Ultrasound of the abdomen showed a triangular cord sign and an absent gallbladder. Intraoperative cholangiogram showed atresia restricted to the common bile duct. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of progressive jaundice, pale stools, dark urine, an absent gallbladder, and the triangular cord sign on ultrasound indicate extra hepatic biliary atresia. The management for this condition is Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.

Biliary atresia is characterized by inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree, resulting in bile flow obstruction and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The clinical features include persistent jaundice, clay-colored stools, and hepatomegaly. The meconium may be slightly bile stained, but later, the stools will be pale, and the urine will be dark. Untreated newborns will show signs of liver cirrhosis and failure (ascites, portal hypertension, and failure to thrive). Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and preduodenal portal vein.

Laboratory evaluation will show elevated direct and indirect bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase. Ultrasound Abdomen will show hypoplastic or absent gall bladder and triangular cord sign. USG Abdomen showing the triangular cord sign is given below:

According to Bailey 28th edition:

  • Fasting USG is the gold standard for diagnosis
  • MRCP is highly sensitive and specific
  • Cholangiography defines surgical anatomy.

Management of extrahepatic biliary atresia:

Type I Atresia restricted to the common bile duct (CBD)

Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II Atresia of the CBD + common hepatic duct(CHD)

Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) (Option A)
Type III

Atresia of the CBD +CHD + right and left hepatic duct

Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy)

The image given below shows the Kasai procedure.

Other options:

Option C: Liver transplantation: Reserved for patients who fail to achieve adequate bile drainage after Kasai's procedure.

Option D: Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage: This is not a definitive treatment for biliary atresia. It is typically used to temporarily relieve bile duct obstruction in other conditions, such as cholangiocarcinoma or bile duct strictures.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presented to the OPD with chronic fatigue, dysphagia and regurgitation. Her blood investigations showed decreased mean corpuscular volume (MCV), mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH)  and increased Red cell distribution width (RDW). Endoscopy was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario dysphagia, blood picture showing iron deficiency anaemia and endoscopy showing post-cricoid web are suggestive of Patterson-Kelly-Brown Syndrome/ Plummer-Vinson syndrome. 

It commonly affects middle-aged women with long-standing anaemia. Triad of Patterson-Kelly-Brown Syndrome:

  1. Iron deficiency anaemia
  2. Esophageal webs
  3. Dysphagia

Oesophagal webs are most common in the upper oesophagus (post-cricoid area), where they are generally semi-circumferential, eccentric lesions that protrude less than 5 mm and have a thickness of 2 to 4 mm. Microscopically, webs are composed of fibrovascular connective tissue and overlying epithelium.

The main symptom of webs is dysphagia associated with incompletely chewed food and regurgitation of food. It is a premalignant condition. It is a known risk factor for post-cricoid hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.  

Treatment includes correcting iron-deficiency anaemia which may improve dysphagia and pain. Oesophagal bougies can be used during upper endoscopy to dilate the post-cricoid webs and allow normal swallowing and passage of food.

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (option A) is seen when there is a gastrin-secreting pancreatic tumor (Gastrinoma). The increase in gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion. The excessive acid entering the duodenum cannot be neutralized by the pancreatic bicarbonate, and thus, duodenal ulcers are formed. Steatorrhea also occurs due to pancreatic lipase inhibition. 

Zenker's diverticulum (option B) is a pulsion diverticulum that occurs in the hypopharynx (just above the esophagus), typically causing dysphagia and regurgitation.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: While studying the x-ray of a child brought to the casualty, the doctor notices a "string of beads" appearance in the paravertebral region. Which of the following conditions is this finding most likely associated with?
questions.solution:
String of beads appearance in the paravertebral region on an x-ray is associated with infantile whiplash syndrome. 

In battered baby syndrome/ Caffey syndrome / infantile whiplash syndrome, violent squeezing of the chest from side to side causes fracture of costochondral junctions and also along with the posterior angles of the rib. After callus formation which takes around 2 weeks, it gives a “string of beads” appearance in the paravertebral region on X-ray.

A battered child is one who is a victim of repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, inflicted by the parent or a guardian. The physical injury may also be associated with deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

It is usually seen in children less than 3 years of age with a history of emotional or financial problems in the family.

Laceration of the upper lip and tear of the fraenulum are frequently seen lesions, resulting from efforts to silence a crying child.

Bruises may be seen on either side of the chest, behind the axillae, and down the anterior chest wall, due to the child being gripped in a rough manner, between the perpetrator's hands and shaken. This shaking of a child leads to infantile whiplash syndrome, often resulting in subdural hematoma and intraocular bleeding in battered babies. Permanent brain damage can occur due to habitual, prolonged shaking. 

The most common cause of death is a head injury, followed by the rupture of any abdominal organ.

Other options:
Option A: Sandifer syndrome involves gastroesophageal reflux in infants resulting in episodes of generalized stiffening and opisthotonic posturing. This may be accompanied by apnea, staring, and minimal jerking of the extremities. These episodes often occur 30 min after a feed and in older children, it manifests with episodic dystonic or dyskinetic movements consisting of laterocollis, retrocollis, or torticollis.

Option C: Munchausen's syndrome involves feigning illness or injury and going from hospital to hospital for unnecessary investigations and treatment. It is seen in the adults themselves.

Option D: Sudden infant death syndrome is defined as the sudden and unexpected death of a seemingly healthy infant, and whose death remains unexplained even after a thorough case investigation, death scene examination, review of clinical history and a complete autopsy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a suspected brain tumour is subjected to a non-invasive test based on the principle of magnetic resonance to analyse the metabolite distribution within the brain tissue. In this test, which of the following components will show a significant rise?
questions.solution:
Magnetic Resonance (MR) spectroscopy is a non-invasive test based on the principle of magnetic resonance used to analyse the metabolite distribution within the brain tissue. The most typical pattern seen in brain tumours includes an elevation in choline accompanied by a decrease in N-acetylaspartate (NAA) and creatine, without the presence of lactate, or lipids.

Elevated choline levels reflect the rapid turnover of cell membranes (due to rapid synthesis and breakdown) and are enhanced in tumour regions with high mitotic activity. 

The below image shows magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing a choline peak and decreased creatinine levels is diagnostic of glioma.

The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

It contains N-acetylaspartate (NAA), a neuronal viability signal; choline (a component of cell membranes and a marker of cellular turnover); creatine (present in metabolically active tissues); lipids (released with cell membrane disruption); and lactate (a hallmark of anaerobic metabolism).

questions.text:
A nursing student comes to the ER with a history of needle prick while drawing a patient's blood. The patient was found to be hepatitis B positive. The student has already completed 6 doses of Hep B vaccination. The response is assessed and labeled as documented non-responder. What will be the post-exposure prophylaxis advised in this case?

ER - Emergency room

choices.text: Two doses of Hepatitis B immunoglobulin 1 month apart
Single dose of Hepatitis B immunoglobulin and initiate revaccination

questions.solution:
The case scenario of a health care professional with 6 completed doses of hep B immunisation showing no response is known as non-responders. Non-responders with exposure to a hepatitis B-positive patient require two doses of Hepatitis B immunoglobulin 1 month apart.
 
As per our national Infection prevention and control (IPC) guidelines, following a complete course of 3 doses at 0, 1, and 6 months, the response is assessed via antibody tittres and the individual is labeled as a responder or non-responder.

  • Documented responders need no further management when exposed.
  • Non-responders after 3 doses should be given another 3 doses of the vaccine. 

Management of non-responders is given below:

  • Non-responder after 3 doses exposed to a positive or unknown source (high risk) requires HBIG single dose and initiate revaccination.
  • Non-responder after 6 doses exposed to a positive source requires 2 doses of HBIG 1 month apart.
  • Non-responder after 6 doses exposed to an unknown source (high risk) requires HBIG single dose and initiate revaccination.
  • No treatment is required if the source is negative.

If the antibody titres are unknown:

  • If the person is exposed to a positive patient, test for anti-HBs antibodies:
    • If more than 10 mIU/mL, no treatment required.
    • If less than 10 mIU/ml, HBIG single dose and vaccine booster is adviced.
  • If the person is exposed to a patient with unknown status, test for anti-HBs antibodies:
    • If more than 10 mIU/mL, no treatment required.
    • If less than 10 mIU/ml, initiate revaccination.
  • No treatment required if the patient tests negative for hepatitis B.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with mild skeletal deformities and a corneal opacity. He had no signs of mental retardation. Investigations revealed L-Iduronidase enzyme deficiency. Dermatan sulfate is positive in the urine. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with L-iduronidase enzyme deficiency is suggestive of Scheie's Syndrome.

Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans.

Deficiency of α-L-Iduronidase results in a wide range of clinical involvement, from severe Hurler syndrome to mild Scheie syndrome. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

The Scheie syndrome (MPS I-S ) is a milder form of MPS-I. The symptoms appear after 5 years of age and the diagnosis is made between 10-20 years. It is characterized by normal intelligence and stature, joint stiffness, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Ophthalmic (corneal clouding, glaucoma, and retinal degeneration) and cardiac involvement (aortic valve disease) might be present. In Scheie's Syndrome, dermatan sulfate is lost in the urine.

The Hurler syndrome (MPS I-H) is a severe progressive disorder with the involvement of multiple organs and tissues that results in premature death. Affected children usually present between 6-24 months of age. 

Hurler-Scheie syndrome is an intermediate between Hurler syndrome and Scheie syndrome. The onset of symptoms is between 3-8 years of age. They have mild or no intellectual dysfunction. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

questions.text: Knudson’s two-hit hypothesis was given for the prototype tumour suppressor gene Retinoblastoma (RB) gene. Which of the following statements is false regarding the hypothesis?

choices.text: In sporadic cases, both RB1 alleles are mutated in the same cell
Familial carriers usually develop unilateral retinoblastoma
Familial carriers have an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma
Sporadic cases have both normal RB alleles at birth

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding Knudson’s two-hit hypothesis is that familial carriers produce mostly unilateral retinoblastoma. Familial carriers usually develop bilateral retinoblastoma.

Knudson's two-hit hypothesis explains the development of retinoblastoma (RB) through mutations in the retinoblastoma (RB) gene. According to this hypothesis:

  • Two mutations (or "hits") are required. The first mutation is inherited in familial cases, while the second mutation occurs somatically. 
  • In familial retinoblastoma, one RB1 allele is already mutated in all the body’s cells, and a second hit (mutation) to the other allele leads to the development of retinoblastoma. They are also at increased risk of developing osteosarcoma (Option C) and other soft tissue sarcomas, which are transmitted in an autosomal dominant trait.
  • In sporadic cases, both RB1 alleles are mutated in the same cell through somatic mutations, and this happens less frequently in both eyes, making sporadic cases more likely to be unilateral. (Options A and D)

questions.text: What will happen to the sensitivity and the specificity of a screening test, if the cutoff value is changed from Point B to Point A?
questions.solution:
As the cutoff point for the test changes from Point B to Point A, the test's sensitivity increases and the test's specificity decreases.

In clinical practice, sensitivity and specificity are inversely related: an increase in one causes a decrease in the other. This is because test results for people with and without a given disease typically lie on a continuum, overlapping each other, rather than forming two discrete groups. Therefore, the clinician must select a “cutoff point” to make a diagnostic decision. This can be seen in the graph showing cutoff values in the question, where point B is the preferred cutoff.

When the cutoff value is decreased by changing the cutoff from Point B to Point A, The test will now identify everyone with the disease and thus will have a very high sensitivity. But at this point, the test would also incorrectly diagnose many healthy individuals as diseased. Therefore the number of false positive results would be also high and thus the Specificity will decrease.

Opposite trends will be seen when the cutoff point is changed from B to C, leading to higher specificity but low sensitivity. Thus the cutoff points of Screening tests are very meticulously chosen to maintain high enough specificity and sensitivity both for clinical practice.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of decreased urine output, cola-colored urine, and swelling of the hands and face. On examination, there is elevated blood pressure and pitting edema in the lower limbs. His mother gives a history of skin infection 4 weeks back. A diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is made.  Which of the following is best used to detect the previous streptococcal skin infection in this case?
questions.solution:
Anti-DNAase B antibody level is the best indicator of previous streptococcal skin infections in PSGN cases.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) usually occurs following an infection of the throat or skin by nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci and is characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema,  hypertension, and renal insufficiency. Diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN):

  • Urine analysis shows RBCs, along with RBC casts, proteinuria, and neutrophils.
  • Hemodilution and low-grade hemolysis may produce mild normocytic normochromic anemia.
  • Serum C3 levels are decreased in the acute phase and return to normal in 6-8 weeks.
  • Throat swab (Streptococcal Antigen Detection) for prior streptococcal infection or carrier state identification.
  • Raised ASO titers are commonly seen following pharyngeal infection. An increase in ASO levels is rarely seen with skin infections.
  • Anti-DNAase B antibody level is the best indicator of previous streptococcal skin infections.
  • MRI may be done in patients with neurological manifestations and it can demonstrate posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome.

Note: CAMP Test is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococci).

Microscopic Findings in PSGN:
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase in the mesangial matrix. 
  • Immunofluorescence: Lumpy-bumpy deposits of immunoglobulin and complement on the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or humps, are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

Treatment:

Managing the acute effects of renal insufficiency (sodium restriction and prescribing diuretics - usually with intravenous furosemide) and hypertension is the mainstay. Antibiotic therapy with a 10-day course of penicillin is recommended to limit the spread of nephritogenic pathogens. But antibiotics do not alter the natural course of PSGN.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old lady with a history of recurrent renal stones, fatigue, and abdominal pains presents with poor blood pressure control. Current medications are lisinopril, amlodipine, and furosemide. Her blood pressure is 166/98 mmHg. Laboratory values are given below. Further evaluation is likely to show which one of the following?
Serum Values
Sodium 136 mEq/L
Potassium 4.1 mEq/L
Calcium 13.2 mg/dL
BUN 18 mg/dL
Creatinine  0.8 mg/dL

choices.text: Reduced blood flow in renal arteries

questions.solution:
The patient presents with a history of recurrent renal stones (stones), abdominal pains (groans), fatigue, and elevated serum calcium are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism has increased serum parathyroid levels and can be associated with MEN1 and MEN2A syndromes.

Patients may also present with polyuria, polydipsia, vomiting, and pathological fractures. ECG may show increased PR interval and shortened QT interval.  

Elevated blood pressure despite using three antihypertensive medications including one diuretic suggests resistant hypertension in this patient. Pheochromocytoma as a part of MEN2A syndrome may be the cause for this.

Other options:

Option A: Elevated aldosterone to renin ratio is seen in Conn's syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism. It causes secondary hypertension and hypokalemia due to hyperaldosteronism. However, it would not explain this patient's hypercalcemia, normal potassium levels, and history of renal stones.

Option B: Reduced blood flow in renal arteries can be seen in renal artery stenosis or fibromuscular dysplasia. It may be the cause of this patient's resistant hypertension and fatigue. However, hypercalcemia or recurrent nephrolithiasis will not be present.

Option D: Elevated 24-hour urine cortisol level is seen in Cushing's syndrome. The condition presents with weight gain, moon facies, easy bruising, buffalo hump, and insulin resistance.

questions.text:
An anxious primigravida came to you for a second opinion with the report of a second-trimester scan and biochemical screening test suspecting Down syndrome. Which of the following are suggestive of Down syndrome?
  1. Hypoplasia of nasal bone
  2. Elevated levels of unconjugated estriol
  3. Sandal gap between first and second toes
  4. Reduced levels of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  5. Low levels of beta HCG
questions.solution:
Hypoplasia of nasal bone, sandal gap between first and second toes, and reduced levels of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (1, 3, and 4) are sonographic and biochemical features suggestive of Down's syndrome or Trisomy 21.

Soft signs or second-trimester sonographic markers associated with Down syndrome fetuses are:

  • Brachycephaly or shortened frontal lobe
  • Clinodactyly (hypoplasia of the 5th digit middle phalanx)
  • Flat facies
  • Echogenic bowel, echogenic intracardiac focus
  • Absence or hypoplasia of the nasal bone
  • Nuchal fold thickening
  • Sandal gap between first and second toes
  • Single transverse palmar crease
  • Single umbilical artery

A focal papillary muscle calcification that is neither a structural nor functional cardiac abnormality is called an echogenic intracardiac focus. Echogenic fetal bowel which appears as bright as the bone has a six-fold increased risk for Down syndrome. 

Two-thirds of fetuses with Down syndrome have an absence or hypoplasia of nasal bone. A prominent space between the first and second toes termed sandal-toe gap is also seen in intrauterine sonography of Down syndrome.

The abnormalities seen on the quadruple screening test for Down syndrome are:
