questions.text: Transport of iron from enterocytes into the blood is done by which of the following proteins:
questions.solution:
Transport of iron from enterocytes into the blood is done by ferroportin.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron in our gut exists in 2 forms, they are non-heme and heme iron. Luminal non-heme iron is mostly in the Fe3+ (ferric) state and is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases. Fe2+ iron is then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

Given below is an image of iron absorption that shows divalent metal transporter-1 protein in intestinal mucosal cells.

Heme iron is moved across the apical membrane into the cytoplasm through heme transporters.

In the duodenal cells, Fe2+ iron can follow one of two pathways: transport to the blood or storage as mucosal iron. The nonstorage form of Fe2+ iron is transported from the cytoplasm into circulation by the protein ferroportin. A protein called hephaestin (Hp) is associated with ferroportin 1. It is not a transporter itself, but it facilitates basolateral transport

Once in circulation, Fe2+ is again oxidized back to Fe3+ iron by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The newly absorbed Fe3+ iron binds rapidly to transferrin, which delivers iron to red cell progenitors in the marrow.

Hepcidin is a protein secreted from the liver that plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate, it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby decreases iron absorption.

 

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient with a history of recurrent arthritis presents with the deformity as shown below. No joint erosions are seen on the radiograph. Investigations show negative anti-CCP antibodies and the presence of nephrotic range proteinuria. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a deformity with ulnar deviation of the fingers. The absence of anti-CCP antibodies rules out Rheumatoid Arthritis. Non-erosive arthritis and nephrotic range proteinuria point towards SLE.

Patients with SLE tend to have intermittent polyarthritis, most commonly involving hands, wrists, and knees. Along with arthritis, there is inflammation of the surrounding soft tissues as well. Erosions are rarely seen. Joint deformities such as swan neck and ulnar deviation of the fingers can develop, but they are often reducible — unlike rheumatoid arthritis, where these deformities are not reducible. Ischemic necrosis of the bone is seen more commonly in SLE than in rheumatoid arthritis, and the diagnosis should be suspected when pain persists in a single joint.

Renal involvement in SLE is known as lupus nephritis. Immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as a full-house effect. Electron microscopy will show the presence of subendothelial deposits.

Rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, and psoriatic arthritis cause joint erosions. Furthermore, proteinuria is not a likely manifestation in psoriatic arthritis and osteoarthritis, but can be present in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with abdominal pain, bloody stools, and elevated blood pressure. He is a known case of chronic hepatitis B. The arterial biopsy finding of this patient is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chronic hepatitis B infection and arterial biopsy findings of fibrinoid necrosis suggests a likely diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). 

Polyarteritis nodosa is a vasculitis syndrome that causes segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation in small and medium-sized arteries. It is often superimposed with aneurysm or thrombosis. 

About one-third of the patients with PAN are noted to have chronic hepatitis B which causes the formation of HBsAg-HbsAb immune complexes being deposited in the vessel walls.

Histologically, during the acute phase, there is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall along with fibrinoid necrosis and luminal thrombosis. Fibrinoid necrosis is usually the result of the deposition of immune complexes and plasma proteins in the arterial wall. On biopsy, fibrinoid necrosis appears as bright pink and amorphous deposits in the vessel wall. 

Clinical features include rapidly accelerating hypertension caused by the involvement of renal arteries, abdominal pain, and bloody stools due to vascular gastrointestinal lesions. 

Other options:

Option A- Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. Arterial biopsy findings show an onion-skin appearance that consists of a concentric arrangement of smooth muscle cells with a thickened and re-duplicated basement membrane.

The image below shows the characteristic onion skin appearance of a renal arteriole.

Option C- Monckeberg medial sclerosis is a vascular pathology of aging characterized by calcifications accumulating in the medial layers of muscular arteries. Since there is no vascular compromise (no luminal narrowing), it is usually an accidental finding.

The image below shows calcific deposits (deep purple on H&E staining) in the arterial wall.

Option D- Giant cell arteritis/temporal arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting large- to small-sized arteries of the head and is commonly seen in the elderly. Patients usually present with constitutional symptoms and symptoms specific to the artery involved:

  • cerebral artery, temporal artery- facial pain, headache
  • ophthalmic artery- sudden onset visual loss, diplopia

Arterial biopsy findings consist of granulomatous inflammation with internal elastic lamina fragmentation and T-cell infiltration. The image below shows internal elastic lamina fragmentation (black arrow) and giant cells (yellow arrow) in a cerebral artery.

questions.text: All the following drugs and their response with the receptors are correctly paired, except _______.

choices.text: Graph 4- succinylcholine at Nicotinic ACh Receptor

questions.solution:
All the following statement is correct, except option C. Graph 4 depicts the action of the inverse agonist. Whereas, succinylcholine exhibits agonism at the nicotinic ACh Receptor.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor. Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist.
 
Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor. Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 3 represents the competitive antagonist: An agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor, but does not have any effect of its own. Example: Naltrexone and naloxone are antagonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist. Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with intellectual disability has hypocalcemia, recurrent infections, and characteristic facies with short philtrum, low-set ears, and micrognathia. Where does the deletion occur in this condition?

choices.text: Band p11.4 on the short arm of chromosome 22
Band q11.4 on the long arm of chromosome 22
Band q11.2 on the long arm of chromosome 22
Band p11.2 on the short arm of chromosome 22

questions.solution:
The child with intellectual disability, hypocalcemia, recurrent infections, and characteristic facies with short philtrum, low-set ears, and micrognathia has DiGeorge syndrome, which is due to a microdeletion in the 22q11.2 region on the long arm of chromosome 22.

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

  • T – Thymic aplasia

AC - Air Conduction

BC - Bone Conduction

choices.text: 4000 Hz in both BC and AC
2000 Hz in both BC and AC

questions.solution:
Boiler’s Notch typically dips at 4000 Hz due to Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) in both BC and AC.

Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) is associated with chronic exposure to less intense sounds for long durations. The Ministry of Labour, Government of India, Factories Act recommends a maximum safe limit of 90 dB for 8 hours a day for 5 days per week.

The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch, at 4 kHz, both for air and bone conduction. It is usually symmetrical on both side

NIHL causes damage to hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells.

NIHL is preventable. Persons who have to work at places where noise is above 85 dB should have pre-employment and then annual audiograms for early detection.

Note: In otosclerosis- bone conduction shows a characteristic notched hearing loss at 2000Hz (Carhart notch) (dip at 2000Hz in BC curve).

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: An autopsy of an elderly male was done after his death due to myocardial infarction. The histopathological examination slide of the cardiac tissue is shown below. What changes does it show?
questions.solution:
The histopathological changes on the slide represent contraction band necrosis, which is typically seen in reperfusion injury following myocardial infarction (MI).

The histopathological findings of contraction band necrosis are nuclear pyknosis, hypereosinophilia, and hypercontraction of sarcomeres, leading to distinct, dense eosinophilic bands. It is seen 12-24 hours after myocardial infarction. It is caused due to high calcium influx during reperfusion, leading to hypercontractility of myocytes and cell lysis.

Other causes of contraction bands are coronary occlusion, resuscitation attempts, drowning, burning, and hypothermia.

Other options:

Option A: Hyaline, amorphous eosinophilic deposits are characteristic of cardiac amyloidosis. These deposits are Congo red-positive under polarized light.

Option C: Lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue is a hallmark of myocarditis. This condition often presents with diffuse inflammatory infiltration, which can lead to myocyte damage.

Option D: Haphazard disarray of myofibrils is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). It is typically accompanied by myocardial fiber hypertrophy and interstitial fibrosis.

questions.text: Which hormone exerts negative feedback on LH secretion during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Estradiol inhibits LH secretion during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle. 

Both estradiol and progesterone inhibit LH secretion. However, Progesterone is low in the follicular phase and primarily important for LH inhibition in the luteal phase. Towards the end of the follicular phase, when estradiol reaches a critical level, it exerts positive feedback on LH and leads to LH surge. 

FSH is inhibited by Inhibin-B and activated by Activin (Option B).

  • Granulosa cells express the FSH receptor.
  • Theca interna cells express LH receptors.

Theca interna cells have many LH receptors. LH acts via cAMP to increase the conversion of cholesterol to androstenedione. The theca interna cells supply androstenedione to the granulosa cells. The granulosa cells make estradiol when provided with androgens.

Granulosa cells have many FSH receptors. FSH facilitates their secretion of estradiol by acting via cAMP to increase their aromatase activity. Mature granulosa cells also acquire LH receptors, and LH also stimulates estradiol production.

Other options:

Option A: Progesterone is low in the follicular phase and is primarily important for inhibiting LH in the luteal phase.

Option B: Activin is a member of the TGF-beta superfamily (like inhibin) and activates FSH.

Option D: AMH plays an important role in inhibiting the initiation of primordial follicle recruitment and suppressing follicular growth. However, it does not directly inhibit LH secretion.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient came with complaints of exertional breathlessness and fatigue for a few months. She gives a history of radiotherapy for carcinoma breast 6 months back. On examination,  bilateral lower limb pitting edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign were present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman presenting post-irradiation with progressive exertional dyspnea, bilateral lower extremity oedema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign is suggestive of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterised by diastolic dysfunction of a non-dilated ventricle with, mildly decreased contractility and ejection fraction.

Most of the cases are due to the infiltration of abnormal substances between myocytes like amyloidosis, abnormal metabolic products within myocytes as seen in hemochromatosis/Fabry's disease, or fibrotic injury like radiation/scleroderma.  

They often present with right-sided heart symptoms like oedema, ascites, and abdominal discomfort. A fourth heart sound is predominately heard than a third heart sound and is often associated with atrial fibrillation. JVP shows rapid y descent and may increase with inspiration.

Kussmaul's sign 

Kussmaul's sign is a paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration. It is an indication of restrictive cardiomyopathy and is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Normally, during inspiration, the JVP falls due to negative intrathoracic pressure. When there is an impairment in the expansion of the right ventricle or a rise in the right atrial pressure, there is a back pressure of blood in the jugular veins. This causes a paradoxical rise in the JVP during inspiration instead of a fall.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy presents with symptoms and signs of left heart failure or biventricular heart failure. Patients show cardiomegaly, and a third heart sound can be auscultated. The most frequent causes are alcoholism, myocarditis, chemotherapy, and endocrinopathies. Echocardiogram shows left ventricular dilation and dysfunction.

Option B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy presents with dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. Examination reveals bisferiens carotid pulse. A fourth heart sound and variable systolic murmur can be auscultated. It is an inherited autosomal disease with variable penetrance. They are caused by mutation of the gene encoding for myosin heavy chains or proteins regulating calcium handling. The echocardiogram is the diagnostic tool. Any area of left ventricle thickness more than 1.5 cm confirms the disease.

Option D: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy presents as acute anterior myocardial infarction, with acute chest pain or shortness of breath. It occurs soon after a high catecholamine surge and is seen predominantly in postmenopausal women.  Cardiac catheterization shows normal coronaries. The LV appears as a round ampulla, resembling the Japanese octopus pot called the takotsubo pot. Imaging reveals apical left ventricular ballooning due to myocardial stunning. 

The image below shows a ventriculogram showing takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles divides the subclavian artery into three parts?
questions.solution:
The scalenus anterior muscle divides the subclavian artery into three parts: the first part (proximal to the anterior scalene), second part (behind the anterior scalene), and the third part (distal to the anterior scalene).

Other options:

Option A: Pectoralis major is a superficial chest muscle involved in movements of the upper limb. It has no direct anatomical relationship with the subclavian artery.

Option B: Pectoralis Minor divides the axillary artery into three parts.

Option D: Scalenus medius is another scalene muscle but does not directly divide the subclavian artery into parts.

questions.text: A mother brings a child who’s diagnosed with Oppositional defiant disorder. All of the following clinical features can be expected in this patient except?

choices.text: Blames others for his own mistakes or behaviour
Physical aggression and destruction of other’s properties
More evident on interacting with known persons than unknown ones

questions.solution:
Aggression towards people and destruction of properties are typically not seen in Oppositional Defiant disorder. It is commonly seen in children with Conduct disorder. 

Oppositional Defiant Disorder involves ongoing negative, disobedient, and hostile behavior toward authority figures, along with blaming others instead of taking responsibility for mistakes.

As per DSM-V, at least 4 of the following symptoms are required for diagnosis:(in at least one setting, commonly at home)

  • Frequently loses temper (option A)
  • Easily annoyed or sensitive.
  • Often angry or resentful.
  • Regularly argues with authority figures.
  • Refuses to comply with requests or rules.
  • Deliberately annoys others.
  • Blames others for mistakes or misbehavior (option B)
  • Displays spitefulness or vindictiveness (at least twice in 6 months).

Moreover, these symptoms are more evident when a child interacts with known persons rather than the unknown(option D).

  Oppositional defiant disorder Conduct disorder
Age of Onset <10years 10-18years
Primary Behaviors Defiance, argumentativeness, irritability, temper tantrums, spitefulness, and blame-shifting. Aggression, destruction of property, deceitfulness, theft, and serious rule violations
Aggression Typically verbal, physical aggression is rare. Frequent physical aggression toward people or animals.
Impact on Relationships Problems with authority figures (e.g., teachers, parents) but may maintain friendships. Difficulty maintaining friendships; often leads to social isolation.
Legal Involvement Rarely results in legal issues. Often involves legal problems due to rule-breaking and criminal acts.

questions.text:
Match the condition with the anatomic structure affected:
Column A Column B
1. Boxer's elbow A. Olecranon process
2. Little leaguer's elbow B. Medial epicondyle
3. Nursemaid's elbow C. Olecranon bursa
4. Student's elbow D. Radial head
questions.solution:
The correct match is Option B 

1. Boxer's elbow A. Olecranon Process
2. Little leaguer's elbow B. Medial epicondyle
3. Nursemaid's elbow D. Radial head
4. Student's elbow C. Olecranon bursa

Boxer's elbow occurs in boxers due to repetitive valgus hyperextension while jabbing. As a result, there is impingement of olecranon, hence it is also known as olecranon impingement syndrome or hyperextension overload syndrome.

Little leaguer's elbow occurs when there is an avulsion fracture of the medial epicondyle. It is more commonly seen in throwing sports playing children and adolescents. 

Student’s elbow (Olecranon bursitis/ Miner's elbow / Draughtsman elbow) involves the olecranon bursa. It occurs most commonly because of trauma, sepsis, and inflammatory arthritis.

 Nursemaid’s Elbow (Radial head subluxation) involves the displacement of the radial head. It occurs when axial traction on a pronated forearm with the elbow in extension. This causes the annular ligament to slip over the radial head and gets trapped in the radiohumeral joint.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with sudden-onset loose stools, vomiting, and muscular cramps. Stools were colorless, like rice water, and had an inoffensive sweetish odor. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent.

TCBS - Thiosulfate citrate bile salt sucrose

choices.text: Cary-Blair medium is used as a transport media
The toxin acts on GM2 ganglioside receptor
The organism has a polar flagellum

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of sudden onset colorless rice watery, stools having an inoffensive sweetish odor is indicative of cholera and the causative agent is Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells, not GM2 receptors.

They are gram-negative and typically comma-shaped. They show darting motility with a single-sheathed polar flagellum. They are facultative anaerobes and produce large yellow convex colonies on the thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose (TCBS) medium.

Following are the special media used for V. cholera:

1. Holding or transporting media:

  • Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
  • Cary-Blair medium- It is a suitable transport medium for vibrios, Salmonella, and Shigella.
  • Autoclaved seawater

2. Enrichment media like Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water 

3. Plating media

  • Alkaline bile salt agar
  • Monsur's gelatin taurocholate trypticase tellurite agar (GTTA)
  • Thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose agar (colonies shown in the image below)

Vibrio colonies may be identified by the 'string test,' where a loopful of the growth is mixed with a drop of 0.5% sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. The suspension loses its turbidity, becomes mucoid, and forms a 'string' when the loop is drawn away slowly in a positive test.

Vibrios multiply in the intestinal epithelium and produce an enterotoxin called cholera toxin (CT), which is very similar to the heat-labile toxin (LT) of Escherichia coli, although CT is far more potent than LT in biological activity. The toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to the outpouring of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the small intestinal lumen and the consequent watery diarrhea.

questions.text: After delivering a baby, you notice the surgeon following the WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labour (AMTSL). Which of the following is considered the most important component?
questions.solution:
According to the AMTSL guidelines of WHO, the most important AMTSL component is the administration of a prophylactic uterotonic, preferably oxytocin.

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic preferably Oxytocin. Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV. Other injectable uterotonics and misoprostol are recommended as alternatives for the prevention of PPH in settings where oxytocin is unavailable.
  • Delayed cord clamping for at least 1-3 minutes. This reduces the rates of anaemia in infants.
  • Controlled cord traction by modified Brandt Andrews technique during placental delivery (in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women and is done every 15 mins for 2 hours.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor in decreasing PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, controlled cord traction is not as critical. But note that all 3 are still essential, and AMTSL includes them. 

Continuous uterine massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in women who have received prophylactic oxytocin

questions.text: In the labor room, you witness the resident applying dinoprostone gel intracervically to a 38-week primigravida who is not in labor. Which of the following is an indication for this procedure?

  • Hygroscopic cervical dilators

Pharmacological induction of labor:

  • Prostaglandin E2- Dinoprostone gel 0.5mg or dinoprostone insert 10mg
  • Prostaglandin E1- Misoprostol 25mcg vaginally or 50-100mcg orally
  • Oxytocin- 10-20 units in 1000ml ringer lactate

Other options:

questions.text: Which of the following venous plexus is situated inferior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate?

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with coarse facial features and enlarging hands and feet. His height is above 2 standard deviations for his age. He also complains of headaches and visual problems. The parents complain about behavioural problems. There is an elevated level IGF-1 level for age and no suppression of GH  in a glucose tolerance test. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests the cause to be pituitary gigantism. It is caused by the overproduction of growth hormone.  It is seen in younger age groups before the closure of epiphysis.

It is a rare condition, caused mostly by pituitary adenoma

Clinical features include-

  • Longitudinal growth acceleration secondary to GH excess.
  • Coarse facial features
  • Enlarging hands and feet
  • Rapid growth of the head can precede linear growth
  • Behavioral problems
  • Visual problems.
  • Delayed puberty.
  • Local effects- headache, visual field defects, and other hormone deficiencies.
  • Some cases also show acromegalic features.

GH levels are elevated. There is no normal suppression of GH levels induced by a glucose tolerance test. There are elevated levels of IGF-1 and IGFBP-3. MRI and CT imaging will show a pituitary adenoma.

The treatment options are surgical removal of well-circumscribed masses trans-sphenoidally or trans-cranially. Radiation and medical therapy may be required in some cases.

Medical Therapy-

  • Somatostatin analogues like octreotide and lanreotide suppress GH levels.
  • Bromocriptine and cabergoline can be when there is concomitant prolactin oversecretion. 
  • Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist that causes effective suppression of IGF and GH levels.

Other options:

Option A: Overproduction of GH results in acromegaly which is seen in young adults after the closure of epiphyses. 

Option B: McCune–Albright syndrome is a classical cause of peripheral precocious puberty caused by a mutation of the GNAS1 gene. It affects the bones, skin, and several endocrine tissues.

Cardinal features:

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Cafe au lait macules
  • Endocrine abnormalities: hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomous ovarian hyperfunction, leading to precocious puberty
  • Predominantly affects girls

Note: Precocious puberty in boys is the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of nine years. 

Option C: Cushing syndrome results from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It presents with weight gain, central obesity, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Other clinical features include thin, brittle skin with easy bruisability, purple stretch marks, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and osteopenia.

questions.text: The image below shows a change observed in episcleritis on the administration of a substance ‘X’. What is the substance ‘X’ used here?
questions.solution:
The image shows that episcleritis gets blanched due to the involvement of superficial episcleral vessels with Phenylephrine.

2.5% phenylephrine can be used to differentiate episcleritis and scleritis. Since the vessels of the episclera are superficial, they blanch. Whereas in scleritis, the vessels do not blanch. 

Episcleritis is benign, recurrent inflammation of the episclera involving the overlying Tenon's capsule but not the underlying sclera. It is more common in women than in men. It is an allergic reaction to an endogenous toxin. Clinically, two types of presentations may occur:

  • Simple episcleritis is characterised by sectorial or diffuse inflammation of the episclera.
  • Nodular episcleritis is characterised by a pink or purple flat nodule surrounded by injection, usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus. The nodule is firm and tender and can be moved separately from the sclera, and the overlying conjunctiva also moves freely.

Management of episcleritis typically includes topical NSAIDs, corticosteroid eye drops, cold compresses, and artificial tears. For recurrent cases, systemic NSAIDs may be required.  

Atropine (option B), an anticholinergic agent, is used for pupil dilation but does not cause blanching of the vessels. Pilocarpine (option C), a cholinergic agent used to constrict the pupil, is often used to treat glaucoma. Tropicamide(option D) is a muscarinic antagonist used for pupil dilation.

questions.text: Which of the following structures do not lie in the same compartment of supraorbital fissure as the nerve blocked in the technique shown below?
questions.solution:
The frontal nerve does not lie in the same compartment of the image's nerve block, i.e., the infratrochlear nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve.

The nasociliary nerve passes through the intermediate compartment (within the tendinous ring) of the superior orbital fissure. Other structures that pass through the same compartment include Both divisions of the oculomotor nerve and Abducens nerve. 

The superior orbital fissure is an important anatomical opening in the skull that allows several critical structures to pass through. Among these structures, the frontal nerve and nasociliary nerve are branches of the ophthalmic nerve, the first division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1), which is responsible for sensory innervation to parts of the face. The frontal nerve provides sensation to the forehead, the anterior scalp, and the dorsum of the nose, while the nasociliary nerve supplies sensation to parts of the nasal cavity.

The superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring:

Compartments Contents
Superolateral compartments Lacrimal, frontal, and trochlear nerve (LFT), Superior ophthalmic vein
Intermediate compartment Superior and inferior division of oculomotor, Nasociliary nerve, Abducens nerve
Inferomedial compartment Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text:
With respect to tuberculosis of the hip, arrange the following deformities in order of occurrence:

1) Dislocation of the femoral head 
2) Destruction of articular cartilage 
3) Synovial hypertrophy 
4) Apparent shortening
questions.solution:
The correct order of deformities occurring in tuberculosis of the hip is synovial hypertrophy > apparent shortening of the affected limb > destruction of articular cartilage > dislocation of the femoral head.

Tuberculosis of the hip occurs in three main stages based on the clinical manifestations: 

Stages Key findings Position of the affected limb Length of the affected limb
Stage 1
(Stage of synovitis)

There is effusion in the joint.

Patient usually does not present in this early stage

 Flexion, abduction, external rotation Apparent lengthening as the pelvis tilts downwards to compensate for the abduction

Stage 2
(Stage of arthritis)

Spasm of the powerful muscles around the hip.

 

 Flexion, adduction, internal rotation Apparent shortening as the pelvis tilts upwards to compensate for the adduction
Stage 3
(Stage of erosion)

Articular cartilage is destroyed

Acetabulum is eroded

Pathological dislocation/ subluxation of the hip  

 Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (exaggerated deformities) True shortening as there is actual destruction of the bone 

Some important radiological signs occurring in established cases of TB of the hip:

  • Haziness: earliest radiological sign
  • Lytic lesion
  • Reduction of joint space and irregular outline of articular ends: because of the destruction of cartilage
  • Wandering acetabulum: head may be lying out of the acetabulum
  • Pestle and mortar appearance: sometimes, the acetabulum gets enlarged and deepened with the deformed head shifted medially.
  • Sclerosis around the hip: seen if the disease is in the healing stage

questions.text: During your rural posting, a 24-year-old male patient came to you to know about the dietary modification for the prevention of coronary heart disease. According to WHO standards, the dietary goal of saturated fatty acid for an adult male should not be more than:
questions.solution:
According to WHO standards, the dietary goal of saturated fatty acid for an adult male should not be more than 10%.

Dietary modification in the prevention of CHD:

  • Reduction of the fat intake to 15–30% of total energy intake
  • Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake
  • Increase in complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetable fruits, whole grains, and legumes)
  • Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5gm daily or less

questions.text: A 7-year-old child has a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents typically with fixed wide split S2, a classic finding of the atrial septal defect (ASD), a type of acyanotic congenital heart disease.

ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration. This leads to a fixed wide split S2.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations.

A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard. Echocardiography will show characteristic right ventricular volume overload, including an increased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and flattening and abnormal motion of the ventricular septum.

Other options:

Option A: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is typically associated with a pan-systolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is typically associated with a harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border (pulmonic area) with a single 2nd heart sound (S2)

Option D: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is characteristically associated with a machinery murmur.

questions.text: Which of the following maneuvers given below is not used to deliver the baby with the presentation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The presentation depicted in the image is a complete breech, and McRoberts maneuver is not used in breech delivery, but is used in the management of shoulder dystocia.

Lovset's maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation. Modified Prague’s maneuver is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head. Burns-Marshall method is also used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Frank breech: Breech with flexion at hip joints, extension at knee joints.
  • Complete breech: Breech with flexion at both hip joints, one or both knees at flexed.
  • Incomplete breech: Breech with extension at one or both hips, as a result, one or both feet or knees lie below the breech. Footling is a type of incomplete breech with one or both feet below the breech.

The maneuver shown in the image is Lovset's maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

Modified Prague’s maneuver is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

The image depicts the McRoberts maneuver used in the management of shoulder dystocia.

McRoberts maneuver consists of forceful abduction and flexion of maternal hips and positioning the maternal thighs on to the abdomen. Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.

It is used to free the impacted anterior shoulder through the following:

  • Straightening of the sacrum relative to lumbar vertebrae.
  • Rotation of symphysis pubis towards the maternal head.
  • A decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text:
Which of the following has a low US:LS ratio?

US: LS Ratio - Upper Segment: Lower Segment Ratio
questions.solution:
Marfan syndrome has a low US: LS ratio.

The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height.

The U/L ratio is

  • 1.7 at birth
  • 1.3 at 3 years
  • 1 after 7 years
  • 0.9 in adults

  • Marfan syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following insulins cannot be mixed with other types of insulin?
questions.solution:
Among the following, the insulin that cannot be mixed with other types of insulin is Glargine.

Glargine insulin is a long-acting insulin that cannot be combined with other types of insulin. It is soluble at a pH of 4.0 but precipitates at neutral pH after it is injected subcutaneously. Due to this property, Glargine Insulin cannot be mixed along with any other type of insulin.

Rapid-acting insulins (like Lispro, Aspart) and short-acting insulin (Regular) can typically be mixed with intermediate-acting insulin (like NPH).

Multiple daily injection regimen (MDI) consists of multiple injections per day. This usually includes an injection of long-acting insulin and an injection of rapid-acting insulin before each meal. A continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion regimen (CSII) infuses insulin at selected basal rates through an electromechanical pump.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient comes to the clinic for evaluation of constant dribbling of urine. Upon performing the following test, the swab labeled "B" is stained blue. Which of the following procedure is not done to repair this defect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of the vesicovaginal fistula(VVF) which is diagnosed using a methylene blue 3 swab test in which the middle swab is stained with methylene blue. McDonald's procedure is not done to repair VVF. It is done for cervical cerclage during pregnancy. 

Methylene blue - 3 swab test: Here, methylene blue is injected into the bladder via the catheter, and three sterile swabs are placed into the vaginal cavity.  

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

Latzko's procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges, freshening the edges, and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix. It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia.

Chassar Moir technique widely separated the vagina and bladder all around by the flap-splitting method and suturing the bladder and vagina separately into two. It has the advantage of tension-free sutures and avoidance of the superior position of the bladder over the vaginal suture. 

Ureteric implantation is considered in cases with extensive loss of bladder tissue, or repetitive failures to close the fistula. Here ureters are implanted into the sigmoid colon creating an ileal loop bladder, or rectal bladder. The disadvantage of this procedure is the high incidence of ascending infection to the kidneys and the risk of electrolyte imbalance.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

questions.text: A young woman presenting with persistent ear discharge, deep-seated ear pain, and diplopia is suspected to have apical petrositis. Which of the following X-ray views is preferred to evaluate this patient?
questions.solution:
Towne's view is preferred to evaluate this patient with apical petrositis.

Towne's view is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck. The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hairline.

  • This is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
  • Bilateral petrous pyramids are visible in this view and hence can be compared.
Structures seen are:
  • Arcuate eminence and superior semicircular canal.
  • Mastoid antrum.
  • Internal auditory canal.
  • Tympanic cavity.
  • Cochlea.
  • External auditory canal.

The image below shows Towne's view 

Patients with petrositis may present with Gradenigo syndrome. Gradenigo syndrome is a triad with the following symptoms:

  • Diplopia or double vision due to cranial nerve VI  palsy
  • Facial pain or deep-seated ear pain due to cranial nerve V involvement
  • Persistent ear discharge due to otitis media

The patient may also have a fever, headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity. The involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves results in facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo respectively.

Diagnosis of petrositis is done by a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of the temporal bone shows bony details of the air cells and petrous apex. MRI helps to detect the presence of fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Other options:

Caldwell's view (also known as the occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 15° to the orbito-meatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

 

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 37° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Submentovertical view/ Hirtz view/ basal view is taken with vertex near the film and X-ray beam projected at right angles to the film from the submental area. It is commonly used to get a better view of sphenoid sinuses.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: A middle-aged man who previously presented with foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting was diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis. He now presents with a woody hard nasal swelling and multiple granulomatous nodules in the nasal mucosa. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma, as the patient had a history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting before the development of a woody hard nasal swelling and multiple granulomatous nodules in the nasal mucosa, which corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by biopsy showing two characteristic findings- Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies. 

Mikulicz cells (small arrow) are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. They occur due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells.

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages:

  • Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.
  • Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.
  • Cicatricial stage– Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called tapir nose.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass. The biopsy shows several oval or round-shaped sporangia filled with spores bursting through the chitinous walls.

Option B: Wegener's granulomatosis is a chronic granulomatous disorder presenting with crusting, granulation and saddle nose deformity. Biopsy shows necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma and necrotizing vasculitis of the vessels.

Option C: Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis involving the skin and mucosa. It presents with ulcerated nodules or plaques and a characteristic apple-jelly appearance on diascopy, not woody nasal swelling or granulomas.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the hospital in a semi-conscious state. He is sweating profusely, has muscle weakness, breathlessness with an audible wheeze, and constricted pupils. On further evaluation, he is diagnosed with carbaryl poisoning. Which of the following should not be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Pralidoxime should not be used for the treatment of carbaryl poisoning.

Oximes like pralidoxime are used to restore neuromuscular transmission in organophosphate anti­ChE poisoning. It attaches to the anionic site of the cholinesterase enzyme, which remains unoccupied in the presence of organophosphates. It binds and forms oxime-phosphonate which diffuses away, leaving the reactivated cholinesterase.

Pralidoxime is not an effective anti­dote to carbamates like carbaryl. This is because the anionic site of the cholinesterase enzyme is not free for attachment to pralidoxime. Hence, it does not reactivate the carbamylated enzyme. Carbamates spontaneously disassociate from AChE and recover in 24-48 hours.

Pralidoxime may potentiate the toxicity of carbaryl. Therefore, pralidoxime should be avoided in known single-agent carbaryl poisonings. However, pralidoxime is considered for use in mixed poisonings with an organophosphorus compound and a carbamate.   

Other options:

Option B: Atropine is the mainstay in the management of carbamate poisoning. It is the antidote of choice, given for muscarinic symptoms. Atropine is usually sufficient till the carbamylated acetylcholinesterase complex dissociates spontaneously and recovers function. This occurs usually within 24 hours.

Option C: Diazepam may be used for the management of seizures in carbaryl poisoning.

Option D: Activated charcoal can be used to perform gastric lavage in oral carbamate poisoning.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the hospital by his wife. She complains that under stressful situations the patient's behaviour completely changes. He believes that he is a 7-year-old boy named "babu" and behaves like a child. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dissociative identity disorder is characterised by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states that assume control of an individual's behavior. It was previously called multiple personality disorder.

The disorder usually begins in childhood, in those who experience overwhelming circumstances, such as physical or sexual abuse.

Patients with dissociative identity disorder initially present with symptoms of emotional and behavioural turmoil. Some patients may have memory gaps and incidents of out-of-character behaviour. The symptoms are characterised by different "alters" or alternate identities, controlling the patient's behaviour for varying lengths of time. The identities of the patient may switch under stressful situations, disputes among alters, and other psychological conflicts.

DSM-5 classification of dissociative disorders includes the following:

  • Dissociative identity disorder (multiple identity disorder)
  • Dissociative amnesia
  • Depersonalisation/derealisation disorder
  • Other specified dissociative disorders include dissociative trance, dissociative reactions to stressful events Etc.
  • Unspecified dissociative disorder

Other options:

Depersonalisation/derealisation disorder (Option A and C): It is characterised by

  • Depersonalization: Experiences of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer of his/her own thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions.
  • Derealization: Experiences of unreality or detachment with respect to surroundings, where the surrounding individuals or objects are experienced as unreal, dream-like, or foggy.

Dissociative amnesia (Option D): It is characterised by the inability to recall important autobiographical information, which is usually of a traumatic or stressful nature. The information that the patient forgets is too extensive and cannot be forgotten under ordinary circumstances. Some might forget significant personal information or even his/her own name. Although in dissociative identity disorder, there may be memory gaps, the key feature is that the patients switch between two or more identities, while in dissociative amnesia, the patient forgets his/her own identity.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions can thiazide diuretics be safely used?
questions.solution:
Thiazide diuretics can be safely used in calcium oxalate kidney stones as they reduce urinary Ca2+ excretion.

Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter in the DCT. The intracytoplasmic Na+ concentration decreases due to the blockade of the co-transporter. To compensate, the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger pumps sodium from the systemic circulation into the epithelial cells in exchange for calcium. The declining calcium levels inside the cell will draw more calcium from the lumen into the systemic circulation. This results in hypercalcemia and reduces urinary Ca2+ excretion. There is also increased loss of Mg2+, K+, and H+.

The diuretic effect of thiazide leads to decreased osmotic pressure due to the loss of Na+, Cl-, and water leading to compensatory reabsorption of uric acid thus resulting in hyperuricemia. Hence it cannot be used in conditions with already increased uric acid levels such as gout, Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, and tumor lysis syndrome.

Thiazide diuretics can thus cause hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, and hypercalcemia as adverse effects as it increases Na+ and K+ excretion and decreases Ca2+ excretion. 

Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension. Other indications for use include treatment of edema associated with diseases of the heart, liver, and kidney, Ca2+ nephrolithiasis, and osteoporosis. Thiazides are the mainstay for the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑
Loop diuretics ↑↑ ↑↑ ↑↑
Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

questions.text: A 3-day-old infant is brought with a rash. On examination, chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions are noted, with no cardiovascular abnormality. CT head shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this infant with periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly is congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

CMV is the most common congenital infection. The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Diagnosis can be made by the presence of IgM antibodies in the fetal blood. Isolation of the virus from the urine or blood by PCR is more sensitive.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness. Below is the image showing the blueberry muffin baby.

Other options:

Option A- Congenital rubella syndrome is due to the rubella virus. The classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome is deafness, cataract and congenital heart disease. Patent ductus arteriosus is a common cardiac defect. Eye findings also include salt and pepper retinopathy as shown below.

Option B- Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. Early features include hepato-splenomegaly, jaundice, diffuse lymphadenopathy, maculopapular or vesiculobullous rash involving hands and feet, persistent rhinitis (snuffles), and condylomatous lesions. 

Skeletal changes like saber shins, dental abnormalities like Hutchinson's teeth, and saddle nose - depression of the nasal root are some late findings.

Option C- Congenital toxoplasmosis is due to Toxoplasma gondii. A classic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications is seen. Blueberry muffin baby appearance is also seen in this. Calcifications occur randomly throughout the brain in congenital toxoplasmosis while periventricular calcification is characteristic of congenital CMV infection.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old female patient has hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and gastrinoma with cutaneous angiofibromas. What is the likely diagnosis?

MEN - Multiple endocrine neoplasia
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of MEN 1 syndrome.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes are characterized by tumors of two or more endocrine glands. There are four major types of MEN (MEN 1–4), and they either show an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance or occur sporadically. 

MEN 1, also known as Wermer’s syndrome, is characterized by the triad of parathyroid, pancreatic islet cell, and anterior pituitary tumors. Adrenal cortical tumors, carcinoid tumors, facial angiofibromas, collagenomas, thyroid tumors, and lipomas may also occur. MEN 1-associated tumors are usually multiple, larger, and more aggressive, resulting in resistance to treatment and poor patient outcomes.

  1. Parathyroid tumors- primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common feature of MEN 1. Hypercalcemia with or without symptoms (polyuria, polydipsia, constipation, dyspepsia), nephrolithiasis, and osteitis fibrosa cystica may also occur. All four parathyroid glands are usually affected with multiple adenomas or hyperplasia. 
  2. Pancreatic islet cell tumors- these are neuroendocrine tumors, including:
    • Gastrinoma (gastrin-secreting tumors)- associated with increased gastric acid secretion and multiple peptic ulcers (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). Patients may present with diarrhea and steatorrhea. Gastrinomas are the major cause of mortality and morbidity. 
    • Insulinoma (insulin-secreting tumors)- patients present with hypoglycemic symptoms (weakness, headaches, sweating, seizures, weight gain) that develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake. Along with increased plasma insulin levels and hypoglycemia, increased C peptide and proinsulin levels help in diagnosing the condition.
    • Glucagonoma (glucagon-secreting tumors)- may be associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, anemia, and stomatitis. 
    • VIPomas (Vasoactive intestinal peptide [VIP]-secreting tumors): The VIPoma syndrome, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. These are mostly located in the tail of the pancreas.
    • PPomas (Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting tumors) and nonfunctioning pancreatic tumors- are associated with a worse prognosis as they often go undiagnosed due to the absence of both clinical features and biochemical abnormalities.
  3. Pituitary tumors- manifestations depend on the hormone secreted (symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, or Cushing’s disease) and tumor size (visual disturbances or hypopituitarism due to compression of the optic chiasm or normal pituitary tissue). 

Surgical excision of the nonmetastatic tumor after localization is the curative treatment. Appropriate medical therapy can be used for some tumors when surgery is contraindicated or unsuccessful (calcimemetics for parathyroid tumors, parietal cell H+-K+-ATPase inhibitors for gastrinomas). In case of metastasis, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, radiation therapy, and artery embolization may be successful.

MEN 1 occurs due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene located on chromosome 11q13. Mutational genetic analysis is necessary to confirm the clinical diagnosis and identify family members who harbor the mutation and require screening for tumor detection and early treatment.

Other options:

Options B and C: MEN 2, also called Sipple’s syndrome, is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumors. This occurs due to mutations of the rearranged during transfection (RET) protooncogene. There are three clinical variants -

  1. MEN 2A (most common): MTC is associated with pheochromocytomas in 50% of patients and parathyroid tumors in 20% of patients. MEN 2A may also be associated with Hirschsprung’s disease and cutaneous lichen amyloidosis.
  2. MEN 2B (MEN 3): MTC is associated with pheochromocytoma, along with Marfanoid habitus; mucosal neuromas of the lips, tongue, and eyelids; medullated corneal fibers; and intestinal autonomic ganglion dysfunction leading to multiple diverticulae and megacolon. Parathyroid tumors are usually absent.
  3. MTC only (FMTC): MTC is the only manifestation.

Option D: MEN 4 is characterized by a combination of MEN 1–associated tumors and CDKN1B mutation-related tumors (gonadal, adrenal, renal, and thyroid tumors).

questions.text:
After completing your MBBS you voluntarily enrol yourself into a scheme aimed at providing free and safe motherhood services. You are instructed to display the scheme's logo outside your clinic. Your respective DMO provides you with all the necessary medications required to run this scheme. Which is the scheme being referred to in the above scenario?

 DMO- District Medical Officer
questions.solution:
Vande Mataram scheme is a voluntary scheme for providing safe motherhood services.

  • Can be volunteered by an OBG specialist, lady doctor/ MBBS doctor, maternity home or nursing home.
  • The enrolled doctors are instructed to display the 'Vandemataram logo' at their clinic.
  • IFA tablets, OC pills, and TT injections will be provided by the respective DMO to the Vandematharam doctors/ clinics for free distribution to beneficiaries.
  • Cases needing special care and treatment can be referred to government hospitals.

Vande Mataram scheme is expected to improve the access of pregnant women to antenatal check-up and reduce maternal and neonatal deaths.

11th of April is being observed as the National Safe Motherhood Day.

Other options:

Option B: The Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) is a scheme for adolescent girls under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) which targets adolescent girls in the age group of 11 to 18 years and addresses their needs of self-development, nutrition and health status, literacy and numerical skills, vocational skills, etc.

Option C: Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK) launched under the National Health Mission ensures holistic development of the adolescent population (10-19 years)

Option D: The Ujjawala Scheme is for the prevention of trafficking and for the rescue, rehabilitation, and reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who works as a sheep herder presents with complaints of fever, cough, and haemoptysis. His chest X-ray reveals mediastinal widening. After examination and investigations, the physician diagnoses pulmonary anthrax and advises his wife to take prophylactic antibiotics for the same. What is the mechanism of action of the drug approved for post-exposure prophylaxis of this condition?

choices.text: Acts on 50s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Acts on transpeptidase and inhibits cell wall synthesis

questions.solution:
Post-exposure prophylaxis for pulmonary anthrax typically involves ciprofloxacin or doxycycline, which are the primary drugs recommended for prevention after exposure. The mechanism of action of ciprofloxacin (and other fluoroquinolones) is to inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, enzymes that are crucial for DNA replication in bacteria. 

Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, inhibits bacterial DNA replication and prevents the growth of bacteria that could otherwise lead to severe infection. DNA gyrase is particularly important in gram-negative bacteria, where it introduces negative supercoils into the DNA to relieve torsional strain. Ciprofloxacin binds to and inhibits this enzyme, preventing the proper replication of bacterial DNA. Additionally, topoisomerase IV is the target of gram-positive bacteria, and its inhibition by ciprofloxacin prevents chromosome segregation during cell division. 

Tetracyclines, such as doxycycline, inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S bacterial ribosome and preventing aminoacyl tRNA from accessing the acceptor (A) site on the mRNA-ribosome complex.

The post-exposure prophylaxis after potential exposure includes ciprofloxacin or doxycycline for 60 days.

Inhalational/ pulmonary anthrax is a life-threatening bacterial infection caused by Bacillus anthracis spores. It is commonly spread from sheep wool and is hence also called Wool Sorter’s disease. Anthrax is a bioterrorism category A agent and a potential tool in biological warfare. Doxycycline is used for the treatment of anthrax and is used in combination with another agent when treating inhalational or GI infections.

questions.text: A gardener living with his cats presents with fever, linear pustular lesions of 2 cm in the distal forearm, and axillary lymphadenopathy for 2 weeks. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
The causative organism of cat scratch disease is Bartonella henselae.

This patient with a linear pustular lesion at the site of a cat's scratch and regional lymphadenopathy has cat scratch disease. The reservoir for B. henselae is cat, which infects humans through contact with skin lesions. It is usually self-limited and treated symptomatically with analgesics and drainage of excessively large lymph nodes. Azithromycin helps shorten the recovery period and lymph node swelling. 

It is also associated with bacillary angiomatosis, which are vascular tumors that appear as red papules on the skin, mucosa, and other locations, which resemble Kaposi sarcoma and bacillary peliosis involving the liver and spleen.

A biopsy of the affected lymph node will show the presence of rounded or stellate granuloma as shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option A: Streptobacillus moniliformis causes rat-bite fever characterized by septic fever, blotchy and petechial rashes, and very painful polyarthritis.

Option C: Francisella Tularensis is spread through infected rodents such as rabbits or through ticks. It causes ulceration at the site of inoculation and regional lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Sporothrix schenckii causes ulceration and necrotic nodules following inoculation by trauma or thorn prick. It also has a lymphocutaneous form with the spread of lesions along the lymphatics till the lymph node where all lesions are ulcerated.

questions.text: A sailor is on his regular cruise journey. 2 weeks later, he develops a high fever, cough with headache. He also reports 2-3 episodes of diarrhoea. He is brought to a nearby hospital, and his chest x-ray is given below. He is diagnosed as a case of Legionnaire's disease. Which of the following is not true about the causative organism for his pneumonia?

choices.text: It causes community acquired and ventilator associated pneumonia
Macrolides and Fluoroquinolones are antibiotics of choice
Infection occurs from air conditioners aerosols
Human to human transmission is seen

questions.solution:
Legionnaire's disease is caused by Legionella pneumophila. Human-to-human transmission is not usually seen in this condition. 

Legionnaire's disease is the cause of community-acquired pneumonia and ventilator-associated pneumonia (Option A). The most common serotype of Legionnaire's disease is serotype 1. It should always be considered in patients with signs of pneumonia and diarrhea, in combination with possible exposure (e.g., cruise ship travel).

Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners (Option C), humidifiers, nebulizers, etc. So, it causes ventilator-associated pneumonia (Option A). It produces severe disease in immunocompromised and ventilator-dependent patients. It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhea, and delirium. 

On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. Hyponatremia is a feature typical to this infection leading to confusion. 

Macrolides and quinolones are the antibiotics of choice (Option B) in the management of Legionnaires disease.

questions.text: A worker from the shipbuilding industry has developed difficulty in breathing. He has been working there for the past 12 years. Pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern with a decrease in lung volumes and diffusing capacity. A chest X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of breathlessness with the pulmonary function test revealing the restrictive pattern of the disease and the X-ray showing a holly-leaf appearance is suggestive of asbestosis.

Asbestosis is an occupational disease and is characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis of the lung that is related to the intensity and duration of exposure to asbestos. It is seen in people who work in the shipbuilding, processing, construction, and mining industries. At least 10 years of exposure to asbestosis is needed to develop the disease. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Radiologically it presents as pleural plaques, irregular or linear opacities, and ground-glass appearance particularly present at the lower lung fields. HRCT will show the presence of pleural plaque, subpleural curvilinear lines 5–10 mm in length that appears to be parallel to the pleura. Asbestosis increases the risk of development of mesothelioma.

Other options

Option A- Silicosis is an occupational disease and is caused by exposure to silica. It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying. It presents as small rounded opacities in the upper lobe. There may be calcification of hilar lymph nodes which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern.

The below image shows the crazy-paving pattern in silicosis.

 

Option B- Chronic berylliosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to beryllium. It is seen in people who work on processing alloys for high-tech industries. Chest radiography shows nodules along the septal lines.

Option D- Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP) is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to coal dust. It is seen in people working in mines. It presents as small opacities in the upper lobe of the lungs. Complicated CWP has nodules ≥1 cm in diameter generally confined to the upper half of the lungs.

questions.text: A skin biopsy is shown below. Which of the following diseases is unlikely to have the finding seen in the slide?
questions.solution:
This slide shows acantholysis, which occurs when there is a breakdown of intracellular connections. Out of the given options, Bullous pemphigoid is the only condition that does not have acantholysis. 

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, leading to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. This results in the formation of intraepidermal clefts, vesicles, and bullae.

Acantholysis may be classified as:

Primary acantholysis: Due to direct injury to or defects seen in desmosomes, separation of keratinocytes occurs, resulting in circular acantholytic cells. Acantholysis is the primary event causing intraepidermal cavities. It is seen in conditions such as:

  • Pemphigus and its variants
  • Acantholytic dermatosis
  • Darier's disease
  • Hailey Hailey disease
  • Warty dyskeratoma


Secondary acantholysis: Due to the damage or alteration to the keratinocytes, leading to the dissolution of desmosomes. This results in acantholysis that is seen in:

  • Viral disorders like herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2), varicella zoster infections (chicken pox and shingles)
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Solar keratoses

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is found to have metastatic bone tumors. The orthopedician uses Mirel’s scoring to assess the risk of pathological fractures in this patient. Which of the following is not a component of the scoring system?
questions.solution:
The age of the patient is not a component of Mirel’s scoring system. 

The Mirel’s scoring system assesses the risk of pathological fractures in patients with metastatic bone lesions. The system evaluates four variables, with a score ranging from 1 to 3 for each of the following: 

Variable Score
1 2 3
Site of the lesion  Upper limb     Lower limb   Peritrochanteric
Pain  Mild   Moderate  Severe
Size (Cortical destruction) <1/3  1/3–2/3 >2/3 
Type of the lesion Blastic Mixed  Lytic

A total score of 8 or higher indicates a high fracture risk, suggesting that prophylactic internal fixation is typically recommended before radiotherapy.

Metastatic tumors are the most common bone tumors. Typically, metastases from the prostate are osteoblastic, while renal and thyroid lesions are osteolytic. Lung and breast metastases produce mixed blastic-lytic lesions. Bone scintigraphy and whole-body MRI are used to identify metastatic disease throughout the body. 

Note: Here, size indicates the maximum degree of cortical destruction as defined by the overall width of the bone (on plain XRay, any view).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is undergoing semen analysis as part of an infertility workup. According to the WHO (2022) criteria for normal semen analysis, what is the lower reference limit for sperm agglutination?
questions.solution:
The WHO (2022) criteria specify that the lower reference limit for sperm agglutination is <2 (meaning that fewer than 2% of sperm should exhibit agglutination for a normal result).

Sperm agglutination refers to the clumping or sticking together of sperm cells, which may occur due to the presence of anti-sperm antibodies or other factors in the seminal fluid. This can affect the sperm's ability to move freely and potentially impair fertility by hindering sperm motility.

The lower reference limits for the key parameters in semen analysis according to WHO (2022) criteria:

Volume of semen 1.4 mL
Sperm concentration 16 million sperms per milliliter
Total sperm number per ejaculate 39 million per ejaculate
Total motility 42%
Progressive forward motility 30%
Vitality 54%
Normal morphology 4%
Sperm agglutination <2

 

Semen is typically collected in a sterile cup after the male has refrained from ejaculating for 3-4 days. The sample should be processed within an hour, and it undergoes liquefaction, which takes about 15-20 minutes. If the initial analysis yields abnormal results, a second sample is typically taken after a month for further evaluation.

Some common sperm-related disorders include:

  • Aspermia: No semen is produced.
  • Azoospermia: No sperm present in the semen.
  • Oligospermia: Low sperm count (less than 15 million sperm per milliliter).
  • Asthenospermia: Reduced sperm motility.
  • Teratospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology.

questions.text: Which of the following can lead to the abnormality given in the below image?

choices.text: Chorionic plate larger than basal plate
Chorionic plate smaller than basal plate

questions.solution:
The given image shows the circumvallate placenta. It is a type of extrachorial placentation and is caused when the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate.

Extrachorial placentation: The chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation - circummarginate and circumvallate placenta.

In the Circummarginate placenta, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage with a smooth margin.

In the Circumvallate placenta, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

Complications associated with Circumvallate placenta:

  • Preterm delivery
  • Abortions
  • Growth retardation
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Retained placenta
  • Hydrorrhea gravidarum

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Histopathology showed the following appearance. Which of the following is true about this tumour?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Mutation in CDH-1 gene is associated with lobular carcinoma.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic with liver disease came to the hospital with complaints of distension of the abdomen. On per abdominal examination, shifting dullness was positive. Which of the following is the diuretic of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature and the positive shifting dullness indicate ascites, probably due to liver cirrhosis in alcoholic liver disease. The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone.

Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels. Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism, such as in cirrhotic ascites.

Furosemide may be added, particularly in patients of ascites who have peripheral edema and are nonresponsive to spironolactone.

questions.text: A family consisting of a husband and a pregnant wife, along with 2 daughters aged 7 and 9 years, they stay in a house with 2 rooms. According to the accepted standards with respect to overcrowding, which of the following is false?
