questions.text: A teenage boy with progressive myopia and night blindness is diagnosed with gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid. Dietary restriction of which of the following amino acids slows down the progression of the disease?
questions.solution:
Gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid is associated with an ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase deficiency, which results in the accumulation of ornithine in the body. Dietary restriction of arginine (precursor of ornithine) helps in lowering the serum ornithine levels and thus slow down the progression. 

Gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase. Ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase (OAT) is a pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP) dependent enzyme present in the mitochondrial matrix. This enzyme is responsible for metabolizing ornithine in the body, and its deficiency leads to the accumulation of ornithine, which is toxic, particularly to the retinal pigment epithelial cells. 

Damage to the retinal pigment epithelium and choriocapillaris atrophy leads to the characteristic chorioretinal degenerative patches seen in gyrate atrophy. The disease typically presents in childhood or adolescence, with symptoms such as progressive vision loss, myopia(nearsightedness), night blindness, loss of peripheral vision, and cataracts. The atrophic patches are often described as circular or spherical, hence the term gyrate atrophy.

Treatment involves dietary modification to slow the progression of the disease by lowering ornithine levels. Arginine, which is a precursor to ornithine, is restricted in the diet, helping to reduce serum ornithine levels and slow down the progression of retinal degeneration. Vitamin B6 supplementation is also helpful, as OAT is a pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP) dependent enzyme.

Other amino acids, such as glycine, phenylalanine, and methionine, are not directly involved in the ornithine metabolism pathway, so restricting these does not significantly affect the progression of gyrate atrophy.

A 47-year-old woman has a history of hypertension and has gained significant weight over the past year. Her laboratory results are given below. Which of the following parameters is not consistent with the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome?

Fasting blood glucose: 108 mg/dL
HDL cholesterol: 38 mg/dL
Blood pressure: 138/90 mmHg
Waist circumference: 78cm
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of high fasting blood sugar, low HDL cholesterol levels suggests metabolic syndrome. The criteria not consistent with the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome is the waist circumference of 78cm. (Criteria: > 88 cm for women and in Indian standards > 80 cm for women).

Metabolic Syndrome is diagnosed when a patient has at least three of the following five criteria:

  • Abdominal obesity: Waist circumference >102 cm for men, >88 cm for women (as per Indian Standards ≥ 90 cm for men, ≥ 80 cm for women)
  • Elevated triglycerides: ≥ 150 mg/dL or on drug treatment for elevated triglycerides
  • Low HDL cholesterol: < 40 mg/dL in men, < 50 mg/dL in women, or on drug treatment
  • Elevated blood pressure: ≥130/85 mmHg or on drug treatment for hypertension
  • Elevated fasting blood sugar: ≥100 mg/dL or on drug treatment for hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer. MRI and PET-CT imaging reveal tumour extension up to the pelvic wall and involvement of the para-aortic lymph nodes. It also shows features suggestive of hydronephrosis. What is the best plan of management in this case?

choices.text: Modified radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy

questions.solution:
Cervical cancer involving the para-aortic lymph nodes is classified as Stage III C2 according to FIGO staging. Chemotherapy with radiation is the best plan of management in this case.

Note: If the patient just had carcinoma extension up to the pelvic wall and/or the presence of hydronephrosis, it would have been classified as Stage IIIB.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve?
questions.solution:
Among the muscles marked in the image, the muscle not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve is palatoglossus (marked as 1). It is supplied by the vagus nerve.

Embryologically, the palatoglossus muscle is unique among the tongue muscles, as it is derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the vagus nerve via the pharyngeal plexus. In contrast, the other muscles of the tongue—Hyoglossus, Styloglossus, and Genioglossus (marked as images 2,3 and 4, respectively)—are derived from the occipital myotomes and are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII).

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of dyspnea. Examination showed tender hepatomegaly, pedal edema, and jugular venous distension. On auscultation, a diastolic murmur was heard on the left lower sternal border. JVP waveform of the patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's congestive symptoms (hepatomegaly, pedal edema, and jugular venous distension), JVP showing giant a wave, and the presence of diastolic murmur in the tricuspid area — all point to a diagnosis of tricuspid stenosis.

Tricuspid stenosis does not occur as an isolated lesion, and is usually seen in association with mitral stenosis. It generally occurs as a consequence of rheumatic heart disease. Patients present with features of venous congestion, such as hepatomegaly, ascites, and edema. There is jugular venous distension, with giant a waves (due to increased RA pressure to pump the blood through the stenosed valve) and slow y descent (due to obstruction to emptying of the RA due to the stenosed valve).

On auscultation, a diastolic murmur is heard, appreciated best along the lower left sternal border and xiphisternum. The intensity of the murmur increases on inspiration and decreases during expiration and the Valsalva maneuver due to decreased blood flow across the tricuspid valve.

ECG shows features of right atrial enlargement which includes tall and peaked P waves in lead II and upright P waves in lead V1. Surgical treatment of TS is carried out at the time of MS repair.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient presents with a chronic history of heartburn. An upper GI endoscopy was done, and a biopsy from a suspicious lesion showed the following picture. 
Which of the following is used to assess the extent of his disease?
questions.solution:
The given histological image shows columnar epithelial mucosa of the oesophagus instead of squamous epithelium. This finding and the clinical history point towards suggests Barrett's oesophagus. Prague C&M criteria are used to assess the extent of the disease.

The Prague C&M Criteria for Barrett’s oesophagus is based on endoscopic assessment of the circumferential (C) and maximal (M) extent of the visualised Barrett’s segment. The length of the metaplastic region has a positive correlation with the risk of oesophagal adenocarcinoma.

Barrett's oesophagus is a type of metaplasia at the gastro-esophagal junction due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The squamous oesophagal mucosa is converted to a columnar/intestinal type, better suited to handle acid reflux. It is associated with an increased risk of oesophagal adenocarcinoma. Mucin stain (Alcian blue) is used to identify goblet cells, which are indicative of the intestinal metaplasia occurring in the condition. It does not stain mucin of the gastric mucosa. 

On endoscopy, grossly the metaplastic epithelium appears as tongues of red, velvety mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction alternating with pale squamous (esophageal) mucosa. 

Other options:

Option A: Tokyo criteria is used for acute cholecystitis.

Option C: Milan criteria is used for selecting candidates of hepatocellular carcinoma for transplant.

Option D: Rome criteria is used in irritable bowel syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following serological investigations is most useful in differentiating HBV pre-core mutant infection from chronic hepatitis B with low infectivity?
questions.solution:
HBV DNA level is most useful in differentiating HBV pre-core mutant infection from chronic hepatitis B with low infectivity.

The HBV pre-core mutant and chronic hepatitis B with low infectivity are both characterized by HBeAg negative status, but they differ in terms of HBV DNA levels.

  1. HBV Pre-core Mutant: These mutants have a mutation in the pre-core region of the C gene, leading to a stop codon that prevents the synthesis of HBeAg. They have high HBV DNA levels, even though HBeAg is absent.
  2. Chronic Hepatitis B with Low Infectivity: Low or undetectable HBV DNA levels. Despite the lack of HBeAg, this infection is associated with lower viral replication, which is why HBV DNA levels are essential for differentiation.

In the HBV genome, the C gene consists of 2 regions:

  • Pre-C region- When translation begins from the Pre-C region, HBeAg is synthesized.
  • C-region- When it begins from the C-region, HBcAg is synthesized.
    In the HBeAg sequence of pre-core mutants, there is a G to A switch at the 28th amino acid, causing a stop codon. Hence, pre-core mutants are unable to synthesize HBeAg. 

The image below shows the HBV genome : 

Serological markers in pre-core mutant and chronic hepatitis B with low infectivity:

  • HBeAg: Negative in both.
  • Anti-HBe: Positive in both.
  • HBsAg: Positive in both conditions (chronic infection)
  • Anti-HBs: Absent in both since the virus remains active and HBsAg is still present.
  • Anti-HBc IgG: Positive in both (chronic infection) 
  • HBV DNA level: High is Pre-core mutants and Low or undetectable in Chronic Hepatitis B with Low Infectivity.

Infection with hepatitis B mutants is difficult to treat and causes infections of prolonged duration. They have a higher risk of progressing to liver cirrhosis. 

Types of hepatitis B mutants are:

Pre-core mutants
  • Defect in pre-core region C.
  • No HBeAg

Escape mutants
  • Mutation in S region.
  • HBsAg resists neutralization by anti-HBs.
  • Seen in Infants born to HBeAg-positive mothers and Liver transplant recipients.
  • Associated with passive and active immunization.

YMDD mutation
  • Mutation in P region, i.e., YMDD locus, which codes for reverse transcriptase.
  • Seen in patients on lamivudine therapy.

questions.text: All the following are the early postmortem changes occurring in the eye except
questions.solution:
Post-mortem changes in the eye lead to an increase in vitreous potassium levels, not a decrease.

Postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Loss of corneal reflex (Option A)
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs (Option B) occurs due to a reduction in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches 0 mm of Hg at the end of 2 hours after death 
  • Dilatation of the pupil (Option C) due to relaxation of muscles of the iris
  • Increased potassium concentration in the vitreous up to 100 hours following death. After death, cell membranes in the vitreous humor start to break down, releasing potassium. Therefore, the concentration of potassium in the vitreous humor increases. 
  • Kevorkian sign occurs due to fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels, which lasts for about 1 hour. It occurs due to the loss of blood pressure and can be seen only through an ophthalmoscope as shown below.

Tache Noir: A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with the base towards the margin of the cornea and the apex towards the medial or lateral canthus of the eye. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a 1-month history of left-sided throbbing and stabbing headaches, particularly retro-orbital. He has nearly 12-15 exacerbations per day, each lasting 10 minutes, during which he has watering and redness in the left eye. Which of the following medications would his headache respond to?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of unilateral throbbing headaches lasting 10 minutes with 12-15 exacerbations per day, particularly in the retroorbital region with conjunctival congestion and lacrimation, is suggestive of Paroxysmal hemicrania. It shows excellent response to Indomethacin.

Paroxysmal hemicrania is a subgroup under trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (TAC). It is characterised by unilateral headache and is associated with autonomic symptoms like lacrimation and nasal congestion. The duration of attack ranges from 2 to 30 minutes with a frequency of 1 to 20 per day. Its responsiveness to Indomethacin distinguishes it from other Trigeminal autonomic cephalgia headaches.

Other options:

Option A: IV lidocaine is used in the management of SUNCT/SUNA. SUNCT is ruled out because it has very short-duration attacks (5-240 seconds) and much higher frequency (3-200/day).

Options B and C: Sumatriptan & Verapamil are indicated in the management of cluster headaches & migraine, which have a lower frequency and longer duration of attacks. Cluster headache has a duration of about 15-180 minutes with frequency of 1-8/day.

questions.text:
A patient with a history of hypertension presents with complaints of chronic fatigue and generalized weakness that has progressively worsened over the last few months. Laboratory results are given below. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

pH: 7.30
Sodium (Na⁺): 140 mEq/L
Chloride (Cl⁻): 113 mEq/L
Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻): 15 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of hypertension, chronic fatigue, muscle weakness, and postural hypotension with metabolic acidosis with Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), confirms Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) as the most likely diagnosis among the given options.

Step 1: The pH in this patient is 7.30 (pH <7.35) which indicates acidosis

Step 2: HCO3- is 15 mmol/L (Normal HCO3- - 22–30 mmol/L). In metabolic acidosis, HCO3- levels decrease.

Hence, this is a case of metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: Calculate the anion gap. 

Anion gap = Na+ - (Cl-+ HCO3-)

= 140 – (113 + 15) 

  = 12, which is a normal anion gap (normal anion gap is between 6-12 mEq/L)

RTA results in Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA) whereas uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis and lactic acidosis results in high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA).

questions.text: During an ongoing cholecystectomy surgery, the surgeon instructs the intern to retract the liver. Which of the following instruments should be used?
questions.solution:
A Deaver retractor is used to retract the liver during surgery.

It is commonly used during cholecystectomy. The liver can still be damaged while using this retractor, so care must be taken to avoid using excessive force. Some surgeons prefer to reduce the risk of liver injury by placing an abdominal pack between the liver and retractor. 

Other options:

Option B - Doyen retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall and bladder during surgery. It is frequently used in lower segment cesarean sections to allow visualization of the lower uterine segment. 

Option C - Morris retractor is a large retractor used to give maximum exposure during abdominal surgeries. Because of its size, it can be used to improve the field of visibility by retracting a large number of structures. 

Option D - Czerny retractor has two ends. One end is a blade with a lip and the other has two prongs and is used to retract the ends of an incision. It is used to retract wounds like in open appendicectomy.

questions.text: A boy presents with fever and chills. The rapid test is positive for specific antigen HRP-2. What type of biological transmission does the given infection show?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever with chills and the HRP-2 positivity are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Malaria shows cyclopropogative type of transmission.  

Methods of biological transmission

Explanation
Cyclodevelopmental

A part of the life cycle is completed in the vector
Eg- W. bancrofti in Culex
Cyclopropagative

Undergoes development as well as multiplication
Eg- Plasmodium in mosquito
Propagative

Simply grows and multiply
Eg- Yersinia pestis in rat flea

When an infectious agent is passed from the parent to its offspring, it is called transovarial transmission.

Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by the Plasmodium species transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. It is characterized by many nonspecific symptoms, such as tachycardia, tachypnea, chills, malaise, fatigue, diaphoresis (sweating), and headache. The fever of malaria is characterized by periodicity depending on the infective Plasmodium species. The fever returns every other day for P. vivax, P. ovale, and P. falciparum, and every three days for P. malariae. The life cycle of Plasmodium falciparum is given below:

The newer tests include rapid antigen detection tests that employ immunochromatographic methods. The parasite-F test is one of them. This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2) which is produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum that are present on the surface of RBCs.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of fall from height was brought to the orthopaedic department. His radiograph of the foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing calcaneal body fracture is suggestive of Lovers fracture.

Lovers fracture, also known as Don Juan fracture or Casanova fracture is a fracture of the calcaneal body. It may be intra- or extra-articular. The name "lover's fracture" is derived from the fact that a suitor may jump from great heights while trying to escape from the lover's spouse. There is an important association between lover's fractures and burst fractures of the lumbar spine, so further evaluation of the spine is required in these patients.

Other options:

Option A: Jones fracture is a transverse fracture on the base of the 5th metatarsal at the metaphyseal- diaphyseal junction. This type of injury occurs in a sudden change in direction by an athlete.

Option C: March fracture is a fracture of the 2nd metatarsal. It occurs due to repeated stress from prolonged walking or running. This may occur in new army recruits committed to marching. Hence the name march fracture. These lesions heal spontaneously. The below radiograph shows a March fracture of the second metatarsal bone.

Option D: Lisfranc fracture is the fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation. Lisfranc articulation comprises the tarsometatarsal joints. The tarsometatarsal joints comprise of first, second, and third metatarso-cuneiform joints along with the fourth and fifth metatarso-cuboid joints.

questions.text: A patient after a motor vehicle accident develops breathing difficulty. On examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the right side, and the trachea is shifted to the left. Heart sounds are normal. There is a dull note on percussion. The chest X-ray is shown below. What will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, dull note on percussion, and the chest X-ray showing blunting of the costophrenic angle and opacification is suggestive of massive hemothorax. The next step of management that can be done for this patient is intercostal drainage tube(ICD) placement.

Massive hemothorax occurs when more than 1500 mL of blood, equivalent to one-third or more of the patient's blood volume, rapidly accumulates in the chest cavity. This condition is typically caused by a penetrating injury that damages major blood vessels, although it can also be the result of blunt trauma.

In patients with massive hemothorax, the neck veins may appear flat due to severe hypovolemia, or they may be distended if there is a concurrent tension pneumothorax. If a patient is in shock and exhibits an absence of breath sounds or dullness upon percussion on one side of the chest, it suggests the presence of a massive hemothorax.

The initial management of massive haemothorax involves decompression of the chest cavity. A single chest tube with a diameter of 28-32 French is inserted, typically at the fifth intercostal space, just anterior to the midaxillary line.

Simultaneous resuscitation to restore blood volume is also advisable. This is achieved by establishing large-diameter intravenous lines, administering crystalloid fluids, and initiating transfusion of blood at the earliest opportunity.

The immediate return of 1500 mL or greater volume of blood typically signifies the urgent requirement for thoracotomy. Patients who initially show an output of less than 1500 mL of fluid but continue to bleed may also necessitate thoracotomy.

Needle thoracostomy and open thoracotomy are done in cases of tension pneumothorax. Here, the patients present with distended neck veins, decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, and hyper-resonant note on percussion.

questions.text: Which of the following antibody actions is not observed with pernicious anemia?

choices.text: Antibody impairing the gastric parietal cells
Blocks binding of intrinsic factor to Vitamin B12
Blocks binding of B12-intrinsic factor complex to Ileal receptor

questions.solution:
Impairment of pepsinogen-secreting chief cells is not associated with antibody actions in pernicious anemia.

Antibody Actions in Pernicious Anemia:

Antibody Antibody effect Action Inhibited
Type 1  Blocking antibodies Binding of vitamin B12 to Intrinsic factor (IF)
Type 2  Binding antibodies Binding of vitamin B12-Intrinsic factor (IF) Complex to Ileal (cubulin) receptor
Type 3  Anti-parietal cell antibodies Intrinsic factor synthesis (IF) inhibition leads to decreased vitamin B12

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies, targeting intrinsic factors and gastric parietal cells, impairing vitamin B12 absorption. As a result, all lineages of bone marrow precursors show asynchronous maturation (due to impaired DNA synthesis) between the nucleus and cytoplasm (megaloblastic cells). This results in:

  • Megaloblastic anemia: Impaired DNA synthesis causing asynchronous nuclear and cytoplasmic maturation in bone marrow precursors.
  • Peripheral smear findings: Macro-ovalocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils, low reticulocyte count, and occasional nucleated red cells.
  • Bone marrow findings: Hypercellular marrow with megaloblasts, giant granulocyte precursors, and abnormal megakaryocytes.

Related Pearl: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.text: A young man presented to the casualty with a suspected abdominal injury following a road traffic accident. On examination, his vitals are found to be stable and there is some tenderness in the epigastric and umbilical areas. He was sent for a contrast-enhanced CT scan. Which of the following can be safely used as an intravascular contrast medium in him?
questions.solution:
Iodinated contrast can be safely used as an intravascular contrast medium in contrast-enhanced CT scan for this patient.

Contrast agents for CT can be divided into:

  • Water-soluble compounds (iodine-containing)
  • Non-water-soluble compounds (barium)

Iodine is the only element that can be safely used as an intravascular contrast medium for radiography including angiography and CT. The iodine provides radiopacity. The other elements of the contrast medium act as carriers of iodine which increases the solubility and reduces toxicity. They interfere with the clotting times. Hence, clotting tests are usually avoided until 6 hours after the administration of contrast media. They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media are classified as ionic and non-ionic, based on the nature of the compound to which the iodine is bound. Ionic media consists of iodine bound to inorganic compounds, while non-ionic media consists of iodine bound to an organic compound. The common examples of ionic and non-ionic iodine-based contrast media include iothalamate, iohexol respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Gadolinium (Gd) is used as a contrast medium for MRI. It contains paramagnetic metal ions that affect the MR signal properties of surrounding tissues. Since gadolinium ion is toxic, it is chelated with DTPA. Hence, Gd-DTPA is the agent used.

Option B: Barium sulphate (BaSO4) is a poorly soluble compound that is used to study the gastrointestinal tract. It is administered orally or rectally, in a finely divided aqueous suspension. It is avoided when there is a suspicion of aspiration, a fistula between the oesophagus and lungs, or perforation of the gastrointestinal tract due to the risk of leakage causing fatal mediastinitis or peritonitis.

Option C: Perflutren, as a microscopic gas bubble is a contrast media used in ultrasound imaging. It is administered intravenously. There are three agents available:

  • Air with galactose and palmitic acid as a surfactant
  • Octa fluoro propane (perflutren) with an albumin shell or a lipid shell
  • Sulphur hexafluoride with a phospholipid shell.

questions.text: A male patient presents with hearing difficulty and tinnitus. On examination of his ear, you note numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal. MRI showed acoustic neuroma. Involvement of which of the following nerves is responsible for numbness in his ear?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal is suggestive of the Hitzelberger sign. It is seen in acoustic neuroma and occurs due to facial nerve involvement.

Acoustic neuroma is also called a vestibular schwannoma or an eighth nerve tumor. It arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve. It is the most common cerebellopontine angle tumor and is associated with neurofibromatosis 2.

Clinically, patients typically present with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus.

The posterior wall of the auditory canal receives sensory fibers from the CN VII/ facial nerve through the auricular branch of the vagus. Therefore, the involvement of the facial nerve in acoustic neuroma results in hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall, which is called Hitzelberger’s sign.

questions.text: According to the Kauffman-White scheme classification of Salmonella, serogrouping is based on which of the following antigens of Salmonella?
questions.solution:
According to the Kauffman-White scheme classification of Salmonella, serogrouping is based on the O antigen of Salmonella.

Kauffman-White scheme classification classifies Salmonella into serogroups and serotypes using three main antigens:

  1. Somatic antigen (O): This is part of the cell wall lipopolysaccharide. Salmonella serogrouping is based on the O antigen, and different O antigens are used to divide Salmonella into various serogroups. 
  2. Flagellar antigen (H): The flagellar antigen, made of flagellin protein, confers motility to Salmonella. This is the second level of classification after determining the serogroup. Based on the H antigen, serogroups are differentiated into serotypes.
  3. Surface envelope antigen (Vi): It is part of the surface polysaccharide envelope or capsular antigen covering the O antigen. It is found in a few species of Salmonella, such as Salmonella typhi, and is important for virulence and used in vaccines.

Although Salmonella species can have fimbriae, which are involved in adhesion to host cells, these are not part of the Kauffman-White scheme and are not used for serogrouping or serotyping.

Serogrouping is based on the O antigen, while serotyping is based on both the O and H antigens. The classification begins with the O antigen to identify the serogroup, followed by a further distinction based on the H antigen for serotyping.

questions.text: A patient presents to the dermatology OPD with scaly plaques on his skin and thickening of palms and soles as seen in the image below. Which of the following is a feature of this skin condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows keratotic sandals (orangish thickening of soles), suggestive of pityriasis rubra pilaris. Skin lesions in this condition show islands of sparing.

Salmon red/orange-red dry, scaly plaques are characteristically seen in pityriasis rubra pilaris, which coalesce together, leaving islands of normal skin, typically known as 'islands of sparing' in between the lesions. The most common site is the trunk. On the elbow and wrist, nutmeg grater papules are seen due to follicular hyperkeratosis.

The image below shows islands of sparing in pityriasis rubra pilaris:


Palmoplantar keratoderma on the sole is so thick that it appears as a sandal (keratodermic sandal). Nails become thickened, discolored distally, and show splinter hemorrhages.


Other options:

Option A: Nail pitting is seen in psoriasis.

Option B: Palmoplantar pustules are seen in pustular psoriasis.

Option D: Subungual hemorrhages can be caused by trauma, and wearing tight footwear.

questions.text: A slit lamp examination of a woman with corneal dystrophy showed the following deposits in the anterior corneal stroma. Which type of dystrophy does this patient have?

questions.text:
A patient with productive cough, fever, and breathlessness was found to have decreased breath sounds and a dull note on percussion on the left side. His X-ray is given below. Sputum analysis revealed a diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia. Which of the following pleural fluid characteristics would best fit the diagnosis, according to Light's criteria?

LDH- Lactate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
The pleural fluid characteristics in a patient with bacterial pneumonia would be pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH of >0.6. The pleural effusion associated with bacterial pneumonia is exudative in nature. 

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum. 

Exudative effusions occur when there is a disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage because of local factors.

Causes of exudative effusion include:

  • Bacterial pneumonia
  • Viral infections
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Malignancy. 

Transudative effusions will not meet any of the above-mentioned criteria. They occur when there is a disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage due to systemic factors.

Causes of transudative effusion include:

  • Cirrhosis of the liver
  • Left ventricular failure
  • Nephrotic syndrome

Understanding the cause of a patient’s pleural effusion can help us diagnose the condition and determine management. 

The other options are incorrect as they are not in line with Light’s criteria for the diagnosis of an exudative effusion.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents with vomiting and abdominal pain for 5 days. She has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. IgA-tissue transglutaminase titer is found to be elevated. Which of the following foods can she safely consume?
questions.solution:
The girl's symptoms and elevated IgA-tissue transglutaminase titer suggest she has celiac disease. She should avoid gluten in her diet but can safely consume rice. 

Celiac disease is an immune-mediated systemic disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten, a protein found in wheat, rye, and barley, in genetically predisposed individuals. It is characterised by various clinical manifestations, specific antibodies, certain HLA genotypes, and enteropathy.

Clinical Features:

  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Chronic diarrhoea, abdominal pain, vomiting, weight loss, and failure to thrive.
  • Extraintestinal Symptoms: Anemia, fatigue, elevated liver enzymes, neurologic disorders, short stature, dental enamel defects, arthralgia, aphthous stomatitis.

The pathophysiology involves an immune response to indigestion of gluten in genetically susceptible individuals (those with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 haplotypes), causing damage to the small intestine. The specific antibodies include autoantibodies against tissue transglutaminase (TG2) and endomysial antibodies (EMAs), as well as antibodies against deaminated gliadin peptides.

Investigation:

  • Serologic Tests: Initial testing for anti-TG2 IgA antibodies and total IgA. If anti-TG2 is positive and IgA levels are normal, CD is likely.
  • Genetic Testing: For HLA-DQ2 or DQ8 haplotypes.
  • Endoscopy and Biopsy: Multiple biopsies from the small intestine to check for villous atrophy.

Biopsy Findings:

  • Villous Atrophy: Flattening of the villi in the small intestine.
  • Crypt Hyperplasia: Enlargement of the crypts.
  • Intraepithelial Lymphocytosis: Increased number of lymphocytes in the epithelium.

Treatment:

Gluten-Free Diet: To manage celiac disease, patients must strictly avoid all foods containing gluten from wheat, rye, and barley. (Option A, B, C).  Pure oats are generally safe, but caution is advised due to possible contamination. Safe alternatives include rice, corn, maize, buckwheat, millet, amaranth, quinoa, sorghum, potato, soybean, tapioca, and teff, along with bean and nut flours.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of the condition and the type of joint involved is wrongly matched?

choices.text: Bouchard nodes, Heberden nodes - Hinge joint
Hill-Sachs lesion with bony Bankart lesion - Ball and socket joint
Unhappy triad of O Donoghue - Condylar joint

questions.solution:
Podagra - Saddle joint is the wrongly matched option.

Podagra refers to gout involving the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint, which is commonly known as the big toe joint. Gout in this joint causes swelling, redness, heat, and tenderness. The MTP joint is an ellipsoid synovial joint, not a saddle joint. Saddle joints, like the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb, allow for more complex movements but are not involved in podagra.

Option A: Bouchard nodes of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and Heberden nodes of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints are manifestations of osteoarthritis. PIP and DIP are both uniaxial hinge joints.

Option B: Hill-Sachs lesion with bony Bankart lesion is seen in recurrent anterior dislocation of the shoulder. The shoulder joint is a ball and socket synovial joint. Detachment of the labrum and capsule from the anterior rim of the glenoid is called a Bankart lesion, while an indentation on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head due to the humeral head being forced against the anterior glenoid rim is called the Hill–Sachs lesion

Option D: Unhappy triad of O Donoghue of the knee refers to an injury of the medial meniscus, medial collateral ligament, and anterior cruciate ligament. The knee is a condylar synovial joint.

4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A child had recurrent bouts of infections. The diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease was made using the nitroblue tetrazolium test. This test assesses the functions of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The nitroblue tetrazolium test assesses the function of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN).

Nitroblue tetrazolium assay is used as a diagnostic test, particularly for chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). It tests the reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in neutrophils and monocytes.

Chronic granulomatous disease is a rare X-linked recessive disease. It is characterized by the impaired phagocytic killing of microorganisms by neutrophils and macrophages. Defects in NADPH oxidase lead to defective production of reactive oxygen species after phagocytosis.

These patients have frequent infections by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Burkholderia cepacia complex, Nocardia, Aspergillus, etc. Recurrent folliculitis may prompt early diagnosis of the condition. Following these infections, there is extensive inflammation and suppuration despite antibiotic therapy.

Other features include aphthous ulcers, inflammation of the nares, and granulomas. Granulomas can cause obstruction of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tracts. Autoimmune complications like immune thrombocytopenic purpura and juvenile idiopathic arthritis may also occur.

Management of CGD is mainly treating infections with antibiotics or antifungals depending on the cause. Granulomas are sensitive to steroids and glucocorticoids can be given. 

Other options:

Options B and C: B and T lymphocytes can be assessed by lymphocyte phenotyping. It is useful in the diagnosis of T-cell immunodeficiencies and agammaglobulinemia.

Option D: Complement can be assessed by CH50 and AP50, which are useful in diagnosing complement deficiencies.

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: All the following coagulation parameters are increased in pregnancy, except:
questions.solution:
Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state (in order to control bleeding and help in hemostasis after placental separation), but Platelet count remains the same or falls by 15%. 

Hematological changes in pregnancy:

  • All clotting factors are increased (Options C and D), except factors 11 and 13. The levels return to normal within 2 weeks of delivery.
  • Fibrinogen levels are increased by 50%. (Option B)
  • ESR is raised due to an increase in fibrinogen and globulin levels.
  • Anticoagulants protein C, protein S, and antithrombin are decreased during pregnancy.
  • The viscosity of blood decreases due to relative hemodilution (relatively higher increase in plasma volume as compared to the increase in RBC mass).
  • Because of a marked fall in albumin level and only a slight rise of globulin, the normal albumin: globulin ratio of 1.7:1 is decreased to 1:1.
  • Platelet counts remain the same or fall by a small amount.
  • Clotting time and bleeding time remain unaffected.

The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption, and the women are generally asymptomatic.

questions.text: A child was brought to the hospital and was found to have hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and accumulation of highly branched glycogen polymers called limit dextrins. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Cori's disease.

Glycogen debranching enzyme deficiency (glycogen storage disease III) is also known as Cori's disease, Forbes' disease, and limit dextrinosis. The debranching enzyme, together with phosphorylase, is responsible for the complete degradation of glycogen. In this case, the debranching enzyme is defective; hence, the glycogen breakdown is incomplete, which results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer-branch chains, which resemble limit dextrin.

Cori’s disease may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke’s disease in infancy and childhood as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and growth retardation is common. Muscle weakness is slowly progressive and associated with wasting. Accumulation of limit dextrins is seen in Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through enzyme assays in the liver, muscle, or both.

questions.text: A paediatric patient presented with a double aortic arch as given below. What is the embryological origin of this condition?

choices.text: Persistence of the distal portion of the Left Dorsal aorta
Persistence of the proximal portion of the Right Dorsal aorta
Persistence of the proximal portion of the Left Dorsal aorta
Persistence of the distal portion of the Right Dorsal aorta

questions.solution:
The embryological origin of the double aortic arch is Persistence of distal portion of the Right Dorsal aorta.

The given image shows a double aortic arch, a congenital anomaly. In this, the right dorsal aorta, between the origin of the seventh cervical intersegmental artery and its junction with the left dorsal aorta, does not disappear. Hence, the distal portion of the Right Dorsal aorta persists. 

The right arch of the aorta passes behind the trachea and oesophagus, while the left arch passes in front of them. This also leads to compression of the trachea and oesophagus, which further leads to difficulty in breathing and swallowing. Both the right and left aortic arches, join the descending thoracic aorta after giving off the left subclavian artery.

questions.text: You are posted in a CHC as a part of your postings. The region has experienced a notable increase in cases of urban malaria. Which of the following approaches would you recommend as the most effective method for arthropod control?

choices.text: Filling and draining of breeding places
Paris green mixed in the water
Provide the entire community with mosquito nets

questions.solution:
Environmental control is the best approach to control arthropods such as Anopheles which is a cause of Urban Malaria. (specifically Anopheles stephensi ).

Urban malaria refers to malaria transmission occurring in urban or metropolitan areas, typically in regions that were previously not associated with malaria. This form of malaria can be caused by the introduction or re-emergence of Anopheles mosquitoes that transmit the disease, despite urbanization efforts like better infrastructure and sanitation.

Environmental control of Anopheles includes: 

  • Filling and draining of breeding places.
  • Levelling: prevents water collection in depressions, which can act as breeding grounds.
  • Intermittent irrigation: Mosquitoes are discouraged from breeding by not allowing water to remain stagnant for long periods.
  • Changing the salinity of water: prevent mosquito larvae from developing 

Mosquito-specific measures of source reduction :

Anopheles Filling and draining of breeding places
Aedes Elimination of artificial collections of water (e.g., tins, coconut shells)
Mansonia Herbicides sprayed on aquatic plants
Culex

Elimination of breeding sources such as cesspools and open ditches and the disposal of sewage and wastewater.

The principles of arthropod control include:

  • Environmental control - The best approach is to manage water sources, drainage, and sanitation.
  • Vector control:
    • Anti-adult measures: Residual spraying, Space application of pesticides in the form of mist, individual protection
    • Anti-larval measures: Larvicides (temephos), Biological control - Use of larvivorous fish like Gambusia
    • Integrated Approach
  • Genetic control - Genetic modification of mosquitoes to reduce their ability to transmit diseases.
  • Newer methods -
    • Chemosterilants
    • Insect growth regulators
    • Sex attractants
  • Integrated approach combines multiple methods for effective arthropod control.

questions.text: A woman presenting with flu-like symptoms, erythema nodosum, and a history of travel to the southwestern United States was suspected to have Valley Fever. Which of the following findings is expected to be seen on sputum microscopy?

choices.text: Oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding
Round yeast cells with single broad-based budding
Yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferentially

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, involving a woman with flu-like symptoms, erythema nodosum, and a history of travel to the southwestern United States (an endemic area), suggests Valley Fever, also known as Coccidioidomycosis. It is caused by Coccidioides immitis. On sputum microscopy, mature spherules filled with endospores are seen.

An image showing mature spherules filled with endospores of Coccidioides immitis is given below:

Coccidioides immitis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It occurs as spherules in tissues and culture at 37°C, and it exists in the mycelial form in the soil and culture at room temperature. They are endemic to the arid desert regions of the southwestern USA and California. Infection is acquired by inhaling dust containing arthrospores of the fungus (e.g., during windstorms, earthquakes, archaeological explorations), with individuals having a travel history to Southwestern United States, California (San Joaquin Valley).

The infection can be asymptomatic, or patients may present with symptoms like fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. It is also referred to as Valley fever. Some clinical features occur due to an immunologic response. These include toxic erythema, erythema nodosum, and erythema multiforme. Symmetrical arthralgias called "Desert rheumatism" may also be seen. Clinical dissemination of infection outside the thoracic cavity occurs in immunocompromised patients. 

Sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage, and biopsy specimens are the samples used for diagnosis. Microscopy shows spherule with endospores. Culture on brain heart infusion agar with 5% blood shows white-colored colonies and is the most specific for diagnosis. Serology using ELISA, Immunodiffusion assays, and complement fixation assays are also used to detect IgM and IgG antibodies. Delayed hypersensitivity can be demonstrated by a positive skin test with 'coccidiodin' (analogous to the tuberculin test).

Azole drugs such as Fluconazole and Itraconazole are the mainstay of treatment. Severe cases are managed with intravenous amphotericin B. 

Other options: 

Option A: Oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response are suggestive of Histoplasma capsulatum. It causes Histoplasmosis/ Darling's disease/ Reticuloendotheliosis.

Option B: Round yeast cells with single broad-based budding depicting Figure of 8 appearance is suggestive of Blastomyces dermatitidis. It causes North American blastomycosis. (Blastomycosis forms broad-based buds.)

Option D: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferentially giving rise to Mickey Mouse or Pilot Wheel appearance is suggestive of Paracoccidioidomycosis brasiliensis. It causes Brazilian blastomycosis/ South American blastomycosis/ Paracoccidioidal granuloma.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the ER after he was found on the highway having suffered from polytrauma due to a road traffic accident. His vitals were recorded to be Pulse- 115/min, BP- 70/40mm Hg. His blood lactate level was 8mmol/L. The team decides to take the patient for damage control surgery. What constitutes stage III of his management plan?

choices.text: Control of haemorrhage and control of contamination
Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit

questions.solution:
Damage control surgery (DCS) is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. Monitoring & Resuscitation in the intensive care unit is done in Stage III of the damage control surgery.

It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. Five stages of damage control surgery:

  1. Patient selection
  2. Control of haemorrhage and control of contamination
  3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
  4. Deﬁnitive surgery
  5. Abdominal closure

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the nerve blocked by the procedure shown in the image below?
  1. Originates from nerve roots S2, S3, S4
  2. Carries only sensory fibers of the perineum
  3. Passes through Alcock's canal
  4. It passes above the piriformis
  5. Pinching of the lower vagina and posterior vulva can be used to confirm a successful block
questions.solution:
The image shows the technique of localizing the pudendal nerve and administering a pudendal nerve block transvaginally.

The pudendal nerve nerve originates from the ventral divisions of sacral nerve roots S2, S3, and S4. It carries both sensory and motor fibers to the perineum. It leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis to enter the gluteal region. It then accompanies the internal pudendal artery through the lesser sciatic foramen into the pudendal (Alcock’s) canal on the lateral wall of the ischio-anal fossa.

The pudendal nerve can be palpated over the ischial spine through the lateral wall of the rectum. It splits into 3 branches

    • Inferior rectal nerve
    • Perineal nerve
    • Dorsal nerve of the clitoris (or penis)

Pinching of the lower vagina and posterior vulva can be used to confirm a successful pudendal nerve block.

questions.text: A patient from a river blindness-endemic region presents with sclerosing keratitis. Which type of Microfilaria is responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Sheathed, Nuclei extend up to the tail tip
Sheathed, Nuclei do not extend up to the tail tip
Unsheathed, Nuclei extend up to the tail tip
Unsheathed, Nuclei do not extend up to the tail tip

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient with sclerosing keratitis, an ocular manifestation of Onchocerciasis (river blindness) caused by Onchocerca volvulus. The microfilaria in onchocerciasis are unsheathed, and their nuclei do not extend up to the tail tip.

Onchocerca volvulus infection primarily affects the skin and eyes and is caused by the presence of adult worms and their microfilariae. 

  • Onchodermatitis: Severe pruritis due to the inflammatory response to microfilariae. It can present with subcutaneous nodules (Onchocercomas) containing adult worms over bony prominences (pelvis, chest, scalp).
  • Ocular Onchocerciasis: Presents with Punctate Keratitis in early-stage (Pinpoint opacities in the cornea due to living microfilariae). Advances to Sclerosing Keratitis (Corneal opacification and scarring), chorioretinitis, and optic Atrophy.
  • Systemic Manifestations: Lymphadenopathy in inguinal and femoral regions and generalized fatigue, malaise,

The image given below shows sclerosing keratitis of Ocular onchocerciasis:

Ocular onchocerciasis may affect any part of the eyeball and cause keratitis, iridocyclitis, choroiditis, glaucoma, optic neuritis, and blindness, commonly known as "River blindness"(black flies breed along fast-flowing rivers). It is part of the Global Vision 2020 program. Other causes of sclerosing keratitis include autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis), and idiopathic anterior scleritis.

Onchocerca volvulus is a tissue nematode. The image given below depicts the life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus:

"Ivermectin" is the drug of choice for onchocerciasis caused by Oncocerca volvulus in adults and children aged more than 5 years.

Note: "Treat rIVER blindness with IVERmectin"

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presented with pain in the right knee region for the past three months. On examination, the right knee region is swollen and there is a reduced range of motion. An x-ray taken for further evaluation reveals the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the x-ray showing an expansile, eccentric, sub-articular soap bubble appearance is suggestive of Giant cell tumor (GCT) or Osteoclastoma.

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 years with slight female predominance. It is seen exclusively in adults and affects the epiphysis of long bones, commonly in the distal end of the femur followed by the proximal tibia. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

  • Important x-ray features of a GCT
    • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
    • Eccentric location, most often subchondral.
    • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
    • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.
    • No calcification within the tumor.
    • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Histologically, GCTs consist of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like distal ulna, clavicle, and proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

Other options:

Option A: Aneurysmal bone cyst is a benign, expansile lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the long bones, comprised of blood-filled cystic spaces. It is more common in the age group of 5-20 years. These occur more commonly in the metaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, and humerus. Patients usually present with pain and swelling. The x-ray image is given below:

 

Option B: Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that present commonly in the adolescent age group. Radiograph and MRI would reveal pedunculated bony protuberance with a stalk with a growing cartilaginous cap (as shown below) or some lesions with a broad sessile base.

 

Option D: Osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance (as shown below) on the X-ray.

questions.text: Identify the stage of maturation of the senile cortical cataract shown in the following image.
questions.solution:
The given image findings indicate incipient cataract of cupuliform type.

The stage of incipient cataract has two types - cuneiform and cupuliform. The cupuliform type has central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule (as seen in the given image). Whereas, cuneiform cataract shows radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally.

Senile cataract is the most common type of acquired cataract and is also known as age-related cataract. The two types of senile cataracts are cortical (soft cataract)-75% and nuclear (hard cataract)-25%.

Stages of maturation of cortical senile cataract:

  1. Stage of lamellar separation
  2. Stage of incipient cataract-
    • Cuneiform pattern
    • Cupuliform pattern
  3. Stage of immature cataract-
    • Lens- greyish-white 
    • Clear cortex is still present, so the iris shadow is visible
    • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.
  4. Stage of mature cortical cataract-
    • Opacification complete
    • Lens- pearly, white
  5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract-
    • Whole cortex liquefies
    • Lens converted into a bag of milky fluid
    • Small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom (alters position with change in the position of the head)

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with a malignant lump in the breast who is undergoing chemotherapy with doxorubicin presents with raised troponin levels. Which of the following drugs could have been coadministered to prevent her present condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity and dexrazoxane would have prevented it. Doxorubicin is an anthracycline group of anticancer antibiotics.

Doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy takes two forms:

  • Acute: pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome, arrhythmias, ST and T wave changes in ECG.
  • Chronic: dilated cardiomyopathy.

Dexrazoxane is a cardioprotective iron-chelating agent that is indicated for use along with high-dose doxorubicin to avoid cardiotoxicity. The exact cardioprotective mechanism of dexrazoxane is unknown and it appears not to compromise with the anticancer activity of doxorubicin.

Option A- Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used to treat inflammation, and allergic reactions, or as part of chemotherapy regimens (to reduce nausea and inflammation). It is not specifically used to prevent cardiotoxicity from doxorubicin.

Option B- Leucovorin is a form of folic acid used to rescue normal cells from the toxic effects of drugs like methotrexate.

Option C- Mesna is used to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis, which is a side effect of certain chemotherapy drugs like cyclophosphamide.

questions.text: As a medical intern, you attend a session conducted by your college, on the topic 'Recent Advances in Fetal Medicine'. The session featured 4 renowned paediatricians who sat on the dais and discussed this topic in front of an audience of 80 people. What form of communication is used in this session?
questions.solution:
The mode of communication used in the above scenario is panel discussion which comprises of 4-8 qualified persons who sit together and discuss a topic in front of an audience. 

It has a chairman, a moderator, and 4-8 speakers. There is no specific agenda or set speeches. The audience is also invited to take part after the main discussion.

Other options:

Option B: A symposium is a series of speeches on a selected subject by experts. Each expert presents an aspect of the subject briefly, after which the audience is allowed to ask questions. There is no discussion among symposium members. The chairman makes a comprehensive summary at the end of the session.

Option C:  A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within a group, with the use of external consultants or experts. It can be divided into small groups each with a chairman and recorder. Each individual solves a part of the problem and leaves the workshop with a plan of action.

Option D: Conference is an official meeting where members of professional organizations meet to discuss important matters. It is usually a part of Continuing Medical Education (CME).

questions.text: The following image shows a graph representing atrial and ventricular pressures during a cardiac cycle. Which phase of the cardiac cycle corresponds to the relaxation of the ventricular muscle with no change in its volume?
questions.solution:
The phase of the cardiac cycle labelled 3 corresponds to iso-volumetric relaxation where the ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.

Events of the Cardiac Cycle

Systole :

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Diastole :

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with 'a' wave in JVP.

questions.text: Which of the following rectal prolapse procedures is performed through the abdominal approach?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Repstein operation is the abdominal approach for rectal prolapse.

It is managed by using the Perineal approach or the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is easy to perform and has fewer complications but a high recurrence rate. The surgeries done using this approach for rectal prolapse are the following:

  • Thiersch's wiring
  • Delorme's mucosectomy
  • Altemeier's procedure or perineal recto sigmoidectomy

The abdominal approach is difficult to perform and has more complications but a lower recurrence rate. The surgeries done using this approach are the following: 

  • Moschcowitz repair
  • Ripstein and Wells rectopexy; ventral rectopexy or suture rectopexy
  • Resection rectopexy

If the patient is fit enough for an abdominal procedure, it is preferred over the perineal procedure, since the risk of recurrence is lower. The perineal approach is preferred in elderly patients with comorbidities and in young men since the abdominal approach may injure the pelvic autonomic nerves which may result in sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: In a patient with pheochromocytoma, the anaesthesiologist should avoid all the following drugs except:
questions.solution:
Vecuronium and Rocuronium are safe neuromuscular blocking agents in Pheochromocytoma, as they do not trigger any catecholamine release.

Pheochromocytoma is a condition where the chromaffin tissue, most commonly in the adrenal medulla, produces excessive norepinephrine and epinephrine. 

Other anesthetic drugs to be avoided in a pheochromocytoma patient are:

  • Ketamine (Option D)  - as it is sympathomimetic and might exacerbate the effects of adrenergic agonists
  • Halothane (Option B) increases the sensitivity of the myocardium to epinephrine-induced arrhythmias. 
  • Anticholinergics and Pancuronium – vagal blockade leading to tachycardia
  • Atracurium – due to histamine release which may provoke catecholamine release. The safest options for these patients would be Vecuronium and Rocuronium
  • Metoclopramide (Option A) may induce catecholamine release from the tumour and trigger hypertensive crisis.

Other considerations in patients with pheochromocytoma:

  • Phenoxybenzamine, an alpha1-antagonist, which can be administered orally, is often given preoperatively to reverse the vasoconstriction. This results in a drop in arterial blood pressure and a drop in hematocrit
  • Phentolamine is used intraoperatively to control hypertensive episodes
  • A major regional block such as spinal/epidural could block sensory and sympathetic discharge in the area of the surgical field. But catecholamines released from the pheochromocytoma could still bind to receptors all over the body.

questions.text: A resident doctor fails to give fluids to a patient with dehydration. Under which doctrine will the doctor be held responsible?
questions.solution:
The resident doctor will be held responsible under the Doctrine of Common Knowledge.

The doctrine is based on the assumption that the issue of negligence in this particular case is not related to technical matters but is within the knowledge of the medical profession. For example, the doctor will be held responsible for a lack of application of common sense, such as failure to give fluids in dehydration or failure to apply antiseptic to an open cut. 

Other options 

Option B:  Doctrine of Res Ipsa Loquitur means the patient need not prove negligence, which means “the thing or fact speaks for itself”. For eg - Prescribing an overdose of medicine produces ill-effects and surgery done on wrong side of the body. Burden of proof of innocence lies on the doctor.

Option C: Doctrine of vicarious liability means the superior is liable for negligent act of the third party. Vicarious liability is by which the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer). When two doctors practice as together as equals, both are liable.

Option D:  If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question based on the same set of facts and this is known as Res Judicata.

questions.text: A 25-year-old football player is brought to the emergency room after falling on the field during a match. His X-ray shows the findings below. Which of the following peripheral blocks is indicated to restore the normal anatomy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of shoulder dislocation as seen on the X-ray. Interscalene block provides surgical anaesthesia for procedures of the shoulder and upper arm.

Interscalene nerve block is performed between the anterior and middle scalene muscles in the inter-scalene groove at the level of C6, where the brachial plexus emerges. It provides an adequate block of the superior and middle trunks of the brachial plexus. The ulnar nerve (C8, T1) from the inferior trunk may be missed. Hence, this block is not used for procedures of the forearm and hand.

The most common complication of inter-scalene block seen in 100% of patients is diaphragmatic hemiparesis due to ipsilateral phrenic nerve blockade. This can result in dyspnea, hypoxia, and hypercapnia, especially if the patient has compromised lung function or preexisting contralateral phrenic nerve paralysis.

Other complications of inter-scalene block are:

  • Horners syndrome – ptosis, myosis, anhydrosis. Due to the involvement of the sympathetic nerves in the cervicothoracic ganglion. (loss of ciliospinal reflex)
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • Vagus nerve involvement
  • Pneumothorax (stratosphere sign on ultrasound of the chest)
  • Bezold Jarisch reflex (hypotension, bradycardia and coronary vasodilation)
  • Accidental vertebral artery injection (immediate seizure is seen)
  • Accidental spinal or epidural injection

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 16-year-old female, you notice the following peculiar abnormality of the iris. This is called as
questions.solution:
Normally the pupil is placed slightly nasal to the center. This image shows an abnormally eccentrically placed pupil. This is called corectopia.

Corectopia is usually benign, non-progressive, and doesn't require any treatment. Treatment is required if it is associated with symptoms such as iritis, visual loss, etc

Other options:

Option A: The absence of the tissue of the iris, ciliary body, and choroid is known as coloboma of the uveal tract. Coloboma of the iris alone is referred to as incomplete coloboma and is typically seen in the inferonasal quadrant. Coloboma is shown in the image below. 

Option B: The presence of more than one pupil is called polycoria which is shown in the image below 

Option D: The congenital absence of an iris is known as aniridia. Complete absence is referred to as true aniridia and in the presence of a peripheral rim of the iris, it is known as clinical aniridia. Aniridia is shown in the image below

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who is a known case of neurofibromatosis type 2 presented with a headache for a few days and  2 episodes of seizures. MRI brain shows a tumor. The biopsy of the tumor specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of headache, seizures, and histopathology showing the syncytial or whorled clusters of epithelial tumour cells in a female patient of neurofibromatosis type 2 is highly suggestive of meningioma.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumours, usually attached to the dura. They are predominantly seen in females and in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2, which is an autosomal disorder associated with multiple meningiomas, schwannomas, and ependymomas.

They arise from the meningothelial cells or arachnoid cap cells. The most common karyotypic abnormality is the loss of the long arm of chromosome 22. Meningiomas often express hormone receptors (eg: Progesterone), hence, they may grow rapidly in pregnancy.

Meningiomas are rubbery, rounded, or bosselated dural masses. They compress the underlying brain tissue. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits. 

The tumour spreads in a sheet-like manner along the surface of the dura causing reactive hyperostotic changes in adjacent bones. They are mostly located in cerebral convexities. The lesions may be finely gritty due to numerous psammomatous calcifications. 

Grades of meningioma based on histologic subtypes by WHO are:

Grade I is the benign meningioma that has a relatively low risk of recurrence or aggressive growth. The histologic patterns are:

  • Meningothelial or syncytial (most common). They are clusters of epitheliod tumour cells that sit in tight groups without visible cell membranes as shown below.
  • Fibroblastic
  • Transitional
  • Psammomatous

The image below shows a meningothelial or syncytial pattern:

 

Grade II is the atypical meningioma which has a high recurrence rate and more aggressive local growth. Histologic patterns are clear cell and chordoid. 

Grade III is the anaplastic or malignant meningioma is highly aggressive often resembling carcinoma or sarcoma. Histologic patterns are papillary and rhabdoid.

The image below shows a well-defined, hyper-intense, and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline suggestive of meningioma.

 

When the meningiomas are small and asymptomatic, observation with serial MRI studies is done. When larger and symptomatic, they should be excised. External beam radiotherapy is done for unresectable tumours.

Other options:

Option B- Schwannomas are benign tumours arising from the Schwann cells. Acoustic or vestibular schwannoma arising from the vestibular portion of the eighth nerve is the most common schwannoma. Histopathologically they are composed of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B respectively. In Antoni A area, a central nuclear-free area ramified by palisading nuclei is termed as Verocay bodies. Schwannomas are associated with NF2, but they typically arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII), leading to hearing loss and balance problems, not headaches and seizures. 

The image below shows the histology of schwannoma.

Option C- Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumour seen predominantly in children. Histopathologically Homer Wright rosettes formed by tumour cells are seen as shown below.

Option D- Oligodendroglioma arises from the glial cells. A histopathologically delicate network of anastomosing capillaries resembling chicken wire is seen as shown below.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.
