questions.text: A male patient presents with a sore throat and difficulty swallowing for 2 days. On oropharyngeal examination, a grey-white membrane is observed over the tonsils. All of the following are differential diagnoses for membrane over the tonsils except
questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned options are the differential diagnosis for membrane over the tonsils except Ludwig’s angina. Ludwig’s angina is the infection of the submandibular space.

The differential diagnosis for grey membrane over the tonsils includes the following

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Aphthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

 The image given below shows acute tonsillitis presenting with a membrane over the tonsil.

The image given below shows pseudomembrane over tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

The image given below shows oral candidiasis.

Ludwig’s angina is the infection of the submandibular space. The space lies between the mucous membrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other. It is most commonly caused by dental infections

Clinically, patients present with difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) and trismus. On examination, the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental and submandibular space becomes swollen, tender, and has a woody-hard feel.

Complications of this condition include the spread of infection to the parapharyngeal space, retropharyngeal space, and the mediastinum, airway obstruction, septicemia, and aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text:
A per rectal examination of a patient revealed an enlarged nodular prostate with adherent rectal mucosa. PSA was found to be 25 ng/ml. A biopsy was done which showed adenocarcinoma of the prostate. Which of the following zones of the prostate is likely to be involved in this pathology?

PSA: Prostate specific antigen
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and findings are suggestive of a case of prostatic carcinoma. Prostatic carcinoma arises from the peripheral zone (marked 2) of the gland.

The prostate has three distinct zones as follows:

ZONE STRUCTURES ENCLOSED CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
Transitional zone Urethra  The common site for BPH (benign prostatic hyperplasia)
Central zone Ejaculatory ducts Rarely diseased
Peripheral zone

Central transitional zone

Pre-prostatic urethra

 The common site for prostatic carcinoma

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) arises from the transitional zone.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years  They may range from indolent lesions that cause no harm to aggressive metastatic tumors. Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements.

Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination. 

Only advanced disease gives rise to symptoms:

  • Bladder outlet obstruction
  • Pelvic pain and haematuria
  • Bone pain, arthritis
  • Anemia or pancytopenia
  • Renal failure

PSA (prostate specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH. A PSA >10ng/ mL is suggestive of cancer and >35 ng/ml is almost diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. Following radical prostatectomy, the serum PSA should fall to undetectable levels

A prostate biopsy using an automated gun is used to confirm the diagnosis. Around 12 systematic biopsy cores are obtained. This procedure can be done by transrectal or transperineal approach.

Gleason grading may be used after the biopsy to evaluate the stage of the histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is a low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is a high risk.

T1a Incidental histologic findings in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected

Tumor confined within the prostate

A tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a The extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)

questions.text: An 18-year-old female with a history of spontaneous bleeding from wounds and menorrhagia is diagnosed with von Willebrand disease (vWD). The factor deficient in this condition is stored in which granules/bodies of endothelial cells?
questions.solution:
The factor deficient in von Willebrand disease (vWD) is von Willebrand factor (vWF), which is stored in Weibel-Palade bodies of endothelial cells.

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. It is caused by a deficiency or defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF), a glycoprotein essential for platelet adhesion and a carrier for factor VIII. The patients with mucocutaneous bleeding, spontaneous bleeding from wounds, and menorrhagia.

The characteristics of different subtypes of vWD are:

Type 2 Qualitative defect in vWF (defective multimer) Autosomal dominant Reduced vWF activity to antigen ratio <0.6
Type 3 Near-complete (quantitative) deficiency of Factor VIII Autosomal recessive Marked reduction or absence in Factor VIII levels

Laboratory findings in vWD:

  • Prolonged bleeding time
  • Normal platelet count
  • Hess test - positive tourniquet test due to defective platelet adhesion
  • Ristocetin-induced aggregation - defective and diagnostic of this disease
  • Platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and thrombin - normal
  • Increased aPTT

  • Ionized calcium
  • Serotonin

  • Proteins involved in coagulation:

    • Coagulation factor V
    • vWF
  • Protein factors involved in wound healing:
    • Fibronectin
    • Platelet factor 4 (a heparin­ binding chemokine)
    • Platelet ­derived growth factor (PDGF)
    • Transforming growth factor­ β.

Alpha granules of platelets also store vWF. The question here specifies endothelial cells, not platelets.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels does not take part in the arterial anastomosis formed in this region of femur?
questions.solution:
The part of the femur that is pointed out in the given image is the lesser trochanter. The cruciate anastomosis is formed in this region. The superior gluteal artery does not contribute to the formation of the cruciate anastomosis.

Cruciate anastomosis:

It lies at the level of the lesser trochanter and is formed by:

  • Transverse branches of medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries
  • Descending branch of the inferior gluteal artery
  • Ascending branch of the first perforating artery

Traumatic insults to the lower extremity (fractures, stab wounds or gunshot wounds) can result in blood loss. It is important for the clinician to understand the arterial anastomoses in the affected area so that bleeding can be appropriately managed and exsanguination can be avoided.

questions.text: The given logo belongs to which of the following programmes?

choices.text: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases

questions.solution:
The image shows the logo of the National Programme for Prevention & Control of Non-Communicable Diseases (NP-NCD), which was earlier called the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS).

NPCDCS was launched in 2010 in order to prevent and control major NCDs (non-communicable diseases). It focuses on strengthening infrastructure, human resource development, health promotion, early diagnosis, management, and referral. NCD Clinics are being set up at District and CHC levels, to provide services for early diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up for common NCD. NP-NCD has specialized facilities at the district hospital level. At the subcentre level, screening and referral are done.

The NP-NCD has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, and stroke. It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states. For the cancer component, there is the Tertiary Care Cancer Centers (TCCC) scheme, which aims at setting up/strengthening State Cancer Institutes (SCI) and TCCCs all over the country, to provide comprehensive cancer care in the country. 

Note: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has been integrated with this programme in 2021.

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody is approved for use in HIV-1?
questions.solution:
Ibalizumab is a monoclonal antibody approved for use in the treatment of resistant HIV-1 infections. 

Ibalizumab blocks HIV-1 from infecting CD4+ T cells by binding to domain 2 of CD4 cells. It also interferes with post-attachment steps required for the entry of HIV-1 virus particles into host cells and thus prevents the viral transmission that occurs via cell-cell fusion.

Option A: Ixekizumab is an IL-17A antagonist indicated in moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. 

Option C: Idarucizumab is a reversal agent for dabigatran.

Option D: Ipilimumab is a monoclonal antibody against CTLA-4 and acts as an immune checkpoint inhibitor.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy came to the OPD with painful scalp swelling, pluckable hair and a discharging sinus with cervical lymph node enlargement. An image of the lesion is given below. What is the best treatment that can be given to this boy?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of the young boy suggests a kerion. Kerion is a severe inflammatory type of Tinea capitis. Of the above options, Terbinafine is the best drug.

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Endothrix - a non-inflammatory type in which multiple black dots are present within the areas of alopecia. It is most commonly caused by T. tonsurans and T. violaceum.
  • Ectothrix - a mild inflammatory type in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen. Microsporum audouinii, M.canis, M.equinnum, and M.ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.
  • Kerion - a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation. Lymphadenopathy is frequently seen. It is commonly caused by T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Favus - is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles. It is caused by T. schoenleinii.

Treatment:

  • Terbinafine: <10 Kg- 62.5 mg; 10-20 kg - 125 mg; >20 kg- 250 mg, all given daily for 4 weeks.
  • Itraconazole: 2-4 mg/kg/day for 4-6 weeks.
  • Griseofulvin: 10 mg/kg for 6 weeks (20 mg/kg considered in some T.tonsurans and T.schoenleinii infections)

Other Options:

Option A: Amoxyclav is given in case of a sebaceous cyst, and I&D is the treatment of choice, but with the above clinical scenario, it is a kerion, not a sebaceous cyst.

Option B: Oral Ivermectin is given in scabies, not in kerion.

Option D: Intralesional steroid is given in alopecia areata, not in kerion.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia

  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)

  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)

choices.text: Used as driving gas for nebulizers in asthma treatment
It reduces patient's work of breathing compared to oxygen/nitrogen mixtures

questions.solution:
The brown cylinder represents Heliox, which is a mixture of Helium and oxygen in a 79%/21% combination.

Heliox is used as a driving gas for nebulizers during bronchodilator therapy in asthma (Option A). It is particularly beneficial in reducing the work of breathing in patients with upper airway obstructions (e.g., subglottic edema, foreign bodies, tracheal tumors) or those requiring small-diameter endotracheal tubes.

Heliox improves laminar gas flow in narrowed airways due to its significantly lower density compared to nitrogen, making it advantageous for small airways. It requires a higher flow rate (11 L/min) than oxygen (6–8 L/min)(Option D). Heliox can reduce patient's work of breathing compared to conventional oxygen/nitrogen mixtures (Option C).

questions.text: Which of  the following is not true about the difference between Alteplase & Tenectplase?

choices.text: Tenecteplase has better efficacy than alteplase
Tenecteplase has simpler dosing schedule as compared to alteplase
Tenecteplase has higher fibrin selectivity than alteplase
Alteplase has a shorter duration of action than Tenecteplase

questions.solution:
Tenecteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, ie, a fibrinolytic agent. It is similar in efficacy & toxicity to Alteplase.

Tenecteplase has a longer duration of action than alteplase because it is resistant to degradation by plasminogen activator inhibitor PAI. Due to this, it has a simpler single bolus dosing regimen in the management of pulmonary embolism with haemodynamic instability, acute ischemic stroke, and acute myocardial infarction. Another advantage is that it has higher fibrin selectivity than alteplase.

However, despite these advantages, Tenecteplase is similar in efficacy & toxicity to Alteplase.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Garrod’s tetrad?
questions.solution:
Cystinosis is not a part of Garrod’s tetrad.

Garrod’s tetrad includes the following metabolic disorders:

  1. Alkaptonuria: Due to deficiency of Homogentisic oxidase.
  2. Albinism: A deficiency in tyrosinase (not tyrosine transaminase (1)).
  3. Cystinuria: A type of aminoaciduria characterized by impaired reabsorption of positively charged amino acids: Cystine, Ornithine, Lysine and Arginine (COLA)
  4. Pentosuria: Caused by a deficiency of L-xylulose reductase or xylitol dehydrogenase, shows a positive Benedict test in urine.

Cystinosis occurs due to a defect in the lysosomal cystinosis transporter, leading to increased cystine levels in the blood. This results in the accumulation of cystine crystals in the liver, kidney, bone marrow, and cornea. Treatment includes the administration of IV fluids, Sodium bicarbonate, and D-penicillamine.

questions.text: As a part of normal physiological changes in pregnancy, endometrial cells also undergo changes, as shown in the histopathological image given below. These changes are also seen in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
The changes seen in the HPE image include adenomatous changes in the endometrial glands, which is suggestive of Arias Stella reaction. Arias Stella reaction is not seen in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.

The changes shown in the histopathological image represent Arias Stella reaction, which is not seen in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. Although, on pap smear, the hypersecretory changes in the cells may look similar to atypical glandular cells, these changes are physiological and do not predispose any risk of cervical malignancy.

The Arias-Stella reaction is observed in a few cases of ectopic pregnancy cases(Option B), Gestational Trophoblastic disease (Option A), Endometriosis (Option D), and Spontaneous abortion.

The Arias-Stella reaction is characterized by adenomatous changes in the endometrial glands. It involves intraluminal budding and distinct cellular changes, including loss of cell polarity, pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, vacuolated cytoplasm, and occasional mitosis. These changes occur due to the influence of progesterone. Hormonal levels decline as these changes appear, denoting that these are probably regressive changes observed during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male diagnosed with parkinsonism and on treatment presented with the finding as seen in the image below.  Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows livedo reticularis and it is a side effect of amantadine.

Amantadine:

Amantadine inhibits the NMDA receptors(glutaminergic receptors) thereby mediating an anti-dyskinetic effect. It also blocks presynaptic dopamine reuptake, facilitates dopamine release, postsynaptic dopamine agonism, and/or dopamine receptor modulation. It also has an anti-viral effect by interfering with the function of the M2 protein and inhibiting viral replication.

 It is used in the treatment of influenza. Amantadine can be used in milder cases of parkinsonism or as a supplement to levodopa for advanced cases. It is also used in the management of levodopa-induced dyskinesia.

Adverse effects include restlessness, depression, irritability, insomnia, agitation, excitement, hallucinations, confusion, headache, heart failure, postural hypotension, urinary retention, and gastrointestinal disturbances like anorexia, nausea, constipation, and dry mouth. Livedo reticularis and peripheral edema can be seen in some cases.

Other options:

Option A: Apomorphine is a dopamine receptor agonist used in 'off' episodes of levodopa therapy.

Option B: Entacapone is a catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitor that decreases levodopa metabolism and prolongs its action.

Option D: Selegiline is an irreversible monoamine oxidase-B (MAO) inhibitor.

questions.text: The excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) are respectively caused by:
questions.solution:
The excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) are caused by Na+ influx and Cl- influx, respectively.

EPSP is produced when the interior of the post-synaptic neuron is more positive than normal, which is excitatory. It occurs due to the opening of the sodium channels causing Na+ influx. When the EPSP reaches the threshold potential, an action potential is generated.

IPSP is produced when the interior of the post-synaptic neuron is more negative. It may occur due to:

  • Opening of chloride channels causing Cl- influx.
  • Increased outward conductance through potassium channels causing K+ efflux.

Related Pearl: Comparison between EPSP vs IPSP

EPSP IPSP
EPSP is an electrical charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of excitatory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane more likely to generate an action potential. IPSP is an electric charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of inhibitory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.
EPSP is caused by Influx of Na+ or Ca2+ ions IPSP is caused by Influx of Cl- ions mainly (also by efflux of K+ ions)
Results in depolarization of membrane Results in hyperpolarization of membrane
Increases the firing rate of action potential on postsynaptic membrane Decreases the firing rate of action potential on post synaptic membrane
Neurotransmitters involved – Glutamate, Aspartate Neurotransmitters involved – Glycine, GABA

 

EPSP- Excitatory PostSynaptic Potentials

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida complains of severe abdominal pain. On examination, she is exhausted and dehydrated.  Obstructed labor is suspected and cesarean section is advocated. Which national program could potentially alleviate the financial burden for the family with regard to the recommended procedure?
questions.solution:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free cesaren section for pregnant women.

The provisions of JSSK include:

  • Free transport
  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics and diet
  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free provision of blood

Note: Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborns till 30 days after birth. Now it is expanded to cover infants also.

Assured 18 service guarantees are provided to all pregnant women under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative to provide assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare at no cost and zero tolerance for denial of services for every woman and newborn visiting the public health facility. It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths, and morbidities and provide a positive birthing experience. 

Other options :

Option A: Janani Suraksha Yojana aims to reduce maternal mortality by encouraging delivery in government health facilities. Under the scheme, a financial incentive is also provided for giving birth in a government health facility. 

Option B: The Laqshya initiative plans to conduct quality certification of labour rooms and also incentivize facilities to achieve the targets outlined. The goal of this initiative is to reduce preventable maternal and newborn mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in the labour room and maternity OT and ensure respectful maternity care.

Option D: Under the Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA), quality antenatal care (including investigations and drugs) is provided free of cost on the 9th of every month.

questions.text: An interventional radiologist implants a medical device in a patient. The X-ray of the patient is shown below. Identify the medical device.
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows an IVC Filter (Inferior Vena Cava Filter) implanted in a patient.

An inferior vena cava filter is a medical device made of metal that is implanted by vascular surgeons or interventional radiologists into the inferior vena cava to prevent a life-threatening pulmonary embolism (PE) or venous thromboembolism (VTE). The filter is designed to trap a blood clot and prevent its travel to the lung where it would form a pulmonary embolism.

The image given below shows an inferior vena cava filter in its position:

The principal indications for insertion of an IVC filter are:

  • Active bleeding (prevents the use of anticoagulation).
  • Deep vein thrombosis in a patient with a contraindication to anticoagulation.
  • Recurrent thromboembolism despite adequate anticoagulation.
  • Propagating iliofemoral venous thrombus in anticoagulation. 

Other options:

Option A: An endovascular coil blocks blood flow in aneurysms or abnormal blood vessels. It appears as metallic loops, not a cone-like structure.

Option B: A venous thrombolysis catheter is a temporary device that dissolves clots and does not appear as a metallic implant on an X-ray.

Option D: An aneurysm clip is used in brain surgeries to clip aneurysms seen near the skull. It looks nothing like an IVC filter.

questions.text: During laparoscopic hernia surgery in a male patient, a nerve located within the triangle of doom is injured. This nerve provides sensory innervation to which of the following regions?

  • Laterally- gonadal vessels in the spermatic cord
  • Posteroinferiorly- peritoneal reflection
  • Apex- deep inguinal ring

The important contents of the triangle of Doom include:

  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Other options:

Option A: The suprapubic area is supplied by the iliohypogastric nerve and it can be injured following appendicectomy. It can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in a direct inguinal hernia.

Option B: The anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament is supplied by the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient has been admitted to the casualty with seizures and loss of sensorium. The T2 weighted MRI image of the patient has been given below. Which of the following can be seen in the biopsy of the patient's brain?
questions.solution:
Cowdry type A bodies will be seen in this patient with HSV Encephalitis.

The MRI image shows hyperintensities in the temporal areas of the brain in T2 weighted MRI which is most commonly affected in herpes simplex encephalitis. The most common strain causing encephalitis is HSV-1. It most commonly affects the inferior and medial regions of the temporal lobe and orbital gyri of the frontal lobes. It causes necrosis and haemorrhages in the areas affected.

Cowdry type A inclusion bodies are seen in neurons and glial cells. They are eosinophilic and intranuclear.

Option A. Cowdry type B bodies are seen in CMV and polio virus infections. They are intranuclear inclusions.

Option B. Verocay bodies are seen in Schwannoma.

Option C. Councilman bodies are seen in the liver in viral hepatitis.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dryness and itching of eyes while staring at his laptop screen & difficulty in swallowing food unless he drinks water along with it. Schirmer’s test was positive. After further examination, bilateral parotid swelling was noted. Which of the following is not true about his condition?

choices.text: Glandular MALToma is the most common malignancy associated
Joint involvement is the most common extraglandular manifestation
Salivary glands show predominantly CD8+ cells infiltrates
It is associated with HLA DR3 positivity

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with dry eyes, difficulty swallowing solid food without water (dry mouth) and the findings of an enlarged parotid gland with a positive Schirmer’s test points to a clinical suspicion of Sjogren’s disease.

It is an autoimmune disorder that has a 10-20:1 Female-to-male incidence ratio. Lacrimal and salivary glands are the major targets of this disease where there is a characteristic decrease in tears and saliva (sicca syndrome) due to lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The infiltrate contains predominantly activated CD4+ helper T cells and some B cells, including plasma cells.

The extra glandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are:

  • Arthralgia or arthritis (Option B) - most common manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jaccoud's arthropathy. Jaccoud's arthropathy is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterised by the ulnar deviation of the second to 5th fingers with metacarpophalangeal joint subluxation.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Interstitial lung disease - the most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Renal tubular acidosis - Type 1 (distal) RTA
  • Primary biliary cholangitis
  • Lymphoma - Glandular MALToma (Option A)

Diagnosis by testing for antibodies against two ribonucleoprotein antigens -SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La). Rheumatoid factor is seen in about 75% of the patients. ANA is also often detected on immunofluorescence assay. A labial biopsy is the investigation of choice & is useful and histology of salivary glands shows lymphocytic infiltration.

Management Sjogren’s syndrome is largely symptomatic. 

  • For dry eye- hydroxymethyl cellulose lubricant drops
  • Xerostomia - water, Cevimeline - M1/M3 agonist
  • Arthritis/arthralgia- hydroxychloroquine
  • Steroids & Biologics - Rituximab for systemic disease

CD8+ve lymphocytic infiltrate is seen in HIV-associated sicca syndrome.

Option D - Patients with Sjögren’s syndrome are mainly women who have autoantibodies to Ro and La and who frequently have HLA-DR3 or B8 MHC haplotypes.

questions.text:
In the Preoperative assessment chart of a patient in the ward, you find that the patient’s airway falls under modified mallampati class III. Which of the following structures would be visible on oral examination of the patient?
  1. Hard palate
  2. Soft palate
  3. Base of Uvula
  4. Fauces
questions.solution:
The hard palate, soft palate, and Base of the uvula are visible in a Modified Mallampati class III Airway. 

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation. It is based on the size of the base of the tongue. During the assessment, the patient has to be seated, with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruding, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only classes I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. In addition to class I-IV, a fifth class is called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen when the mouth is opened and the tongue is protruded. 

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye. On fundus examination, the following finding was seen. Which among the following conditions is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows a splashed sauce appearance which is characteristic of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). 

CRVO refers to sudden or acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It presents with a sudden loss of vision. On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is present.

Funduscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive retinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots. The disc is edematous and hyperemic. Changes that occur later include neovascularization at the disc or periphery with pigmentary changes at the macula.

Complications:

  • Rubeosis iridis or neovascularization of the iris
  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) or 100 day glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

100-day glaucoma is a type of neovascular glaucoma (NVG) and is so-called because it typically develops 3 months after the episode of CRVO.

Other options:

Option A- The funduscopy findings in central retinal artery occlusion include pale retina, thread-like arteries, a cherry-red spot in the macula, and cattle trucking (segmentation of blood in the retinal veins). It is shown below.

Option C: The funduscopy in retinal detachment shows detachment of fovea and macula, as shown below.

Option D: Fundoscopy changes in retinitis pigmentosa include perivascular retinal hyperpigmentation, narrow retinal arterioles, atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium, and disc pallor. It is shown below.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought with complaints of pain and limping. The symptoms started 6 months back and gradually worsened. On examination, the child is afebrile. The child whines with pain during passive movement of the hip. The range of motion is restricted in the abduction and internal rotation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child with gradually progressing pain and limping with examination findings of limited abduction and internal rotation and X-ray showing necrosis of femoral epiphysis is likely to have Perthes's disease. 

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is  avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in children between the ages of 4 and 8, with a higher incidence in boys than girls. Perthes disease is usually unilateral but can occur bilaterally in 10% of cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia and protein C and S deficiencies.

The disease is characterized by the disruption of blood flow to the femoral head due to which the bone goes for osteonecrosis and stops growing. The lateral epiphyseal artery, a branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include pain and limping. Pain aggravates when doing any activity and is relieved by rest. Physical examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip and abduction with internal rotation movement is limited.

Xray findings depend on the stages 

  • Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus
  • Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis
  • Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase
  • Remodelling phase: Remodelling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained.

Treatment:

  • Children under 6 years - Symptomatic treatment is conservative including activity modification, reduction in weight-bearing, abduction bracing, bisphosphonates
  • Children aged 6-8 years - Operative management with proximal femoral varus osteotomy.
  • For children aged 9 and above - Operative management with pelvic osteotomy.

Other options:

Option B: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) occurs most likely in the age group of 10-15 years with an associated endocrinal disorder. Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray. Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis. When Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis, it is known as Trethowan’s sign. 

Option C: Septic arthritis can be ruled as the boy is afebrile in the given scenario. It presents as severe tenderness and all movements are abolished due to muscle spasm. Septic arthritis can present as acute, subacute, or chronic arthritis. X-rays may be normal or can show increased joint space and a soft tissue shadow corresponding to the distended capsule due to swelling of the joint. 

Option D: Developmental Dysplasia of the hip: It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip is decreased. X-ray shows a broken Shenton's line and the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrant formed by the Hilgenreiner’s line and the Perkin’s line.

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner’s line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness that worsens in the evening. He is diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. Which of the following drug can exacerbate symptoms?
questions.solution:
Azithromycin can exacerbate the symptoms of myasthenia gravis (MG) by affecting presynaptic neuromuscular transmission. 

Many drugs are known to increase weakness in patients with MG, and hence must be avoided:

  • Antibiotics like aminoglycosides, quinolones, and macrolides (azithromycin)
  • Beta-blockers
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Local anaesthetics
  • Magnesium
  • Non–depolarising muscle relaxants
  • Penicillamine
  • Quinine derivatives

Preferred drug for diagnosis of MG: Edrophonium

Treatment for myasthenia gravis involves:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents – pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice.
  • Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids like prednisone and immunosuppressive drugs like azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine. These are used when patients are significantly symptomatic despite on pyridostigmine
  • Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange. Thses are used to in severe illness like myasthenic crisis and as bridge therapy before surgery, or starting chronic immunomodulating treatment
  • Monoclonal antibodies: Rituximab is used in patients with MuSK antibody positive. Eculizumab is other monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of MG
  • Surgical approach: Thymectomy and surgical removal of thymoma.

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: Which of the following are secreted by the beta cells of the pancreas along with insulin?
questions.solution:
Amylin is secreted by the beta cells of the pancreas along with insulin. Amylin slows the rate of glucose entering the bloodstream, making it a short-term regulator of blood glucose levels.

Cells of the endocrine pancreas are divided into: 

Cell type

Secretion

A (alpha)

Glucagon

B (beta)

Insulin and amylin

D (delta)

Somatostatin

F or PP

Pancreatic polypeptide

The close interrelations among these cells allow direct control of the secretion of some of the hormones by the other hormones. For example:

  • Insulin inhibits glucagon secretion,
  • Amylin inhibits glucagon secretion, and
  • Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of insulin and glucagon.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with fever and neck stiffness since one week. He has a positive Kernig's sign. CSF analysis shows normal glucose level, increased protein level, increased lymphocyte count, and increased opening pressure. Which of the following stains would help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, India ink stain would help in the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans.

Cryptococcal meningitis is the most common cause of meningitis in an immunocompromised HIV patient. It presents with subacute meningoencephalitis with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. The CSF profile shows elevations in WBC with lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein levels, and reduced to normal levels of glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated.

The diagnosis is made by the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with Indian ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination. Indian ink is a type of negative stain that is not picked up by the capsule, making it evident.

Initiation with amphotericin B with flucytosine, which is followed by oral fluconazole as maintainance treatment is the standard of care.

Other options.

Option A: Gram stain can identify Streptococcus pneumoniae or Neisseria meningitidis, which has elevated neutrophils, decreased glucose level, and increased protein level.

Option B: Gomori methenamine silver stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii which causes fungal pneumonia.

Option C: Acid-fast stain is used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis which has lymphocyte predominance, decreased glucose, and elevated proteins.

questions.text: Based on the X-ray of the hand given below, what is the likely age of the person?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the appearance of pisiform (>10 years) but there is no fusion of the base of the 1st metacarpal (<17 years). Among the given options, the likely age of the person is <17 years.

The base of all metacarpals appears at 2-3 years of age and fuses at 15-17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is <17 years.

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age. Since it is present in this case, the age of the child is >10 years. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years.

Ossification Centres of Carpal Bones:

  • Capitate: 1-3 months
  • Hamate: 2-4 months
  • Triquetral: 2-3 years
  • Lunate: 3-4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4-6 years
  • Trapezium: 5-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5-6 years
  • Pisiform: 10-12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be <18 years.

questions.text: Paltauf’s spots are seen in:
questions.solution:
Paltauf’s spots or hemorrhages are lung findings seen in cases of drowning.

They are usually subpleural and appear as pale red to brownish spots, some as large as a fingernail. They are caused by the tearing of the capillary walls caused by massive over-distension of the lung tissue.

Other findings in drowning include cutis anserina, which refers to the appearance of goosebumps, and edema aquosum, characterized by waterlogged tissues. Emphysema aquosum occurs when the lungs are distended with fluid, giving them a spongy texture. Frothing and Cadaveric spasms may also be seen.

Diatom detection can be used to confirm drowning. This involves identifying diatoms (microscopic algae) in the bone marrow or other organs, which can indicate that water was inhaled before death.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Indirect Gonioscope?
questions.solution:
The example of an Indirect Gonioscope is Zeiss 

A gonioscope is used to measure the angle of the anterior chamber. The types of gonioscopes include:

  • Indirect gonioscopes: Provides a mirror image of the opposite angle. Examples include Goldmann, Zeiss, and Posner.
  • Direct gonioscopes: Provides a direct view of the angle. Examples include the Koeppe, Richardson, Medical Workshop, Barkan, and Swan–Jacob.

The below instrument is an indirect gonioscope- Zeiss, which uses a handle and is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber. 

Applications:

  • To view the angle of the anterior chamber. The structures visualized in order from front to back are:
        - Schwalbe’s line
        - Trabecular meshwork
        - Scleral spur
        - Ciliary body band
        - Root of iris
  • The localization of foreign bodies, abnormal blood vessels or tumours in the angle.
  • Demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae.
  • During goniotomy, a surgical procedure for the treatment of congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with severe pain over the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe. He had a history of similar episodes in the past. Synovial fluid aspirate showed negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals. The physician prescribed him a drug that catalyzes the conversion of uric acid into allantoin. What is this drug?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario shows that the patient has chronic gout. The drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which was prescribed by the physician, is pegloticase.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase) used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated. The efficacy of this drug gets lowered if antibodies are produced against the drug, which occurs in many patients. This also increases the risk of infusion reactions. 

Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase. It is indicated for the initial management of elevated plasma uric acid levels in patients with malignancies who are on chemotherapy. The efficacy is limited by the production of antibodies to the drug.

Management of gout:

  • Reduction of pain and inflammation: NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids
  • Inhibition of the formation of urate: Allopurinol, febuxostat
  • Promotion of urate excretion: Probenecid, lesinurad

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin. This reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol acts by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme preventing the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin

Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: An intern who aspires to be a surgeon did not qualify in the entrance exam. He now claims that the syllabus changed completely this year as compared to the previous year. What is the defense mechanism being used here?
questions.solution:
Justifying his inability to qualify for the exam with an excuse that the syllabus changed completely is an example of rationalization.

Reaction formation is an unconscious defense mechanism in which the person develops a wish or impulse that is a direct antithesis to the ones that are harbored consciously or unconsciously. It develops against impulses that are unacceptable to the ego.

Projection is an immature defense mechanism and it involves attributing one's own unacknowledged feelings to others.

Repression is a type of psychological defense mechanism that involves keeping certain thoughts, feelings, or urges out of conscious awareness. The goal of this form of defense is to keep unacceptable desires or thoughts out of the conscious mind in order to prevent or minimize feelings of anxiety.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

A 52-year-old female presents with complaints of fatigue and severe itching throughout her body. On investigation, serum GGT and ALP levels were found to be elevated with a mild elevation in AST and ALT levels. The histopathological image of her liver biopsy is given below. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be present in this patient?

GGT- Gamma glutamyl transferase
ALP- Alkaline phosphatase
AST- Aspartate aminotransferase
ALT- Alanine aminotransferase

choices.text: Antibodies to Liver Kidney microsomes type 1

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with the presence of florid duct lesions on histopathology is indicative of primary biliary cholangitis. The antibodies most likely to be present in PBC are anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA).

Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by portal inflammation and necrosis of cholangiocytes in small and medium-sized bile ducts. It has a strong female preponderance with a median age of 50 years.

The most common symptoms include fatigue that is out of proportion to the severity of the liver disease or the patient's age and pruritus, which is usually most bothersome in the evening. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease, including hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites, and edema are found to be present.

Amond the liver enzymes, GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. The majority of the patients show anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA) positive. A liver biopsy shows a florid duct lesion. This occurs due to the destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation.

Liver transplantation is indicated in patients with decompensated cirrhosis due to PBC. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line drug that helps to slow down the rate of progression of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Anti Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibody (ANCA) is seen in autoimmune vasculitis.

Option B: Antibodies to Liver Kidney microsomes type 1 (anti-LKM1) are characteristic of autoimmune hepatitis.

Option D: Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) may be seen in PBC, but the most common is an Anti-Mitochondrial Antibody (A). AМΑ is the serologic hallmark of PBC. It is present in approximately 95 percent of patients with ΡBС. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are found in up to 70 percent of patients with РBC.

questions.text: An arterial and a venous blood sample is drawn from a patient and a complete blood count is done separately for both samples. The test results report a high packed cell volume (PCV) in venous blood. What is the reason behind the high PCV in the venous sample?
questions.solution:
Hematocrit (PCV) of venous blood is normally 3% greater than that of arterial blood because of 2 reasons: 

  • Chloride shift(Hamburger phenomenon)
  • A small amount of fluid in the arterial blood returns via the lymphatics rather than the veins leading to decreased fluid in the venous blood.

For every CO2 molecule added in a RBC, an additional ion like Cl- or HCO3- is added which takes up water and leads to an increase in size of the cell leading to an increase in PCV. The combined effect of decreased fluid in the veins combined with the increased cellular mass due to the Hamburger phenomenon leads to the overall increase in PCV.

Chloride shift:

  • Upon entering the red blood cell, CO2 is rapidly hydrated to H2CO3 by carbonic anhydrase.
  • H2CO3 is in equilibrium with H+ and its conjugate base, HCO3-.
  • H+ can interact with deoxyhemoglobin, whereas HCO3- can be transported outside of the cell via anion exchanger 1 (AE1 or Band 3).
  • In effect, for each CO2 molecule that enters the red cell, there is an additional HCO3- or Cl- in the cell.
  • Because of this chloride shift, the Cl – content of the red cells in venous blood is significantly greater than that in arterial blood.\

Other options:

Options A and B: Haldane effect is the increased capacity of deoxygenated haemoglobin to bind and carry CO2, Bohr's effect is the decrease in O2 affinity of haemoglobin when the pH of the blood falls.

Option D: 2,3 BPG is formed from glycolysis. It is found in high amounts in red blood cells and in trace amounts in most other cells. 2,3 BPG facilitates increased oxygen delivery by reducing the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.
